maania
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: red tussock
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/11/2003
Source:  NZ Geographic
Author:
Vol / Page:  No. 66/40
Edition:
Quote:  Maori names for tussock varied from region to region. In one southern dialect, <i>wi</i> was used for silver tussock (furher north the same word was applied to rushes) and <i>patiti</i> seemed to be a general term for tall tussocks, with <i>maania</i> an alternative or the word for red tussock in particular. The Maniatoto (<i>maania</i> = blood, <i>toto</i> = plain) was formerly covered in red tussock.
Notes:

Notes:  (And)

Date:  0/0/1954
Source:  Personal Communication
Author:  R MASON
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Mabel Island lily (Arthropodium cirrhatum).</i> Name used sometimes in Wellington and Marlborough. The plant grows on Mabel Island near Picton but is not known to grow elsewhere near Picton. It is the <i>renga-lily, rock lily </i>etc. of Auckland.

[cf ? 1830 <i>Lycopodium ramulosum </i>T. Kirk]

Mackenzie Country
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a large pastoral basin of inland South Canterbury, named after the legendary James Mackenzie, purported to have been caught there with stolen sheep.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

mackerel
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a common name for fishes resembling the northern hemisphere mackerel, esp. <i>Pneumatophorus</i> sp., the southern mackerel; and <i>Trachurus novae-zelandicae,</i> horse mackerel


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: early spellings mackarel, mackrel, etc.

Date:  8/11/1769
Source:  Cook's Journals
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/195
Edition:
Quote:  The natives ... sold us ... as much fish as served all hands, they were of the Mackerel kind and as good as ever was eat. [f@n1] The Southern Mackerel, <i>Pneumatophorus colias. </i>
Notes:

Date:  9/11/1769
Source:  Banks Journal
Author:
Vol / Page:  2/428
Edition:  1962
Quote:   ... a vast number of boats were on board almost loaded with macarel of 2 sorts, one exactly the same as is caught in England. [fn.] The Southern Mackerel, <i>Pneumatophorus colias</i> (Gm), is rather similar to the English species. The other sort was perhaps <i>Trachurus novae-zelandicae</i> Richardson.
Notes:

Author:  YATE
Vol / Page:  71
Edition:
Quote:  ... in the mackerel-season, when several tribes go together to the little creeks where these fish frequent, and always succeed in capturing some hundreds of thousands before they return

ibid 109 Their method of preparing the mackarel is different ... It is gutted, throughly washed with sea-water, and hung up to drain ...
Notes:   (Griffiths Collection)

Date:  0/0/1835
Source:  New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author:  YATE
Vol / Page:  71
Edition:
Quote:  [mackarel] Those saltwater fish] most plentiful, and of greatest note, are, soles, mackarel, cod-fish, a species of salmon, whiting, snapper, mullet, bream, skate, gurnards, and a few smaller kinds, some not near so large as a sprat; with an abundance of crayfish, oysters, shrimps, prawns, muscles, and cockles. <i>Ibid.</i> 85 In their great fishing-expeditions for mackarel, all concerned in making or mending the nets, the ground upon which those nets are made, the river upon the banks of which the work goes on, are all in a state of sacredness; ...

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Fisherman's Bible
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  267
Edition:
Quote:  BONITO Offshore anglers use bonito fillets for snapper bait and deep-sea anglers claim its dark-red flesh attracts almost every sporting fish up to shark and marlin. It is known as Mackerel, Horse Mackerel, Skippy, Skipper and Skipjack because of its habit of breaking the surface when feeding. The name `Skipjack' has also been applied however to at least half-a-dozen other species.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1927
Source:  Natural History of Canterbury
Author:  SPEIGHT
Vol / Page:  199
Edition:
Quote:  The only true mackerels recorded from Canterbury are the Pacific Bonito <i>Sarda chiliensis</i>) and the large-scaled Tunny (<i>Gasterochisma melampus</i>) which may reach a length of 6 feet; but a related family includes the well-known Barracouta (<i>Thyrsites atun</i>), the King Barracouta, <i>Jordanidia solandrii</i> (often known locally as Kingfish, but not to be confused with the North Island Kingfish which is a form or Yellowtail) and the elongated, silvery-hued frost fish (<i>Lepidopus caudatus</i>) whose curious stranding habits can hardly yet be said to be satisfactorily explained. tentatively divided into 1. <i>Trachurus</i> spp. JACK MACKEREL HORSE MACKEREL a. <i>T novaezelandiae</i> of south-east Asian distribution; and b. <i>T. declivis</i> restricted to Australasia 2. <i>Scomber australasicus</i> and Indo-Pacific species, (COMMON) MACKEREL, BLUE MACKEREL, ENGLISH MACKEREL (from its similarity to the N. hemisphere species), FRIGATE MACKEREL, PACIFIC MACKEREL, SOUTHERN MACKEREL; 3. of uncertain attribution

Date:  0/0/1872
Source:  Edible Fishes
Author:  HECTOR
Vol / Page:  112
Edition:
Quote:  32. MACKEREL. ... This valuable fish (<i>Scomber australasicus</i>) is only known to me from two large hauls ... made in Wellington Harbour about the 15th December, 1870, but it appears to be the fish ... called by the natives [113] Tawa-tawa. ... [It] is very superior in delicacy to the Scad or Horse Mackerel, which is commonly called the Mackerel in New Zealand.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1886
Source:  Handbook Fishes of NZ
Author:  SHERRIN
Vol / Page:  61
Edition:
Quote:  MACKEREL (<i>Scomber Australasicus</i>). ... This valuable fish is well known as an occasional visitant in Wellington Harbour, being called by the Natives tawatawa. In colour, size, and form it closely approaches the common mackerel of England, and is very superior in delicacy to the scad or horse-mackerel, which is commonly called the mackerel in New Zealand.
Notes:

(c) Other common names: (i) Common Mackerel, Frigate mackerel, English mackerel (ii) Horse Mackerel. (d) Principal localities where taken: (both) Gisborne, Nelson, Picton ...

Macquarie cabbage

Definition: an old name for the Chatham Island lily.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1870
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  2/176
Edition:
Quote:  The Snares are] almost entirely covered with scrub and trees of stunted growth, the Tupari, Akeake, and Kokomuka. Of M'Quarrie cabbage there is abundance, and of fine growth, some of the leaves measuring two feet in diameter.Patches clear of scrub are clothed with Lutaki tussock. <i>Myosotidium hortensia</i> (formerly <i>M. nobile</i>)  = CHATHAM ISLAND LILY

Macquarie cabbage
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: Stilbocarpa polaris
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: more fully Macquarie Island cabbage
Citations
Date:  0/0/1997
Source:  Field Guide to Native Edible Plants of NZ
Author:  CROWE
Vol / Page:  84
Edition:
Quote:  Macquarie Island cabbage <i>Stilbocarpa polaris </i> Punui... The early whalers and sealers called the plant Macquarie Island cabbage, eating it as a remedy for, and as prevention against, scurvy.
Notes:

Date:  0/8/2000
Source:  NZWords
Author:
Vol / Page:  No. 4 : 7
Edition:
Quote:  So did Macquarie Island, an Australian possession that features in New Zealand English, as Orsman documented, at least in the case of the plant Macquarie cabbage <i>Stilbocarpa polaris</i>. Although the Macquarie cabbage takes its name

from an island now belonging to Australia, the earliest quotations I have found are in the <i>Transactions of the New Zealand Institute</i> (1870 and 1883... This plant occurs on the Auckland, Campbell and Antipodes Islands, as well as on Macquarie, and has been reported from the Snares.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1883
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  15/448
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Stilbocarpa polaris</i>, `Macquarie Island Cabbage' of the sealers, in flower and fruit [on Macquarie Island].
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Oxford Book of NZ Plants
Author:  MOORE & IRWIN
Vol / Page:  96
Edition:
Quote:  <i>STILBOCARPA POLARIS. </i>... Early whalers and sealers used the plant as an antiscorbutic, hence the old name `Macquarie Island cabbage'. According to experience in 1950-51, `The petioles taste like celery when cooked; pickled rhizomes taste like turnips; and leaves when cooked like wet blotting paper' (Taylor 1955).
Notes:

Quote:  Our crib was shielded from the road by a macrocarpa hedge. Actually, the term "hedge" does not convey the reality. A better description might be our crib was shielded from the road by a small forest of enormous macrocarpa trees masquerading as a hedge.

macrocarpa
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the common name of <i>Cupressus macrocarpa</i> 
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: the tree; Californian, naturalised in NZ where it grows distinctively, is named distinctively (as opposed to US Monterey Cypress), and where there is a variety of cultivars.
Citations
Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Carpathians, The
Author:  FRAME
Vol / Page:  194
Edition:

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1961
Source:  Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page:  1355
Edition:
Quote:  <i>macrocarpa n</i> -s [NL <i>macrocarpa</i> (specific epithet of <i>Cupressus macrocarpa</i>), fr. <i>macr- + -carpa</i> (fr. Gk <i>karpos</i> fruit) - more at HARVEST] : a New Zealand evergreen shrub or tree (<i>Cupressus macrocarpa</i>) that is used for hedges and that sometimes causes abortion in cattle that browse on it.
Notes:

Quote:  [Hdg] The secretive surf clams, the larger shellfish showing its foot is mactra; the smaller is the spisula... The huge mactra surf clam, and the smaller triangular spisula are "new" in the sense that there is no tradition of eating them in New Zealand, despite their being indigenous to our islands.

mad as a gumdigger's dog
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition: very angry
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  14/2/2004
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  48
Edition:
Quote:  Where do the sayings "Mad as a gum-digger's dog", "mad a a meat axe" and "Mad as a cut snake" come from? asks Barry Wheaton of Hobsonville... In New Zealand, from the mid-19th century, gumdiggers grubbed a living retrieving fossil kauri gum from the land and their dogs were often disparaged as skinny, useless or mad.
Notes:

mad as a maggot
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition: very angry or mad
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: cf. mad as a meat axe; go maggoty
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1935 Havelock
Citations
Date:  0/0/1943
Source:  English as it is spoken in NZ
Author:  BENNETT
Vol / Page:  90
Edition:
Quote:  The verbs <i>to go snaky, to go maggoty</i> (cf U.S. <i>maggoty</i>, whimsical) [mean to show anger or annoyance]. Phrases like `mad as a maggot', `mad as a meat-axe' are obviously linked with these expressions (some though not all of which may be heard in Australia; cf. Australian <i>snake-headed,</i> annoyed); whether <i>mad</i> in the sense of angry is a survival of an English provincialism, or has been introduced from America, is not clear.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1956
Source:  Green Kiwi
Author:  SUTHERLAND
Vol / Page:  121
Edition:  1960
Quote:  `Good bloke,' said Bailey, `Mad as a maggot, of course,' ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1959
Source:  Gun in My Hand, A
Author:  SLATTER
Vol / Page:  43
Edition:
Quote:  Mad as a maggot. Ya shoulda married her.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Collected Plays
Author:  BAXTER
Vol / Page:  24
Edition:  1968
Quote:  Young Jack Skully, mad as a maggot, singing out in the dark.
Notes:  (Wide Open Cage)

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  71
Edition:
Quote:  <i>mad as a maggot </i>very mad, very silly, very angry, very eccentric; Gordon slatter; eg `Old Millie's mad as a maggot, you know, hosing the lawn when it's raining, that sort of thing.'

mad money
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1935
Source:  Slang Today
Author:  PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page:  285
Edition:
Quote:   [The] following [was] employed by those who served in the [Great] War ...<i> mad money,</i> return fare, it being very generally believed by the New Zealand troops (<i>Fernleaves </i>or, as they preferred to call themselves, <i>Diggers</i>) that every English girl infallibly carried her return fare in case her soldier friend became <i>mad</i>, i.e., acted with excessive freedom of manner;
Notes:  1935 Mitchell and Strong in Partridge Slang Today 285



Date:  0/0/1941
Source:  NZ Slang
Author:  BAKER
Vol / Page:  50
Edition:
Quote:  Terms originated in the first Great War [include] ... <i>mad money</i>, a return fare carried by a soldier's feminine acquaintance in case she `got mad' because of too-amorous attention.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1938
Source:  Dictionary of Slang
Author:  PARTRIDGE

Vol / Page:  503
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Mad money</i>. A girl's return fare, carried lest her soldier friend got `mad', i.e. too amorous for her: New Zealand soldiers': 1916-18. Mostly a legend, and concerning only English girls. -->[Supplement] Has, since ca1918, meant money that a girl carries as a precaution against any such quarrel with her boy friend as might leave her monetarily stranded, and been widely used also in Australia and Canada.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  71
Edition:
Quote:  <i>mad money</i> splurge money; originally return ship fare WWI soldiers believed English girls brought with them in case their Kiwi soldier boy went mad, ie acted with excessive freedom. <i>[Baker] <.i>
Notes:

Vol / Page:  277
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Mado, n.</i> A Sydney fish, <i>Therapon cuvieri</i>, Bleek; called also <i>Trumpeter-Perch. Atypus strigatus,</i> Gunth., is also called <i>Mado</i> by the Sydney fishermen, who confound it with the first species. The name is probably aboriginal.
Notes:

Quote:  <i>Atypichthys strigatus </i>(Guenther). MADO.

Vol / Page:  245
Edition:
Quote:  SWEEP Good-eating, deep-bodied fish that belong to the family <i>Scorpidae</i>. The young are frequently caught in the shallow waters near wharves, ... One member of the family, the Mado, - figures prominently in the catches of saltwater fishermen seeking snapper and blue maomao.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Collins Guide
Author:  AYLING
Vol / Page:  231
Edition:  1984
Quote:  <i>MADO</i> (Stripy) <i>Atypichthys latus (Atypichthys strigatus)</i> ... The mado is a small fish similar in shape and size to the sweep ... Until recently it was thought to be <i>Atypichthys strigatus </i> but examination of specimens of [231] ths species from Australia showed that this was not so and in fact the New Zealand mado proved to be another similar Australian species <i>Atypichthys latus. </i>
Notes:

madoo
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Maori <i>matu</i>. <i>Reed's Concise     matu</i>: fat <i>Williams matu</i>: 1. fat 2. richness 3. gist, kernel
Citations
Date:  0/0/1991
Source:  Working the Kauri
Author:  Duncan Mackay
Vol / Page:  27
Edition:
Quote:  '... Sawing was especially difficult when there was a lot of gum in the tree trunk. The gum became hot from the action of the saw and made the saw blade sticky and hard to drive. The cross-cutters always had a tin of 'madoo', a mixture of kerosene and salt-free fat, which they used to lubricate the blade.'
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Quest for Kauri
Author:  SALE
Vol / Page:  159
Edition:
Quote:  On the log, too, are the steel wedges which kept the cut open and prevented the saw jamming, and finally helped the tree on it's way down; the maul for driving the wedges; and the tin of madoo, a special mix of kerosene and salt-free dripping used to keep the saw blade free of gum (and was made up by the bush cooks).
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  World of the Kauri, The
Author:  HALKETT & SALE
Vol / Page:  89
Edition:
Quote:  Saws themselves were kept free of accumulations of sticky gum by being lubricated with "maddoo", a mixture of kerosene and salt-free dripping made up by the camp cook.
Notes:  [224] Madoo: A special mix of kerosene and salt-free dripping used to keep a saw blade free of gum.  Also used to grease the skids of the "catamaran" used for hauling cut logs.

maggie
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the ace of hearts in the card-game of FORTY-FIVES.


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1980
Source:  Ghost Towns of NZ
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  127
Edition:
Quote:  Old Calamity was an early one-man band of fiddle, horn, cymbals and kettledrums. Gambling was poker of 45s, a diggers' card game from California involving legs, queer suits and Maggie, cries of `Get Jinx!' and `Go for the Doctor!'
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1948
Source:  Our Own Country
Author:
Vol / Page:  99
Edition:
Quote:  In smoky little back parlours [in Westport] friendly little groups meet to play `forty-fives' with uproarious oaths and much heavy thumping of the table. For [100] the uninitiated it may be stated that in this game the <i>five-fingers</i> (the five of the trump suit) beats all other cards. The trump suit order is five, jack, ace, king queen - all other suits begin with the king. Non-trump suits win high in red; low in black. Obviously the ace of diamonds is the lowest card in the pack unless diamonds are trumps, in which case it is the fourth best. The word "obviously' in the preceding sentence is a little optimistic - as the ace of hearts (the Maggy) is always the third best trump. It is credibly reported (a) that the game is of Irish origin (b) that there are no written rules (c) that the game can only be learned by playing it, and (d) it is as charactistic of Westport as whitebait or coal.
Notes:

Date:  0/1/1999
Source:  NZWords
Author:
Vol / Page:  1
Edition:
Quote:  New Zealand legal words may have a substantial local history.     One instance is magistrate. Initially, the term was a synonym for justice of the peace, as it was and largely still is in England.
Notes:

magistrate's court
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a local court, with powers to try minor cases (summary jurisdiction), and to hold preliminary inquiries into more serious cases which may go to a higher court. In New Zealand now called a District Court.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: magistrate's or magistrates'?
Citations
Date:  0/1/1999
Source:  NZWords
Author:
Vol / Page:  1
Edition:
Quote:  Generally  known  simply  as magistrates (or SMs) they were legally qualified and exercised increasingly important judicial functions in magistrates courts  These had a general jurisdiction - civil, criminal and domestic - that set them apart from English magistrates courts which mainly dealt with petty crime and were presided over by justices of the peace. Magistrates courts were renamed district courts and their presiding judges district court judges in 1981, but the term magistrate in New Zealand denoted stipendiary magistrates rather than justices of the peace, who were and are usually referred to simply as justices or JPs.
Notes:

Notes:

Date:  15/9/1918
Source:  Kia-ora Coo-ee
Author:
Vol / Page:  Second Series 3/12
Edition:  1981
Quote:  In this land two infections assail all comers and vie with one another for first place. These are known as Malaria and Balkan Tap respectively. On the first we need not dwell, but a little information about the latter may be of interest. A similar infection has been met with elsewhere, and in Gyppo Land is known as `magnune', whilst away in our own sunny island I think `dippy' about covered it. Here we have a more or less insidious form of the disease, and no one with six months' residence to his credit may hope to escape. There are two varieties of the disease, malignant and benign. In the latter form the symptoms are easily recognised, and are amenable to treatment; but with the malignant type the victims, quite unconscious of infection, blindly affirm their condition to be normal, This form of the malady has several unfortunate features and is incurable. The percentage in our unit is very high.
Notes:

The total of 25 successful defences was a record until Auckland took over in the 1980s.

Notes:

Date:  16/9/1972
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  11/7-9
Edition:
Quote:  Magpie Moth (Nyctemera annulata) 1970: 2 1/2c: Definitive issue. (Later overprinted 4c.)

The second moth is the common and conspicuous Magpie Moth, a day-flying member of the large family noctuidae. Its members include many destructive species, whose caterpillars are known as `army worms.' They sometimes appear in enormous numbers, causing considerable damage to crops and pastures.

mahoe
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:

I am a totara and pointing to a young man, he is a ngaio

Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  61/'142
Edition:
Quote:  17. <i>Caulopsetta scapha</i> Forster. Megrim or Witch. Maori: Mahoa
Notes:   (Young)

Date:  0/0/1956
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  GRAHAM
Vol / Page:  186
Edition:
Quote:  NEW ZEALAND MEGRIM or WITCH (MAHUE)<i> Caulopsetta scaphus</i> (Bloch and Schneider) In Napier it is known as Lantern-fish, but for what reason I am unable to say, unless it is from the peculiar transparency when it/is held up to a strong light. Another name given to this useless fish by local fishermen, in Port Chalmers at least, was that of Cadger's-fish.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Fisherman's Bible
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  74
Edition:
Quote:  MEGRIM ... Sometimes called Lantern-fish (because a lantern could be easily shone through it) and known to the Maoris as `mahue' - the fish that is left behind. Known to Christchurch fishermen in early years as the Bludger's Fish. It was the fish they handed out to well-known bludgers who came down to the docks to cadge fish.
Notes:

Date:  8/12/1982
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  37
Edition:
Quote:  Ironically, the most abundant of all New Zealand flounders, the witch or megrim, is useless for eating because of its multitude of long thin hair-like bones and thin watery flesh. The Maori name for this fish - mahue - says it all. It translates as `to be left behind'.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Collins Guide
Author:  AYLING
Vol / Page:  307
Edition:  1984
Quote:  <i>WITCH </i>(Megrim, mahue) <i>Arnoglossus scapha</i> ... The witch is a thin-bodied left eye floundr with an oval shape ... However, they have no commercial value as they have thin watery flesh and many fine bones.

mahuta
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the last strand of a coal-mining pillar
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/2000
Source:  Dream of Nikau Jam, The
Author:  HAWES
Vol / Page:  85
Edition:
Quote:  As you worked at the pillar - picking, shotfiring, shovelling an' that - it got thinner an' thinner until in the end it looked like a big black tornado, or a tree holding up the sky. That's why the last strand of the pillar is called a 'mahuta'. Things got very tricky at this stage, because the coal in the mahuta was amazingly easy to win; just one gentle prod with yer pick and the coal just blew out... It was tempting to have one last go at the easy stuff in the mahuta, but get it wrong and you brought the roof down on yer head.
Notes:

Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1838
Source:  New Zealand  (Polack)
Author:  POLACK
Vol / Page:  1/137
Edition:
Quote:  We passed an extensive grove containing a Wai-tapu [a2-acute]. In this place was deposited the bones of a male and female chief ... The house which enclosed these remains of mortality was built of old canoes, ... [138] It was surmounted with a <i>maihi</i>, or frontispiece, which was decorated with feathers.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1840
Source:  Manners & Customs of the NZers
Author:  POLACK
Vol / Page:  1/123
Edition:
Quote:  Round the top a head-board (<i>maihi</i>) was affixed, on which a number of obscene figures were carved. <i>Ibid.</i> 1/206 Over the door-ways and window-sills, handsomely carved boards are fixed, painted in flaming red, these are placed horizontally or in a gable form called <i>maihi</i>, surmounted by a wooden image termed the <ik>taupare</i> [a2-acute] <i>warre</i> [e-acute]; some of these figures are exceedingly droll. ... [Caption] The Maihi, a carved board for the front of a house, surmounted by the Toupare [e-acute], or figure-head.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1895
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  27/674
Edition:
Quote:  The ridge-boards are carved to represent a number of<i> ngarara</i>, or lizards, running along the roof, and the <i>maihi</i>, or gable-boards, have carvings of the mythological animal known as the <i>manaia</i> - probably a kind of taniwha.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1904
Source:  Maori Race, The
Author:  TREGEAR
Vol / Page:  273
Edition:
Quote:  In front of the verandah of a house, short perpendicular slabs (<i>amo</i>), often carved or painted, supported the barge-boards (<i>maihi</i>) of the gable, and formed very striking and highly embellished adornments.

Date:  0/6/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/153
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Maihi,</i> facing-boards joining a gable of Maori house, ornamented with incised carving, deeply incised at lower ends, even perforated: the koruru covers the join at gable, a grotesque figure surmounting the koruru: the upright supports at lower ends are amo.
Notes:   (J.C.Andersen)

Edition:

mail day
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1

Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:  Another term brought over from Australia [from the 1860's on] was "maimai' for a rough shelter from the weather. It was said to be a name for a black-fellow's camp, which I have always seen spelt `miamia', and which is called `gunyah' or `wurley', etc. by some tribes. We now apply the name to shooting shelters.

Date:  0/0/1873
Source:  Pakeha Rambles Through Maori Lands
Author:  ST JOHN
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  In the days of bush fighting it used to be a common occurrence at the end of a day's march, when <i>maemaes</i> had been knocked up by the side of a stream, to see ... men gravely set to work with pannikin ... and `wash' for a prospect. ... [Orig. footnote] A low hut worked up with sticks and interlaced raupo or fern, open in front, with roof reaching to the ground on the windward side. [NB. There were Australian `Volunteers' in the later Maori Wars]
Notes:  1873 St. John Pakeha Rambles in 1959 Taylor Early Travs. 555

Date:  0/0/1914
Source:  History of North Otago
Author:
Vol / Page:  43
Edition:  1978
Quote:  Other evidence that the Maoris camped in this locality was the remains of what I believed were called mai-mais. These were shelters made by plaiting the tips of the leaves of a large flax bush in such a manner as to form an arched canopy.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1947
Source:  Early Runholding in Otago
Author:  BEATTIE
Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:  In 1851 a number of Australian `squatters' came over and took up runholding in Canterbury, but, generally speaking, their advent was some years later in Otago. ... They brought over a number of Australian aborigine words that were new to this side, and which were used a certain amount, usually in a joking manner as far as I know. I have heard some of them fairly frequently used by the `old hands,' sometimes oracularly and sometimes as a semi-humorous quotation. When I was a boy I heard sheep called `jumbucks,' an Australian aborigine term for them, but with the decease of ex-Australian stockmen the word has gone out of use now. Another term brought over from Australia was `maimai,' for a rough shelter from the weather. It was said to be a name for a blackfellow's camp, which I have always seen spelt `miamia,' and which is called `gunyah' or `wurley,' etc., by some tribes. We now apply the name to shooting shelters.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1945
Source:  Historical Southland
Author:  HALL-JONES
Vol / Page:  107
Edition:
Quote:  Many a pioneer camped under a tree or a flaxbush while he made a clearing and planted his seeds. The next stage was a maimai, a crude shelter of boughs still used by duckshooters.
Notes:

mainland island
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an area of mainland (as opposed to offshore) vegetation where predatory mammals, such as rats and possums, are controlled or removed to allow native animals and plants to survive; an onshore sanctuary for indigenous plant and animal species
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Environment
Region: [none]

Pronunciation:

One of the cockers gave my father a beautiful white cock, his comb dubbed, trimmed and fighting fit. <i>Ibid.</i> 348 The clamorous challenges of the old English game cocks melted the hearts of some of the committee-men but cock fights were not part of the popularity of the [Greymouth] Poultry Show and mains did not materialise

Vol / Page:  1/III/34

Quote:  The Ake (<i>Dodonaea viscosa</i>), and the Maire, (<i>Santalum Cunninghamii</i> at the North, and <i>Olea sp</i>. at the South,) supplied hardwood for war implements ... <i>Ibid.</i> 46 The Maire:- two, or more, very distinct genera, containing several trees, (<i>Santalum Cunninghamii</i>, and <i>Olea</i> sp.,) are confounded under this Native name; althogh the natives themselves generally [47] distinguish them pretty clearly, - calling the <i>Olea</i>, Maire-rau-nui. Both were by them called maire, from the fact of both being hard-wooded ... <i>Ibid.</i> 50 (<i>known hard woods</i>.) The Mairetawhake, (<i>Eugenia Maire</i>); the Rohutu (<i>Myrtus pedunculata), ... The Maire (Santalum Cunninghamii) </i>... the Manoao (<i>Dacrydium Colensoi</i>), a small hard-wooded pine ...

Date:  0/0/1875
Source:  Durability NZ Timbers
Author:  KIRK
Vol / Page:  21
Edition:
Quote:  MAIRE.- <i>(Olea cunninghamii</i> and <i>O. lanceolata.</i>) ... BLACK MAIRE.- (<i>Olea apetala.</i>) ... MAIRE.- (<i>Santalum cunninghamii</i>.) These afford fine-grained timber of great density ... All are commonly called `Maire' alike by settlers and Natives. Black maire usually attains the largest dimensions, and is sometimes 40 feet high or more. <i>Santalum</i> is the least of the group, but even stems of this ... make durable fencing rails. ... All the kinds are confined to the North Island ...

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page:  2026
Edition:
Quote:   <i>Ma&#769;.i-re</i> (ma.&#769;.e.-r&amacr.; <i>colloq.</i> m&imacr.&#769;.r&emacr.),<i> n</i>. [Maori.]<i> (Bot.) Any one of several New Zealand trees : - (a) Olea lanceolata, of the order Jasmineae; -called white maire by Auckland bushmen. (b) Fusanus Cunninghamii,</i> of the order <i>Santalaceae</i>; called also <i>New Zealand sandalwood. (c) Olea Cunninghamii</i>, of the order<i> Jasmineae; - often called</i> black maire <i>by bushmen</i>. (d) Olea <i>apetala</i>, of the order <i>Jasmineae</i>; - called also <i>broad-leaved maire. (e) Olea montana</i>, of the order <i>Jasmineae</i>; - called also <i>narrow-leaved maire. (f) Eugenia maire</i>, of the order <i>LMyrtaceae</i>; - called by the Maoris <i>maire-tawhaka.</i>
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  279
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Maire, n</i>. A Maori name applied to three kinds of trees; viz. (I) <i>Santalum cunninghamii,</i> Hook., a sandal-wood; (2) <i>Olea</i> of various species (formerly <i>Fusanus</i>); (3) <i>Eugenia maire</i>, A. Cunn., Native box-wood, but now usually confined to N.O. <i>Santalaceae. </i>
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1907
Source:  Plants of NZ
Author:  LAING & BLACKWELL
Vol / Page:  334
Edition:  1940,p. 355
Quote:  <i>Olea Cunninghamii (The Black Maire*)[(The Maire*)</i>]. A large tree, with whitish branches. ... The wood is dark brown or black, and is hard, heavy, and durable. ... [fn *] This name is also applied to Mida [salicifolia], ... , and to Eugenia, ...

Date:  0/0/1961
Source:  Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page:  1363
Edition:
Quote:  <i>maire n</i> -s [Maori] : any of several New Zealand trees with dense heavy wood: as a : a New Zealand tree of the genus Olea - usu. used with a descriptive qualifier; compare BLACK MAIRE, WHITE MAIRE<i> b </i>: a small light-barked tree (<i>Eugenia maire</i>) with white flowers followed by red berries <i>c</i> : a small and often shrubby tree (<i>Mida myrtifolia</i>) that is related to the Asiatic sandalwood and has glossy glabrous usu. alternate leaves and small brownish green flowers in axillary clusters followed by small red drupes

Source:  Handbook of New Zealand
Author:  HECTOR
Vol / Page:  132
Edition:
Quote:  Maire - a small tree ten to fifteen feet high, six to eight inches in diameter; wood hard, close-grained, heavy, used by Maoris in the manufacture of war implements. Has been used as a substitute for box by wood-engravers. Black maire, <i>N.O. Jasmineae</i>; also Maire-rau-nui, <i>Olea Cunninghamii.</i> Hook., fil., Black M., forty to fifty feet high, three to four feet in diameter, timber close-grained, heavy, and very durable.

The Maire-aunui (<i>Olea Cunninghamii</i>), which ... is a much bigger tree than the maire, but does not yield such valuable timber.

Quote:  The Maire:- two, or more, very distinct genera, containing several trees, (<i>Santalum Cunninghamii</i>, and <i>Olea</i> sp.,) are confounded under this Native name; althogh the natives themselves generally [47] distinguish them pretty clearly, - calling the <i>Olea</i>, Maire-rau-nui. Both were by them called maire, from the fact of both being hard-wooded ...

Author:  MONRO
Vol / Page:  262
Edition:
Quote:  Behind Toutuki, [the prospective Otago settler] may explore the mountain dreaded by the natives, on account of its being the favourite residence of the mairoero. This is a wild man of the woods, strong, cunning, and mischievous, and addicted to running off with young people and damsels. His body is covered with coarse and long hair, which also flows down from the back of his head nearly to his heels. To com-[263]pensate for this excessive quantity behind, his forehead is said to be bald. He was vividly described to us by a Maori who had seen one long ago, when he was a little boy, and was of opinion that `there is not a more fearful wild-fowl that your <i>mairoero</i> living.'
Notes:  1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 262-263

The `Indian' name that Anderson gives is unknown to the dictionary, and may well be one of the many South Island Maori words that were never collected.]]

makawhiti
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: aua, sea mullet
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1872
Source:  Edible Fishes
Author:  HECTOR
Vol / Page:  114
Edition:
Quote:  58. SEA MULLET. ... The Makawhiti or Aua of the Maoris (<i>Agonostoma Forsteri</i>) ... is a common fish ... It is commonly called Herring, from its general resemblance in size and form to that fish, but is easily recognisable from the true Herring by having two fins on the back, ... The Picton Herring, a dried fish commonly known throughout the colony, is the Aua preserved by smoking.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1878
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  10/326
Edition:
Quote:  [Maori or Settlers' Name] Herrings, Makawhiti .. [Scientific Name] <i>Agonostoma forsteri </i>
Notes:   (P. Thomson, Otago)

Date:  0/0/1886
Source:  Handbook Fishes of NZ
Author:  SHERRIN
Vol / Page:  65
Edition:
Quote:  MAKAWHITI (<i>Agonostoma Forsteri</i>). ... Called the sea-mullet in other places, but the makawhiti or aua by the Maoris. It is a common fish, Dr. Hector says, obtained at all seasons of the year by fishing from the wharves in the harbours. In Dunedin it is known as the mullet. ... The Picton herring, a dried fish, commonly known throughout the colony, is the aua, preserved by smoking.
Notes:

Vol / Page:  30

Quote:  By mid-June [1864] disappointed miners were returning from Picton to try once again to `make a rise' from the banks of the Clutha where it was possible to realise at least a couple  of pennyweights a day using only the humble cradle.

In Otago, it is the New Zealand Currant, or Moko-mok'. In Canterbury, it is called the Wine-berry. In the North Island, it is the Mako-mako.

In the North Island, it is the Mako-mako. <i>A. ruliceps.</i> PELZ.

makomako
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 3
Definition: a reshaping of the heard Maori form, often under the false impression that the makomako is a mocking-bird (as is the tui) though some, e.g. Bathgate, attribute spg to variant Otago Maori dialectal form <i>mokomoko.</i>


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: contrast and compare mocker @n1, mockie; and Marsh cit. spg <i>mok-e-mok</i> prob. referring to tui (see at mocker, mockie)
Citations

Quote:  13. ANTHORNIS MELANURA. Sparm. Bell-bird. Mocker. Korimoko. Moko-moko.
Notes:   [? Hutton's mis-spelling: cf korimoko]

Notes:  (Dieffenbach.)

Date:  0/0/1873
Source:  Birds of New Zealand
Author:
Vol / Page:  91
Edition:   {1888 2nd edn 1/85}
Quote:  ANTHORNIS MELANURA. (BELL-BIRD.) ... <i>Native names</i>. Mako, Makomako, Komako, Kokomako, Korimako, Kohimako, Kokorimako, Titimako, and Kopara. Of the above names, Korimako is most generally used by northern and Makomako by southern tribes. The Ngatiawas call this bird Rearea; and the natives of the Bay of Plenty distinguish the male and female as Kokorohimako and Titapu.
Notes:

Date:  16/8/1875
Source:  Richmond-Atkinson Papers
Author:
Vol / Page:  2/399
Edition:  1960
Quote:  I have got a great many birds since you have been away, which I shot with your gun or a catapult (excuse spelling), and which I stuff and hang up by the beak. ... One of them is a New Zealand bittern ... I have also the mako-mako, silver-eye, riro-riro, miro-miro, fanny etc. ...
Notes:  (?Bill Atkinson, Nelson, 15 years)

Notes:

makutu
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: to bewitch; to cast a spell (on).
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Maori, <i> maakutu</i> to bewitch; a spell, incantation: form (esp. the verb) occas. anglicised: found usually in Maori contexts ca1937 R. Mason Makutu'd used by a pakeha busdriver in the King Country.
Citations
Date:  10/1/1934
Source:  Marsden's Lieutenants
Author:  ELDER
Vol / Page:  235
Edition:
Quote:  ... we were told by the natives there that the dead bodies were three slaves that were killed for makootooing (makutuing) a chief, that is bewitching or praying evil prayers against him that caused his death.
Notes:  1825 Jan 10 William Hall in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 235

Date:  25/3/1828
Source:  Early Journals of Henry Williams, The
Author:  WILLIAMS
Vol / Page:  117
Edition:  1961
Quote:  It is generally current that Pango ... had <i>makutu'd </i>(bewitched) 'Hongi and caused his death ...
Notes:  1828 Mar 25 H. Williams Early Journals (1961) 117

I enquired how that event came about; he said, that an enemy of an opposing tribe had smoked out of the sick man's pipe, and he promised to show me what he could do in destroying the effects of the makutu [a-acute]; he accordingly approached Waitara, and began a shibboleth to the atua that no person present understood; ...

Vol / Page:  55/153

Quote:  <i>Ma[macron]kutu</i>, bewitch; spell, incantation, for purpose of bewitching: commonly regarded as magic, witchcraft, of which there were two varieties; black (evil) and white (good). Makutu (without macron), a kind of kuumara.

Editor of the paper, Mataafa Keni Lesa, said according to superstition if a male is tattooed with a malu it can cause both the wearer and the tattooist to die.

mamaku
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: <i>Cyathea medullaris</i>, the black tree fern; occas. its prepared edible pith Compare silver fern.
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1997
Source:  Field Guide to Native Edible Plants of NZ
Author:  CROWE
Vol / Page:  117
Edition:
Quote:  The Rev. Taylor.. describes a few occasions when he ate mamaku pith boiled in tutu juice - a dish he describes as 'quite acceptable'. On his West Coast expedition in 1846, Heaphy resorted to mamaku as a food many times, and although he generally found it disapopointing, he did comment that 'when mixed with wine, sugar and spice in a tart, it might be mistaken for baked apple.'
Notes:

Date:  0/11/1773
Source:  Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The
Author:  FORSTER
Vol / Page:  3/426
Edition:  1982
Quote:   ... I got a Man who went & fetched me a Fern-tree with root and all, he called it <i>Ma[macron]a[macron,grave]gu</i>, & as I pointed to a large ferntree near me, with leaves whose underside is white, he shewed me the difference & called the latter <i>Po[grave]nga.</i> This Tree is full of tender pulp, ... and I believe this Fern is nearly related to the <i>Sago</i>-tree, which is likewise a Fern.

Date:  0/0/1884
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  17/217
Edition:
Quote:  The most common species are the poka (<i>Dicksonia squarrosa</i>) and the katote (<i>Hemitelia smithii</i>); the stem and fronds of the latter are sometimes used as food for cows. The mamaku (<i>Cyathea medullaris</i>) is local, and has not been observed south of Halfmoon Bay.
Notes:  (Kirk)

Vol / Page:  16
Edition:
Quote:  I have forgotten `mamaku' (the tree fern) - fanning itself in the mid- heat of summer. <i>Ibid.</i> 281 Hence, when ... a large tangi or other party reduced his pataka or rua kumera contents, he ... made shift with fern-root, berries, or mamaku (tree fern) until the next year's crop came in.

Date:  22/5/1930
Source:  Na To Hoa Aroha
Author:
Vol / Page:  2/21
Edition:  1987
Quote:  They could [22] have satisfied most of the `kinaki' [ed fn: Relish eaten with other food] wants from the coast, but preferred forest products. You found the incoming Ngati-Porou along the coast following the fishing grounds and the warm areas for kumara and taro cultivation, while the `tangata whenua' stuck to the hinter-land and forests, faring on `mamaku' [ed fn: Edible tree fern (<i>Cyathea medullaris</i>)], `aruhe', eels and huahua.
Notes:  (Ngata)

Date:  0/0/1938
Source:  Godwits Fly, The
Author:  HYDE
Vol / Page:  116
Edition:  1970
Quote:  When they have passed the mamuk' [[end note] tree-fern which grows right in the middle of the path], they know the Day's Bay fetish has been properly observed. [note 234] Presumably a contraction of mamaku (cyathea medullaris). The term seems peculiar to Robin Hyde - it was never in general use.

The coup de grace was the Toyota ad campaign of the 80s and 90s in which Man Alone tackled the wilderness in a Japanese car.

Date:  0/0/2003
Source:  Long Journey to the Border
Author:
Vol / Page:  191
Edition:
Quote:  Could he do something about the title, as <i>Talking of War</i>, just a the moment, seemed that bit too ambiguous. "In consultation with my chief reader," Kerby wrote, "and bearing in mind the fact that Hitler is master of Europe, [192] what did he think of either 'A man Alone', or 'Escape from Death'? The editor felt the former was the one to go for. ... The title Muligan settled on for the novel has at times been remarkably misread. In his own country, the phrase 'man alone' became a glib response to what is supposed to define an aspect of national maleness, what Orsman's <i>Dictionary of New Zealand English,/i> designates 'a type (or stereotype) of the independent outdoors New Zealander.' It is as though the novel is assumed to celebrate Johnson's raw struggle with land and society, and that Muligan proposed that experience as asdmirably defining.

Notes:

Date:  0/11/2005
Source:  North & South
Author:
Vol / Page:  39-40
Edition:
Quote:  Salt attributes our "man drought" to the fact that young single males are more likely to stay away permanently or come back with an overseas born partner. .. Richard Bedford says the man drought is real but not nearly as bad as Salt says - and OE isn't causing it. .. Man Drought is due, suggests Bedford, to the compounding and cumulative effects of four factors:  more young men than women dying in accidents and from suicide; higher net migration loss among men; more women than men coming to New Zealand from some countries and a tendency for males to be under-counted at censuses.

There's even a social-historical reason for men to imbue the motorised man-space with male potency.

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page:  2026
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Ma&#769;.na </i>(ma.&#769;.n&adot.), <i>n</i>. [Maori.] The authority, influence, or prestige enjoyed by a person on account of his rank, character, or success in life, or for any other reason. [<i>N. Z.</i> and <i>N. S. W</i>.] In its Maori use, <i>mana</i> has a wide signification and is applied to both persons and things. In English, it is technically used of the authority or prestige of a Maori chief, but is colloquially applied to other persons, esp. public officers and politicians.

mana

Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: authority, prestige, or influence. [Maori]

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  Towards Taha Maori
Author:  HOWE
Vol / Page:  20
Edition:
Quote:  Mana - `prestige' - but actually much more than this. It includes charisma, power, control and influence. People can accrue mana by means of birth, leadership qualities increasingly shown, knowledge, and the ability to increase the prestige of all things Maori. Increasing age may bring mana. It is earned, though sometimes given by a group to someone or to a tribe beacause of actions deemed to be worthy of them. Loss of mana is a loss of one's dignity and sense of worth. Total loss of mana could mean loss of life's meaning.
Notes:

Date:  28/2/1987
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  11
Edition:

Date:  0/0/1860
Source:  Maori King Movement
Author:  BUDDLE
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:  `When he returned these tribes were asked ... `Will you have this man for a King?' The reply was `Ae'. He asked again `Will you give all the power (mana) and all the land to the King?' They replied `Ae', again. <i>Ibid.</i> 17 Another object aimed at is the preservation of what they call the `mana' of the Chiefs. This word means authority, power, influence. <i>Ibid.</i> 18 [inherent in land] `Kia mau te mana o te whenua' is another expression now in frequent use, i.e., `hold fast the mana of the land'. ... This is altogether a new application of the term; perhaps it has ben adopted in consequence of the Queen's Sovereignty over the Island having been translated as the Queen's mana. But it certainly did not originally mean that which is now claimed for it, viz., a Chief's `manorial right'. This use of the word was not heard until this Maori King movement originated it. (See Paul's speech, p. 51.)
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1860

Author:  BUDDLE
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:  `When he returned these tribes were asked ... `Will you have this man for a King?' The reply was `Ae'. He asked again `Will you give all the power (mana) and all the land to the King?' They replied `Ae', again. <i>Ibid.</i> 17 Another object aimed at is the preservation of what they call the `mana' of the Chiefs. This word means authority, power, influence. <i>Ibid.</i> 18 [inherent in land] `Kia mau te mana o te whenua' is another expression now in frequent use, i.e., `hold fast the mana of the land'. ... This is altogether a new application of the term; perhaps it has ben adopted in consequence of the Queen's Sovereignty over the Island having been translated as the Queen's mana. Date:  0/0/1863
Source:  Old New Zealand Houses
Author:  MANING
Vol / Page:   (i) 3
Edition:
Quote:   ... it was ... from the deck of a small trading schooner ... that I first cast eyes on Maori land.

It <i>was</i> Maori land then; but, alas! what is it now? Success to you, O King of Waikato. May your

<i>mana</i> never be less! <.I>Ibid.</i> (vi) 90 ... all these qualifications combined made him unquestionably `a great <i>rangatira'</i>, and, as he had never been defeated, his mana was in full force. <.I>Ibid.</i> (xv) 224 Now then for <i>mana. Virtus, prestige,</i> authority, good fortune, influence, sanctity, luck, are all words which, under certain conditions, give something near the meaning of <i>mana</i>, though not one of them gives it exactly; but before I am done, the reader shall have a reasonable notion (for a pakeha) of what it is.

Date:  16/11/2000
Source:  Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page:  3
Edition:
Quote:  Mrs Turia.. told Parliament yesterday that mana whenua (tribal groups) had different rights from others "in certain situations". Mr Samuels said mana whenua was a historical concept arising from Maori tribal wars. It acknowledged traditional boundaries and customs and still had a place in relations between certain hapu (subtribes) and iwi (tribes).

manaaki/manaakitanga
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: hospitality, goodwill, caring
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1998
Source:  Sunday Star Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  C2
Edition:
Quote:  We've seen over the past 25 years that the manaaki, the graciousness of other Maori MPs have been taken for granted.


Notes:  Probably issue in June 1998

Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  Towards Taha Maori
Author:  HOWE
Vol / Page:  20
Edition:
Quote:  Manaaki - this term is of special goodwill. It refers to acts of kindness, hospitality and goodwill. It is related to the term `mana', and refers to a person's finer qualities rather than what a person has in terms of material goods. If a Maori shows warmth, respect and kindness to people, they are showing manaakitanga. The most humble homes can show this quality as much as wealthy homes - it is giving from the heart.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/2004
Source:  Salient
Author:
Vol / Page:  9/23
Edition:
Quote:  ...Maori concepts of manaakitanga (literally, caretaker-ship) will allow all to enjoy our natural resources, within the bounds of environmental sustainability.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/2003
Source:  Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Trainee Kaitohutohu Himiona Herbert approaches his career work with a strong Maori perspective. He says his dealings with Maori clients are based on the concept of manaakitanga - welcoming people in and making them feel at home with the same sense of warmth and connection that they would encounter on a marae.
Notes:  from careers.govt.nz (Career Services publications Issue 10, July 2003)

Date:  16/7/1945
Source:  NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page:  17
Edition:
Quote:  The open pumice land is covered with a tangled mass of manuka and manaoa, with tussock on the colder flats. In developing pumice country a great saving can be effected in clearing costs if the manuka and manaoa scrub are burnt standing two or three years ahead of cultivation. Dense manaoa scrub is difficult and costly to clear in its green state, but it carries a fire well and its burnt stubs soon rot.
Notes:

Author:
Vol / Page:  684
Edition:
Quote:  <i>manchester n. Austral. & N.Z. 1.</i> goods, such as sheets and pillowcases, which are, or were originally, made of cotton.

Date:  0/0/1886
Source:  Handbook Fishes of NZ
Author:  SHERRIN
Vol / Page:  11
Edition:
Quote:  BARRACOUDA (<i>Thyrsites atun</i>). ... Dr. Hector describes barracouda as a very common fish, well known throughout the colonies as the barracouda, which name is no doubt borrowed from a fish of a similar shape, the barracouda pike of the tropical parts of the Atlantic. This fish is a favourite with the Maoris, who call it the manga, or maka.
Notes:

Author:
Vol / Page:  306/7
Edition:  7
Quote:  Since the 1970s, keen Forest and Bird members and others with an interest in forest health have observed, with increasing alarm, the mysterious demise of the native mangeao the tree <i>Litsea calicaris</i>. The mangeao is a well-branched tree growing to about 12 metres, occurring as a component of the rainforest from North Cape to Mokau in Taranaki and the East Cape.

Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:   There is scarcely a bare stem to be seen, even the tallest are embraced by a variety of twining plants, parasites and creepers, amongst which the <i>kia-kia</i>, decked at every joint with bunches of iris-shaped leaves, and the <i>mangamanga,</i> a creeping fern, are the most conspicuous; the <i>kareo</i>, also, forming a network of cane-like stems, hangs its bunches of glossy leaves pendant from every bough, and many others of equal beauty join to form a verdant arch, midway between the spreading branches of the noble trees to which they cling.
Notes:  1847 Johnson Notes from a Journal in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 121

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Oxford Book of NZ Plants
Author:  MOORE & IRWIN
Vol / Page:  216
Edition:
Quote:  <i>LYGODIUM ARTICULATUM</i> (Schizaeceae). The strangest thins about mangemange is that the true stem is very short but the leaf goes on growing at its tip and may be many metres long. In kauri forest these tough wiry leaves wind round trees and shrubs in an impenetrable network. Such a tangle makes thin strong vines suitable for securing thatch on a whare, as wire might be used today.
Notes:

mango

Vol / Page:  1/101
Edition:
Quote:  My companion eyed it much, ... and observed, that the mango, or shark, was a rich treat to the New Zealanders. <i>Ibid.</i> 1/323 The mango or<i> shark</i> (Squalus); <i>pilot-fish</i> (Scomber ductor); <i>flying-fish</i> (Exocoetus volitans);<i> hammer-headed shark </i>(Squalus zygoena); frequent the coast, expecially the River Thames, in vast shoals, and are preserved by the natives as winter food.

Vol / Page:
Edition:

Date:  0/0/1882
Source:  Brighter Britain
Author:  HAY
Vol / Page:  2/151
Edition:
Quote:  In the bays and tidal rivers are the mango or sharks - the most highly-prized food-fish - the tamure or schnapper, the whapuka or rock-cod, the kahawai or mackerel, the porahi or herring, the kanae or mullet, the patiki or sole, and many others. On the shores are oysters, mussels, cockles, mutton-fish, crabs, and other shell-fish in profuse abundance. In the fresh-water creeks are eels (tuna), lampreys (pipiharau), and whitebait (inanga).
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1886
Source:  Handbook Fishes of NZ
Author:  SHERRIN
Vol / Page:  117
Edition:
Quote:  TIGER SHARK (<i>Lamna glauca</i>). ... In New South Wales it is called the blue pointer, and, as Mr. Hill tells us, is `not only a very powerful, but perhaps the most bold of any of the large sharks visiting our shores. ... [118] Although there is some doubt on the subject, <i>Lamna glauca</i> is considered to be the mako of the Maoris, which is mainly found in the neighbourhood of Mayor Island. ... Mango, it should be remembered, seems [119] almost a generic name for shark in the North, as there is the mango-taniwha, a large variety; the mango-pare, the hammerheaded shark; the mango-reremai, the common dog-fish; the mango-pekepeke, and the mango-aruroa.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  282
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Mango, n.</i> Maori name for the <i>Dog-fish</i> (q.v.), a species of shark.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page:  2026
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Ma&#769;.ngo</i> (ma.&#769;.ngo.; <i>colloq</i>. m&adot.ng&#769;.o.), <i>n</i>. [Maori.] (<i>Zoo.l.</i>) A kind of shark. See MAKO [Local, N. Z.]
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1929
Source:  Fishing Methods
Author:  BEST
Vol / Page:  43
Edition:
Quote:  The following fish were caught with hook and line: araara, maomao, moki, mango, ngoiro, pakirikiri, kahawai, tamure, tarakihi, and warehou. The kanae, kehe, kopipiro, moho, nanu and other species were taken by net. <i>Ibid.</i> 49 In mango [o-macron] the generic term for sharks, the final vowel is long, as is also the case with the name of the barracouta, manga [a-macron].
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/153
Edition:
Quote:  <i>mango[o],</i> a sea-fish, shark, or dog-fish; a general name, adopted by Pakeha for shark, with erratic pronunciation, including manggo.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Fisherman's Bible
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  224
Edition:
Quote:  GUMMY SHARK <i>Mustelus antarcticus</i>: These harmless members of the shark family <i>Triakidae</i> live on smooth, sea bottoms ... They are slenderly built and have a fairly smooth skin, and are good eating. Also known as Sweet William Shark, Spotted dogfish, gummy, and by the Maori name `mango'.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  Countless Signs
Author:  McNAUGHTON
Vol / Page:  43
Edition:
Quote:  My father caught ten sharks this way, grabbing their tails and sending them arcing out over our heads to the rocks behind, with us all watching and shouting out 'Mango, Mango' yelling and jumping about on the rocks.
Notes:  From Patricia Grace (1975) : Waiariki

Quote:  Note, In speaking of Mercury Bay I had forgot to mention that the Mangrove trees found there produce a resinous substance very much like rosin, something of this kind I am told is found in both the East and West Indias. We found it first in small lumps upon the Sea beach, but afterwards found it sticking to the Mangrove trees and by that means found out from whence it had come.

manoao
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a north Auckland forest tree related to the rimu. [Maori] Common Error: do not confuse with monoao, a scrub plant.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: <i>Halocarpus kirkii</i>, aka Kirk's pine [There is confusion in the OEDS article with MONOAO <i>Dracophyllum subulatum</i>, possibly springing partly from the mistaken attribution in 1963 Poole and Adams 26 (repeated in the index p. 247), itself possibly taken over from 1961 (1982) Allan Flora of NZ 1/109, itself possibly taken over from Cheeseman.

Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/III/32
Edition:
Quote:  [MANOUA] Manoua (<i>Dacrydium Colensoi</i>). A small tree, found at an altitude of 1000 to 2000 feet, at Dunedin, and at the sea level on the west coast. Leaves of two kinds, spreading and imbricate.... Manoua (<i>Dacrydium laxifolium</i>), is a very doubtful species, being difficult to distinguish from the last <i>[D. Colensoi]</i>. <i>Ibid.</i> 49 Manoue. Dacrydium laxifolium

Manpower Act
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: There seems to be no Manpower Act or Manpower Regulations as such. What we had instead were various amendments to the National Service Emergency Regulations promulgated first in 1940, when they referred mainly to the Services and spoke of Placement Officers and which I suspect were the "Manpower  Regulations" of the time.  The first relevant regulation seems to be 1942 Statutory Regulations 5/19 The National Service Emergency Regulations 1940, Amendment No. 8: There shall from time to time be appointed.. such number of District Man-power Officers as may be required. Ibid. 21. In any essential undertaking.. (a) Except with the permission in writing of the District Man-power Officer, the employer shall not terminate.. the employment of any person for the time being employed therein.. except in case of emergency... (b) Except with the permission in writing of the District Man-power Officer, no person for the time being employed in the undertaking shall leave his employment... Ibid. 24. The Minister may.. direct all persons of any specified class or of specified classes.. to register for employment with the District Man-power Office.

Date:  0/0/1933
Source:  Reminiscences of Early Days
Author:  WASHBOURNE
Vol / Page:  5
Edition:
Quote:  The `manrope' party were so called because they had to descend to their claim by means of man ropes in the Gorge of Slate River. ... Lanterns were an unknown luxury on the diggings and one of the party invented by breaking the bottom out of an `Old Tom' bottle, and this was carried upside down with a candle dropped into the neck of it. This has always since been known as a `manrope lantern' [on the Nelson goldfields, c 1857-59]

manu
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the proprietary path or area on a muttonbird island over which a proprietor has the right to birds


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1979
Source:  Titi Heritage
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  55
Edition:
Quote:  Ever since the beginning, to `take' meant journeying to the islands and living there for the season and using hands or any device to catch the birds. ... to `take' also includes an `attempt to take'. During the torching season the birds run down the paths to the sea at night. Paths are used as boundaries by the [56] supervisors and in some cases the dividing line is the middle of the path. If one pursues a bird and grabs it over the other edge of the path one can be prosecuted, even although the bird came from the pursuer's manu.
Notes:

Manu Korero
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a Maori speaking competition
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: (from the net) The Manu Korero competition returns to the Far North next year. Panguru Area School Principal Mina Pomare requested to host the event at a July meeting of the PPTA. A strong contingent of Tai Tokerau principals led by Pa Tony Brown won the tono from 2 other regions to host the 2005 national Manu Korero . The prestigious competition expects to attract 2000 secondary students, television and radio broadcast. 2005 will be the 40th anniversary of Manu Korero, the first competition was won by Donna Awatere.

Date:  19/7/1986
Source:  PSA Journal
Author:
Vol / Page:  12
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Sponsoring the manuhiri</i> [heading] Have you ever thought about what is involved in sponsoring a refugee? ... The theme for this year's refugee Sunday is `many manuhiri'. The manuhiri are the `people coming in', and New Zealand has a tradition of welcoming strangers that goes back to the very first people who settled here. More recently, New Zealanders have continued that tradition and established an international reputation for their refugee resettlement programme.

manuka
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a common New Zealand scrub bush or tree which makes excellent firewood, a species of Leptospermum; tea-tree. [Maori manuka[a1-macron]]; bush manuka Leptospermum ericoides, tree manuka, white manuka, kanuka bush `as a ush-tree', i.e., `large', or less probably `growing in the bush' cp. Scrub manuka Leptospermum scoparium, a shrub or small tree; kahikatoa, leptosperm, tea-broom, tea-tree (titri); also occas for L. ericoides, kanuka, tree manuka:




Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: also kanuka, manuea
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1826
Source:  Boultbee Journal
Author:
Vol / Page:  110
Edition:
Quote:  tea tree bush - man|nook [manuka]


Notes:  also in 1826-28 Boultbee Vocabulary in 1979 Begg 283-

Date:  18/2/1832
Source:  London Medical Gazette
Author:
Vol / Page:  750/1
Edition:
Quote:  This tree..is probably a species of Leptospermum. It is found abundantly at New Zealand,..and is named Kaetatowa, or Manuka, by the natives.
Notes:  [OEDS]

Date:  0/0/1890
Source:  PWD Catalogue of Timbers
Author:
Vol / Page:  11
Edition:
Quote:  Manuka .. Leptospermum scoparium .. Wood of a reddish colour, hard, and elastic; ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  283
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Manuka n.</i> the Maori name for <i>Tea-tree</i> (q.v.). Properly, the accent is on the first syllable with broad <i>a</i>Vulgarly, the accent is placed on the second syllable. There are two species in New Zealand <i>white</i> and <i>red</i>; the first, a low bush called Scrub-Manuka,. <i>L. scoparium,</i> R. and G. Forst., the <i>Tea-tree</i> used by Captain Cook's sailors; the second, a tree <i>Leptospermum ericoides,</i> A. Richard.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1951
Source:  Grasslands of NZ
Author:  LEVY
Vol / Page:  87
Edition:  1970
Quote:  From the above low-forest association, or often directly from the manuka-kanuka associations, ... arise the larger trees of the forest proper, kamahi, rewarewa, hinau, totara, matai, southern beech, kaikomako, wharangi, rimu ...

Quote:  English Name Native name Botanical Name Manuka Manuka ..
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1944
Source:  Maori Place-Names of Otago
Author:  BEATTIE
Vol / Page:  39
Edition:
Quote:  When in a hurry, or feeling orthographically tired, he [the southerner] calls the big manuka `kaikatoa.' A southern Maori once said to me:- `We did not pronounce the word manuka like some northerners who throw the accent forward and say `man-u-ka,' nor like the bushmen, who say `m'nooka,' but about halfway between these two pronouncing each part clearly as mah-nook-a.' Unless my hearing deceives me this throws the emphasis on the central syllable while leaving the first syllable clearly pronounced. It is a remarkable fact that while the manuka is so common its name is so seldom used in the composition of place-names.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/144
Edition:
Quote:  <i>ma[a]nuka</i>, a shrub (Leptospermum scoparium), commonly called tea-tree, because Cook's people used the fresh young leaves infused for tea; but very often mis-spelt ti-tree - ti being something totally different, the cabbage tree (Cordyline). The tree-manuka is kanuka, with smaller leaves and smaller flowers than the scrub-manuka, and it is the kanuka that is usually sold for firewood. I spoke to a dealer about it, and he said they dodged the confusion by selling it as T.T. There is a crimson-flowering variety of manuka known in England as a rarity, but by means of slips (not seed) it has become not uncommon. The starry-flowered manuka would have been adopted as the national flower but for the fact that it is too prolific, and apt to become a nuisance. It has a second name, kahika[a]toa but that is discouraged on account of its spelling being so nearly the same as kahikatea, the white pine, though in sound they are quite different, the macron in hahika[a]toa causing an apparent accent which, when observed, clearly differentiates the two words: it is not an accent, however, but a lengthening of the vowel.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Date:  0/0/1963

Author:  KEENE

Date:  0/0/1907
Source:  Plants of NZ
Author:  LAING & BLACKWELL
Vol / Page:  272
Edition:  1940 p. 286
Quote:  <i>Leptospermum scoparium (The Manuka)</i>... Maori names <i>Manuka, Kahikatoa</i>. Colonists' [English] name, Tea-Tree. <i>Ibid.</i> 272, 274 [286] To the Maoris the tree was known as the manuka. By the bushmen it is generally called tea-tree. It has acquired this name because early voyagers and colonists sometimes used its [284] pungent leaves in place of tea.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1908
Source:  Shingle-Short
Author:  BAUGHAN
Vol / Page:  54
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Kauri</i> and <i>Totara, Rimu</i>, and <i>Matai </i>and <i>Maire,/ </i>Red-as-blood <i>Rata,</i> and bright-as-blood <i>Pohutukawa,/ Manuka </i>dark-ey'd, Convolvulus star-ey'd - / The glittering of you that morning! [f@n2 attached to the italicised names] 2. <i>Kauri, ... Mah</i>[a acute]-<i>noo-kah</i>): New Zealand Bush trees. </i>Ibid.</i> 75 [fn] (mah-noo-kah): Here pronounced, as often by the settlers, with the stress on the second syllable [previously stressed on first syllable]. A shrub with small aromatic tea-like leaves.

Date:  0/0/1883
Source:  Ranolf and Amohia
Author:  DOMETT
Vol / Page:  1/303
Edition:
Quote:  Ma'nuka ....<i> O</i>. Myrtaceae; <i>G</i>. Leptospermum; <i>S</i>. L. scoparium, or L. ericoides. "A large shrub or small tree; leaves used as tea in Tasmania and Australia, where the plant is equally abundant." In the poem it is called indiscriminately manuka, broom, broom-like myrtle, or leptosperm. The settlers often call it `tea-broom.'

Edition:
Quote:  The leave[s] of the `manuka' (<i>leptospermum scoparium</i>) furnished Captain Cook with a substitute for tea ...; and ... he used the small branches of this shrub and of the tree `rimu', <i>(dacrydium cupressinum,</i>) in equal proportions, to make a decoction from which he brewed spruce beer, frequently referred to by him as a valuable anti-scorbatic.

Date:  0/0/1856
Source:  Diary
Author:  W H S ROBERTS
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Writing of the Waimea Plain in 1856: - `The ground was well grassed, but the speargrass was too plentiful. The pasturage was very good. There was a good deal of scrub in the bends of the Mataura known as `wire plant' (Olearia virgata). There were also manuka and koromiko. Maori-heads, a kind of grass tree about three feet high, abounded in the swamps, and in some we saw toitoi grass and raupo. We did not pass any cabbage trees to-day ... we proceeded slowly through tomatakuru scrub, speargrass, Spaniard, snowgrass, and other native grasses ... we camped in a bend with good feed at the Elbow and a swamp on one side. Maori cabbage abounded ...'
Notes:  1856 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 18

Notes:  1861 Sep 27 Tuapeka in NZ Goldfields 1861 (1976) 23

Date:  0/0/1842
Source:  New Zealand (Heaphy)
Author:  HEAPHY
Vol / Page:  46
Edition:
Quote:  The dwarf <i>Manuka</i>, or `tea-tree', concludes the list of flowering plants. ... The infusion of the leaf of this plant forms an excellent substitute for tea: the taste is agreeable, and the effect slightly narcotic. It is much used as a beverage at the whaling stations.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1843
Source:  Travels in NZ
Author:  DIEFFENBACH
Vol / Page:  1/27
Edition:
Quote:  At the summit of the hills we find but little wood; and the manuka [fn Leptospermum scoparium.] and kahikatoa [fn Leptospermum ericoides.], the esculent fern and euphorbium [fn Euphorbium glaucum.], and the epacris parviflora, form the chief part of the vegetation. <i>Ibid.</i> 28 The manuka supplies the place of the tea-shrub. <i>Ibid.</i> 2/371 Manuka - a shrub (<i>Leptospermum scoparium</i>)]

Date:  0/0/1848
Source:  Handbook for New Zealand, The
Author:  WAKEFIELD
Vol / Page:  143
Edition:
Quote:  13. Kahikatoa, or Manuka, (<i>Leptospermum Scoparium</i>.) A tree of stunted growth, flourishing in clayey barren soils, and producing a hard red wood. <i>Ibid.</i> 240  ... very broken ground, covered with fern, toitoi, grass, and tall manuka. <i>Ibid.</i> 461-462 An unmixed growth [462] of stunted <i>manuka</i> is a bad sign, a quantity of ti-shrubs, commonly called the cabbage-tree, a very good one.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1872
Source:  Ranolf and Amohia
Author:  DOMETT
Vol / Page:  146fn
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Manuka</i>: A large or small tree; leaves used as tea in Tasmania and Australia where the plant is equally abundant' (Hooker). In the poem it is called indiscriminately manuka, broom, broom-like myrtle, or leptosperm. The settlers often call it `tea-broom'.

Date:  0/0/1882
Source:  Brighter Britain
Author:  HAY
Vol / Page:  2/195
Edition:
Quote:   The Manuka or Manukau (<i>Leptospernum scoparium et ericoides</i>) is the `ti-tree' of the settlers. In one condition it is low shrubbery, not unlike heather, called then Rawiri by the Maori. ... There are red and white varieties. The Maori particularize it as Kahikatoa, when in tree condition.
Notes:

manuka blight
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a sooty mould formed on honey-dew exuded by a scale insect infesting red manuka and kanuka.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Author:
Vol / Page:  533
Edition:
Quote:  Has 'Manuka blight' been established in the North Island and what is the cost of getting it started? Manuka blight is an insect which sucks sap from the plant and secretes 'honey dew' on which sooty mould fungi form. Manuka blight is very likely to be already established on your land.

manuka blight
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a black blight which kills manuka scrub
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/4/1950
Source:  NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page:  337/1
Edition:
Quote:
Notes:

Date:  0/10/1959
Source:  Tararua Tramper
Author:
Vol / Page:  7
Edition:
Quote:  MANUKA BLIGHT [heading] Since first noted in the Canterbury district in 1937, the scale insect

<i>Eriococcus scoparium</i>, has ... become widely established.
Notes:

Date:  0/10/1954
Source:  NZ Geographer
Author:
Vol / Page:  110
Edition:
Quote:  The manuka blight was first introduced into the [Hawkes Bay] region in 1945 ... [fn] The blight is caused by the action of a small sucking insect which feeds on the sap of the manuka and which secretes large quantities of a clear sticky substance known as `honey-dew'. A black sooty mould forms on this secretion. A combination of sap loss and mould slowly kills the plant.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author:  TURNER
Vol / Page:  142
Edition:
Quote:  In New Zealand a disease <i>manuka blight</i> is used to control the scrubby manuka or tea-tree.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Weeds of Roadsides
Author:  TAYLOR
Vol / Page:  91
Edition:
Quote:  Manuka blight is caused by a scale insect <i>Eriococcus orariensis,</i> which is native to Australia where manuka has long been adapted to it.

Date:  0/0/1982

When this technology becomes mainstream in the next 18 months, Manuka honey has the potential to reach upwards of $40 a kilo."

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/144
Edition:
Quote:  <i>ma[a]nuka,</i> a shrub (Leptospermum scoparium), commonly called tea-tree, because Cook's people used the fresh young leaves infused for tea; but very often mis-spelt ti-tree - ti being something totally different, the cabbage tree (Cordyline). The tree-manuka is kanuka, with smaller leaves and smaller flowers than the scrub-manuka, and it is the kanuka that is usually sold for firewood.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Black Beech & Honeydew

Date:  0/0/1953
Source:  Unorganized Games
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  2/769
Edition:
Quote:  Action terms related to the movements of the marbles are, Throughs and No Throughs, Tracks and Clears, Stops and Rolls, Lay-Up, Manyies, Kiss, Ons, Gees, Haystacks, Stays, Spiders Can't Cross a River etc. Action Terms related to taking an opponent's marbles are Fires, Double-Hits and Forces.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1972
Source:  Folkgames of Children
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  175
Edition:
Quote:  Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  History of Children's Play
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  269
Edition:
Quote:   Here are some [marble] terms from Taranaki around 1880-1890: firsts, lay-up, stakes, tips, sticking-taw, nothings, anythings, fade-it, knuckledown stiff, dubs, finking [sic, ?funking], sips, spanning, placing; and from Dunedin School in 1949: knee high, manyies, tracks, screws, nuts, sleets, kills, forces, dig, dubs, cheats.

maomao
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an edible New Zealand fish (varieties termed `blue' or `pink') commonly found in rocky northern waters. <i>Scorpis aequipinnis</i> and <i>S. violaceus</i>, also blue maomao, =hui [NB Natusch separates 2 species of Scorpis the maomao and the hui (see hui); Williams hui (iv) S aequipinnis the SWEEP, a fish]

Maori
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: as the Maori (also nga Maori): the Maori people as an ethnic or cultural entity

Colenso also assigns the Maori name `Pinakitere'; but it does not clearly appear whether to the type, or to which of its New Zealand forms.

Maori
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: the Maori language, the only use of Maori in the early journals: cf [ed fn] This is one of the rare occasions in which the word `Maori', as meaning a `person of the native race', is used by the missionaries. But its use here as meaning `the language of the native race' would seem to indicate that it was not an unusual name, although the missionaries and others normally used `native' or `New Zealander'.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: `the Maori language' used in 1834, 1841, 1842: see C.below)
Citations
Date:  0/0/1817
Source:  New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author:  NICHOLAS
Vol / Page:  2/347
Edition:
Quote:  It is good to read the language of New Zealand / Kapi ta karakea a koraro no New Zealand
Notes:  NB `Maori'= language not used by Nicholas

Date:  17/8/1828
Source:  Early Journals of Henry Williams, The
Author:  WILLIAMS
Vol / Page:  141
Edition:  1961
Quote:   The Service very pleasant as all the natives assembled and part of it is held in <i>Maori</i>, which keeps up their attention.
Notes:

Date:  21/9/1828
Source:  Early Journals of Henry Williams, The
Author:  WILLIAMS
Vol / Page:  144
Edition:  1961
Quote:  Read the former part of the morning service in <i>mauri. </i>
Notes:

Date:  17/8/1828
Source:  Journal
Author:  WILLIAMS
Vol / Page:  141
Edition:  1961
Quote:   The Service very pleasant and as all the natives assembled part of it is held in <i>Maori</i>.

[ed 1961 fn.] This is one of the rare occasions in which the word "Maori', as meaning a `person of the native race', is used by the missionaries. But its use here as meaning `the language of the native race', would seem to indicate that it was not an unusual name, although the missionaries and other normally used `native' or `New Zealander'.
Notes:

I have done all in my power to avert this evil, by publishing monthly in the Maori language, ... a gazette ...
