Quote:  [Note: P. uses <i>Maori </i>as a aj] The flax (<i>korari</i>,) forming the dresses is of two or [176] three kinds; the most coarse, called muka, is employed for working the common garment <i>(kakaou</i>[a1-acute] <i>maori</i>[a-acute].) This flax is also made use of for laying up ropes, lines, &c. The superior dress called Kaitaka[a2-a3-acute], is made from silken flax, (<i>hunga hunga</i>[as-acute].) <i>Ibid.</i> 1/199 [caption] Na[acute] <i>muttou maori</i>[a-acute], <i>New Zealand Fish-hooks.</i>

Date:  0/0/1945
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  54/233
Edition:
Quote:  The frequent use [following the Treaty of Waitangi] of the expression <i>nga Rangatira me nga Tangata maori </i>(with a small m) o Niu Tireni (the chiefs and people of New Zealand) appears to have been too cumbersome for official records and was quickly abbreviated to the one word Maori. In fact we may reasonably date at this period the elevation of Maori from a qualifying adjective to the status of a proper noun.
Notes:  (E.H. Schnackenberg)

Date:  0/0/1959
Source:  Descriptive Atlas
Author:  McLINTOCK
Vol / Page:  72
Edition:
Quote:  In the country proper the Maori has retained his traditional mode of life which is symbolised in the

<i>marae</i>. In a literal sense the term means the open courtyard in front of the communal meeting house; today ... it embraces all aspects of community life - community buildings, tribal gatherings, church activities, and recreation. ... For the purpose of this article a Maori is a person having 50 per cent or more of Maori blood.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1984
Source:  NZ Yesterdays
Author:  KEITH & MAIN
Vol / Page:  288
Edition:
Quote:  Oddly enough, there does not seem to have been a Maori and pakeha variant [of Cowboys and Indians], although a stalking game called `Maori' is recorded as being played in the 19th century.
Notes:

Maori
Homonym Number:
Word Class: adjective
Sense Number:
Definition: native, a new formation from MAORI n. use B used attributively, thence adjectivally rather than a borrowing or continuation of use A. Used increasingly for the earlier NATIVE (or New Zealand or aboriginal), and as native came to connote and denote a more general `New Zealand' (from say the 1890's) it was replaced by Maori aj in most uses.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Pits had been dug to obtain sand and gravel, which, after having the larger stones removed, were spread over the natural loam top soil to render it more suitable for the cultivation of the kumara ... <i>Ibid.</i> 28 The <i>taniko </i>in the embroidered borders of cloaks, is from the point of technique the latest development in Maori weaving.

Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Maori</i>.- Used as an adjective synonymous with <i>native</i>, except that it seems slightly contemptious. We admire native bush, pasture, or game; but <i>M</i>. hens (woodhens), <i>M.</i> cabbage [the European cabbage run wild--A.W.], and <i>M</i>. onion (Chrysobactron bookeri) are caricatures of their English namesakes. ([1898 Morris Austral-English])

Notes:

Maori
Homonym Number:
Word Class: adjective
Sense Number: 4
Definition: chiefly pejorative derogatory or offensive, to refer to anything inferior or uncivilised in construction, appearance, or style; or connoting (low) cunning. Chiefly in loose combinations merging with compounds. [cf OEDS sb (a) 1 a. Add: also as a term of contempt - check: THE MAORI = Maori blood 1967 Sargeson Hangover iv 30 see MAORI DOG, PT; in some uses approaches the sense of modern CLAYTON'S e.g. MAORI TACKLE, MAORI P.T.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1938 (Havelock) To keep a Maori house ("be a dirty housewife") a real Maori cow, (a lean, ill-thrifty animal)

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Some Modern Maoris
Author:  BEAGLEHOLE
Vol / Page:  295
Edition:
Quote:  Again, the word Maori for these [Otaki] people has taken on a secondary meaning when it is used as an adjective referring to any object that is broken, dilapidated, hard to use, or about which people are so casual that it does not function efficiently. Thus a `Maori' door is one on which the catch is broken or which fits so badly that it blows open in the wind. ... A `Maori' gate is always a weird contraption made of bits of wire, string, parts of an old iron bedstead - something so complicated that it defies the ingenuity of the non-expert either to open or close. The owner of the gate jokes about his `Maori' gate. He is rarely sufficiently concerned ever to make a simple workable gate.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  In and Out of the World
Author:  BALLIS
Vol / Page:  82
Edition:
Quote:  According to the honoured Maori scholar, Sir James Cowan, [Pomare] should ever be remembered as ... a `medical apostle' who carried `the gospel of health' to the Maori.
Notes:

Maori
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: plural is Maoris or Maori 1. a) a member of the tangata whenua, the Polynesian race that first peopled New Zealand. b) a Polynesian of the Cook Islands. Compare PAKEHA. 2. their languages. Maori adjective (usually capital, can be offensive in some non-Maori use)
1. a) of or pertaining to Maori peoples or culture (often replacing earlier native): `Maori Battalion'; `Maori Affairs Department'; `Maori oven'. b) use can be derogatory or stereotypical: `Maori cannon'. 2. a) indigenous, native to New Zealand: `Maori bug'; `Maori hen'. b) undomesticated (synonym is wild): `Maori cabbage'; `Maori celery'; `Maori dog'. [Maori Maori originally an adjective, normal, usual, ordinary]
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: For fuller discussion of theories of origin, and applications, of MAORI (and PAKEHA) see Journal Polynesian Soc. 54/4/223-234; [etc.] Maori, <i>maaori </i> see also taha maori, tangata maori, copper maori , pro-Maori include in article Maori as a subject of study: e.g. Maori was admitted at last as a university subject: a Chair of Maori ??? -->pl forms Maori the native race, or several Maoris, is becoming the preferred pl among maoriphiles: Maories quite common until the 1870s;

"Maori" means a person belonging to the

and persons of pure descent from that

race.

Housing assistance for Polynesians...

"(2A). For the purposes of this Act, the

term "Maori" shall be deemed to include

any Polynesian who is a native of any

island of the South Pacific Ocean and any

person who is a descendant of such a

Polynesian if, in either case, - "(a) He

is a New Zealand citizen; or "(b) He has

lived in New Zealand for five years and

is permanently resident in New Zealand."

Date:  14/5/1990
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  100
Edition:
Quote:  Having suitably characterised the white strangers as pakeha, the tribes adopted the word maori as a distinguishing descriptive term for themselves. Maori means normal, ordinary or natural, in contrast to the extraordinary or supranormal quality of fair skin. Thus did the two terms Maori and Pakeha mutually define each other.
Notes:

Maori
Homonym Number:
Word Class: adverb
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1935 Havelock <i>to go Maori</i>, of a European, to live in an inferior fashion. <i>to act the Maori</i>, to show uncivilised or aggressive behaviour.
Citations
Date:  0/0/1974
Source:  Hand on the Rail, The
Author:  MASON
Vol / Page:  18
Edition:
Quote:  HINGAWARU: Wish she'd have married Maori, though.
Notes:

Maori
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: There is a discussion on the word in the `Journal of Polynesian Society,' vol. i. no. 3, vol. ii. no. I, and vol. iii. no. I. Bishop Williams (4th ed.) says that the word means, `of the normal or usual kind.' The Pakehas were not men to whom the natives were accustomed. So Maori was used as opposed to the Europeans, the white-skins. <i>Kuri Maori</i> was a name used for a dog after the arrival of other quadrupeds called also <i>kuri. Wai maori</i> was fresh-water, oridinary as opposed to sea-water. Another explanation is that the word meant `indigenous,' and that there are kindred words with that meaning in other Polynesian languages. First, `indigenous,' or "of the native race,' and then with a secondary meaning, `ours.' (See `Tregear's Maori Comparative Dictionary,' s.v.) The form of the plural varies, The form <i>Maoris</i> is considered the more correct, but the form <i>Maories</i> is frequently used by good writers.

Date:  0/0/1949
Source:  Coming of the Maori, The
Author:  BUCK
Vol / Page:  333
Edition:
Quote:   The smallest sociological unit is the biological family, which the Maoris termed<i> whanau</i>, derived from <i>whanau</i>, to give birth . ... The term <i>hapu</i> (pregnancy) was used to denote this expanded family group for it expressed the idea of birth from common ancestors ... The term<i> iwi</i> (bone) was brought into current use to include all the<i> hapu</i> descended from common ancestors and thus related to each other by a blood tie. To denote the groupings in English, the <i>iwi</i> has been termed tribe and the <i>hapu</i> a sub-tribe.

The former refers to the Maori people as a whole and as an ethnic and cultural entity; the latter designates individuals of this people (cf

<i>The Coming of the Maori</i> and <i>Some Modern Maoris</i>.

So far as is known, they had no name for their race: the word <i>maori </i>meant normal'. They applied the term to themselves only when, for the first time in their recollection, they encountered another race.

Quote:  <i>I[i]nanga, inanga</i>, n. <i>1. Whitebait</i>, the adult of the minnow, <i>Galaxias attenuatus</i> (also the fry), and the fry of the smelt, <i>Retropinna retropinna.</i> ... Maoris distinguish between <i>inanga papa</i>, a variety of smelt, <i>Retropinna</i>, and <i>inanga tu[u]tuna,</i> a spotted variety of minnow, <i>Galaxias. </i> <i>Ibid.</i> 364[plurals] [At <i>Taipo</i?> Williams has:] This word is used by Maoris believing it English, and by Europeans believing it maori, it being apparently neither. Colenso suggests <i>tae-po</i>, but this is not used by the Maori. 1979 Webster Rua 212 <i>et pass</i> [pl Maori] Maori who remembered Rua at the time, but were not followers, had very differing opinions about the prophet.

Date:  0/0/1977
Source:  Moa-Hunters of NZ
Author:  DUFF
Vol / Page:  12
Edition:
Quote:  This raises the question of what we mean by the term Maori. Why should Kupe be termed a Maori, if (according to Maori tradition) he was a Society Islands voyager of some 1,000 years ago who touched at New Zealand in the course of exploring voyages and returned to his homeland? By what greater right can we apply the term to Toi who arrived from the same part of the Pacific 200 years later to settle in New Zealand, or to the numerous voyagers subsequent to Toi and culminating in the Hawaiki Fleet of 1350? Every immigrant from tropical Polynesia did not become a Maori the moment he stepped ashore in New Zealand. The culture which we have come to know as Maori was undoubtedly the end product of a long period of local development, probably not reaching its final perfection of form until after the visit of Tasman. The use of the term Maori (lit. normal, ordinary or proper) to distinguish the Polynesian inhabitants of New Zealand from the intrusive European is even more clearly a late development and certainly post-European.* [fn] Williams (1921) notes no literary use before 1850 of the Maori in its present sense. Scholefield (1945) puts its use back to 1840, in the translation of the Treaty of Waitangi. McNab, quoted by Shrimpton and Mulgan, without the reference being cited, states that its earliest use was in 1818.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  History of Children's Play
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  14
Edition:

In 1868 the birth of another brother made my mother seriously ill. I remember them shifting her away from the district because they feared the attacks of the Maoris. [Pronounced `Moorees' by this elderly woman.] [sic]

Date:  30/4/1988
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  8
Edition:
Quote:  (Profesor Joan Metge) Recent letters opposing the use of the word `Pakeha' claim that it means `foreigner' or `stranger'. ... Whatever the word meant when it was first bestowed, it has taken on a new and special meaning. Maoris today use it to identify non-Maori New Zealanders of European and especially of British stock, people whom they recognise as having a history of residence and commitment to this country.

Maoris use it not only to distinguish Pakehas from themselves but to couple them with themselves. The word has meaning only within the New Zealand context, in relation to and partnership with `Maori', the shared reference point being the land of Aotearoa/New Zealand.
Notes:

Date:  0/10/1951
Source:  NZ Geographer
Author:
Vol / Page:  127
Edition:
Quote:  Security of tenure was needed before any scheme to resuscitate the citrus industry could be commenced with successful prospects. Recommendations were therefore made to enable one member of the family to have, by communal aggreement in the Native Land Court, a definite area of the land held within the

<i>kopu tangata</i>. Consequent upon such an agreement the occupier was confirmed as the owner under Maori custom and became capable of pledging the freehold to the administration as security for financial and material advances.
Notes:  (Johnston `Citrus Industry of the Cook Islands')

Maori
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:  an aboriginal or native New Zealander; pertaining to the Maori. Spg <i>Mouri, Mauri, Mawnee</i>, [? typographical or transcription error], in the earliest texts; <i>mouray Mao[diereis]ri Maori</i> from at least 1842 (with occasional lower case m.) Plural. Mauries, Mauris, Mouries, Maories; Mauri, Mouri, Maori. The plural <i>Maories</i> can be found in written texts to the 1870's or 1880's; and is not uncommon in informal written English today, though usually regarded as a spelling error. The plural <i>Maori</i> has been usual among those with knowledge of Maori; and among those who are sensitive to Maori usage or feeling.

<i>Synonyms.</i> Leaving aside the very early (Cook, Banks) <i>Indian </i>q.v., early writers used <i>native</i> (as n and aj.) or <i>New Zealander </i>q.v. as the preferred terms, with<i> aborigine</i> q.v. being common in early writing asociated with `imperial' agencies as the Colonial Office and the Church Missionary Society, and was reinforced by the early appointment of a <i>Protector of Aborigines</i>. Early uses of <i>Maori</i> were usually tagged with an explanatory `native"; and indeed <i>Maori </i>did not replace <i>Native</i> in official use until 1947 when the name of the Department of Native Affairs was replaced by `Maori Affairs'.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  284
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Maori, n.</i> (pronounced so as to rhyme with <i>Dowry</i>). (I) The name used to designate themselves by the Polynesian race occupying New Zealand when it was discovered by the white man, and which still survives. They are not aboriginal as is commonly supposed, but migrated into New Zealand about 500 years ago from Hawaii, the tradition still surviving of the two great canoes <i>Arawa</i> and <i>Tainui</i> in which the pioneers arrived. They are commonly spoken of as the <i>Natives</i> of New Zealand. -->(2) The language of the Maori race. -->(3) Applied to anything pertaining to the Maoris or their language. See Pakeha.

-->There is a discussion on the word in the `Journal of Polynesian Society,' vol. i. no. 3, vol. ii. no. I, and vol. iii. no. I. Bishop Williams (4th ed.) says that the word means, `of the normal or usual kind.' The Pakehas were not men to whom the natives were accustomed. So Maori was used as opposed to the Europeans, the white-skins. <i>Kuri Maori</i> was a name used for a dog after the arrival of other

quadrupeds called also <i>kuri. Wai maori</i>was fresh-water, ordinary as opposed to sea-water. Another explanation is that the word meant `indigenous,' and that there are kindred words with that meaning in other Polynesian languages. First, `indigenous,' or "of the native race,' and then with a secondary meaning, `ours.' (See `Tregear's Maori Comparative Dictionary,' s.v.)

The form of the plural varies, The form <i>Maoris</i> is considered the more correct, but the form <i>Maories</i> is frequently used by good writers.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1841
Source:  Settlement of New Plymouth
Author:
Vol / Page:  16
Edition:
Quote:  (Settler's letter) The mauris (dark men) .... parkias (white men) ...

Author:  BUTLER
Vol / Page:  v/72
Edition:
Quote:   [pl] The few Maories that inhabit this settlement travel to the west coast by way of this river. They always go on foot, and we saw several traces of their encampments - little <i>mimis</i>, as they are called - a few light sticks thrown together, and covered with grass, affording a sort of half-and-half shelter for a single individual.

Wai maori</i> was fresh-water, oridinary as opposed to sea-water. Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Maori used as an adjective synonymous with <i>native </i>except that it seems slightly contemptuous. We admire native bush, pasture or game; but Maori hens (woodhens), Maori cabbage [European cabbage run wild, A Wall] and Maori onion (Chrysobactron hookeri] are caricatures of their English namesales.
Notes:  Acland

In the second world war Maoris served willingly, without the distrust that marked their attitude to fighting for the pakeha in the first world war. Maori soldiers served in the 28th Battalion (`the Maori Battalion') in North Africa, Crete, and Italy.

Date:  0/0/1908

Author:
Vol / Page:  No 5 (N.S.) 18
Edition:
Quote:  ...over all the basin the upper members were completely shorn away, excepting a strip of `Maori bottom' along the foot of the Pisa Range ... [near Cromwell, Central Otago] <i>Ibid.</i> 33 On the other hand, the sandstone gravels - the `Maori bottom' of alluvial miners -, ... are absent at Banneckburn.  <i>Ibid.</i> 42 <i>Sandstone Gravels </i>- These consist of yellowish known sandstones gravels, well rounded, and fairy uniform in size, the material seldom exceeds 6 in. in diameter, and is generally much decomposed. The gravels form the well-known `Maori bottom' of the Maniototo and Manuherikia basins.
Notes:   (Park)

Date:  0/9/1958
Source:  Tararua
Author:
Vol / Page:  28
Edition:
Quote:  ... The term <i>Maori bunk</i> for a shelf that serves as a common bed for several people is obviously a New Zealand expression and in no doubt due to the Maori habit of having a common sleeping floor. How well known the term is outside tramping circles I do not know, but the device was not unknown in the inns of rural France, I understand.
Notes:  Ruth Mason `Track and Trail'

The Maori's name for these horrible insects is <i>kekerengu</i>. They are about one inch and a half long and resemble a black cockroach in appearance.

Author:
Vol / Page:  1/351
Edition:
Quote:  There are very few cockroaches, the ones met with in habitations being exotic ones; the best known native species is the unpleasant stink-roach, often incorrectly called the `black beetle', and too frequently referred to as the `Maori bug' - a term that should be avoided because it is a name just as objectionable to the Maori as the insect's odour is to the Europeans who coined the name; however, it has been said that the term is a corruption of the original and inoffensive European name of `kauri bug'.
Notes:   (D. Miller)

Maori bunk
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a bench-type bunk with divisions between sleepers, as in a tramper's hut. (trampers') -->(probably pejorative, based on the Maori custom of sleeping visitors together) ; ca1945 the upper section of a tramping hut where trampers sleep without division and higgledy-piggledy on bracken in one large bunk.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1958
Source:  Great Days in NZ Mountaineering
Author:  PASCOE
Vol / Page:  156
Edition:
Quote:  They dug out a platform for the tent, lined the floor with rocks as a sleeping-bench or Maori bunk, and got stuck into another kea stew.


Notes:

Date:  0/9/1958
Source:  Tararua
Author:
Vol / Page:  28
Edition:
Quote:  ... The term <i>Maori bunk</i> for a shelf that serves as a common bed for several people is obviously a New Zealand expression and in no doubt due to the Maori habit of having a common sleeping floor. How well known the term is outside tramping circles I do not know, but the device was not unknown in the inns of rural France, I understand.
Notes:  Ruth Mason `Track and Trail'

Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Manawatu Tramping Club Jubilee
Author:
Vol / Page:  17
Edition:
Quote:   ...design for a hut. . ., to have a large open fire place and a bench type bunk (known in tramping circles as a Maori bunk), was approved. -->a large mattress or bunk base on which many people could sleep <i>Ibid.</i>  78 Two yards from the door stood the bunk house - two rooms with a Maori bunk, capable of sleeping a dozen, in each.
Notes:  [reference 1932]

Date:  0/8/2000
Source:  NZWords
Author:
Vol / Page:  7
Edition:
Quote:  Interestingly, in the subantarctic the same plant [sc. Macquarie cabbage, <i>Stilbocarpa polaris</i>] has another name, Maori cabbage, which in New Zealand English means especially the sow thistle (Maori puha), and certainly not the subantarctic plant. 'Maori' here probably had the sense of 'growing wild, non-domesticated.. and was applied to the <i>Stilbocarpa</i> by early Macquarie residents.

Date:  4/11/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Maori.</i>- Used as an adjective synonymous with<i> native</i>, except that it seems slightly contemptious. We admire native bush, pasture, or game; but <i>M.</i> hens (woodhens), <i>M.</i> cabbage [the European cabbage run wild--A.W.], and <i>M.</i> onion (Chrysobactron bookeri) are caricatures of their English namesakes. ([1898 Morris Austral-English])
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1939
Source:  First White Boy Born in Otago
Author:  BEATTIE
Vol / Page:  123
Edition:
Quote:  Along some rivers [in Otago in the 1860s] Maori cabbage grew and formed a welcome addition to the meagre vegetable supplies of the earliest incomers. ... Speaking of the so-called Maori cabbage, Mr Kennard remarked: `Up along the Kawa-rua [old pronunciation of Kawarau] between Cromwell and the Gorge there was Maori cabbage on the sandbanks, a sign that the Maoris had been there. It was like rape. When T.B.Nelson had Mount Royal he sowed rape with young grass, and an enterprising man put it in Maori kits and sold it in Palmerston as Maori cabbage.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1945
Source:  Maori Place-Names of Canterbury
Author:  BEATTIE
Vol / Page:  65
Edition:
Quote:  Pora is an introduced vegetable run wild. The word `pora' means a ship. The plant flourished up the rivers, and the first settlers called it `Maori cabbage'. The lists also call it Pora-kawa-kawa, but this is amalgamating two names, for the kawakawa is another vegetable run wild.

Date:  0/0/1852
Source:  Australian & NZ Gazette
Author:  33/11
Vol / Page:
Edition:  1852
Quote:  . ... A plant called the `Maori Cabbage'. Gathered some of the leaves for cooking. ... I believe this plant is a turnip which has degenerated for want of proper cultivation, so that the roots are too small to be of much use, but the tops are excellent boiled as greens. It is supposed to have been introduced by Captain Cook. .... Its appearance is always a sure sign that a Maori encampment has at some former time occupied the site.
Notes:  1851 Aust and NZ Gazette (1852) 33/11 (Journal Canterbury Settler)

Date:  0/0/1880
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  13/31
Edition:
Quote:  The leaves of several smaller plants were also used as vegetables [by the ancient Maoris]; but the use of these in modern times, or during the last forty or fifty years, was commonly superceded by that of the extremely useful and favourite plant - the Maori cabbage, <i>Brassica oleracea</i>, introduced by Cook (nani of the Maoris at the north, and rearea at the south), of which they carefully sowed the seeds. [<i>Williams: nani Brassica campestris</i>, wild cabbage, wild turnnip (Modern). <i>Rearea:</i> 2. Leaves of <i>korau</i> and other greens used as food]
Notes:  (Colenso)

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Collins Guide
Author:  AYLING
Vol / Page:  275
Edition:  1984
Quote:  <i>MAORI CHIEF>/i> (Black cod) <i>Notothenia angustata (Notothenia microlepidota) </i>... The maori chief, often named the black cod, is a large bottom-living fish similar in shape to the blue cod ... These fish are common ... around the south of the South Island ... <i>Ibid.</i> 276 <i>BLACK COD</i> (Black notothenid, maori chief) <i>Notothenia magellanica</i> ... The black cod is similar to the maori chief but has a deeper, less rounded body ... and does not reach such a large size. ... Black cod are common in inshore rocky areas south of Cook Strait ...

Source:  Codes for Species in NZ Waters

Maori copper
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: copper Maori
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1878
Source:  Autobiography
Author:  HEBERLEY
Vol / Page:  31
Edition:
Quote:  The Natives took a cask of lime, and thought it was cask of flour, they went to work and made dumplings of it and naked them in what is termed a Maori Copper.
Notes:  [1830s]

Date:  7/10/1864
Source:  Chudleigh Diary
Author:
Vol / Page:  147
Edition:  1950
Quote:  We roasted half a sheep in a Maori copper, that is first dig a hole in the ground in proportion to the thing you want to cook. Line the bottom and sides with stones as big as a breakfast cup then light a fire over them till they are quite red hot throwing in more loose stones to put on the top. Then take out all the ashes, wrap your meat in green grass put it in the pit, throw the loose stones on top and cover the whole with sods of grass, clay or anything that will keep the steam in, three or four hours will cook your meat to perfection.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1919
Source:  Maori as a Fisherman, The
Author:  POATA
Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:  They must be cooked off a tapu ground in the Maori copper only, custom forbidding any other method.
Notes:

Citations
Date:  2/9/1965
Source:  Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  A special report on the subject which the medical statistics branch of the Health Department has issued makes this point [of the prevalence of ear, nose, and throat disease among Maoris]. For more than half a century the `Maori ear' had been regarded in medical practice as a most unrewarding condition to treat in more ways than one and by both parties concerned, the report said. If future generations of Maori children retained their greater susceptibility to ear disease, every year would add to the size of the problem till it might become too big ever to be solved.

Vol / Page:  9

Quote:  [Dick Harris in Introduction] The reader should be warned that the apparently phonetic spelling of English as it is commonly supposed to be spoken by Hori is not to be accepted as authentic `Maori English'.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1971
Source:  Maori Children & the Teacher
Author:
Vol / Page:  42
Edition:
Quote:  It is sometimes stated that a Maori child's spoken vocabulary often lacks idiom. It is true that he has limited access to the wide range of expressions that enrich the English language, but `Maori English' is perhaps excessively idiomatic in its use of colloquial phrases, slang, and short, pithy expressions that convey more meaning than is in bare words. The range is not wide , however, and the expressions are used repetively, often to reinforce a meaning rather than add to it.
Notes:

Date:  0/5/1972
Source:  NZ Journal Educ. Studies
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:  59
Quote:  `Restricted Codes and Maori English' [title] A recent (1971) N.Z. Department of Education publication, Maori Children and the Teacher (henceforth MCT), discusses at some length the question of `Maori English' and the language of Maori children. [<i>Ibid </i>68] I hope to have shown, in this review, that we should not accept uncritically the assumption that Maori English constitutes a restricted code or that Maori children are cognitively deficient. We know that Maori English is different from Standard English and we are aware of some of the factors that make it so. ... evidence and ...
Notes:   P.Hawkins

Maori fire
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: <i>Pennantia corymbosa</i>; kaikomako
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: (see 1940 L & B 244 ff for Maui legend about this and its subsequent Maori use as a fire stick - that is a sharp-pointed stick worked along the surface of a flat piece of softer wood (eg mahoe)) -->[a1927] Ver (Stony Bay) = Vernacular names heard by J.C. Andersen at Stony Bay, Banks Peninsula) <i>Pennantia corymbosa </i>[fn] called because used for Maori fire - sticks; the tree also personified as Hine - Kaikomako
Citations
Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/151
Edition:
Quote:  <i>kaikomako</i>, a small tree (Pennantia corymbosa), bridal-tree, Maori fire. Sometimes kahikomako. The softer of the two woods used by the Maori for producing fire by friction: he can get the blaze in under a minute and a half.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Maori flounder
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: = black flounder
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1956
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  GRAHAM
Vol / Page:  204
Edition:
Quote:  NEW ZEALAND BLACK FLOUNDER or RIVER FLOUNDER (PATIKI-MOHOAO)

<i>Rhombosolea (Adamsoma) retiaria adams</i> Whitley and Phillipps/ It is known to fishermen and those in the fishing industry as the River Flounder as it is caught mostly inside or near the mouths of rivers and enters lakes where it lives chiefly among weeds. To some it is known as the Maori Flounder. I have helped to catch these fish in various rivers in New Zealand, Both in the North and South Islands, from the Bay of Islands, Bay of Plenty, Canterbury and Otago.

We admire native bush, pasture, or game; but <i>M</i>. hens (woodhens),<i> M.</i> cabbage [the European cabbage run wild--A.W.], and <i>M</i>. onion (Chrysobactron bookeri) are caricatures of their English namesakes. Notes:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/147
Edition:
Quote:  <i>weka</i>, a ground-bird (Ocydromus sp.), wood-hen, Maori hen; it has wings, but too small for flight, but it can dodge and run well; and whilst its long toes are unwebbed it swims well, and voluntarily takes to the water to investigate distant isles in the great lakes: a most inquisitive and amusing bush-companion, and a courageous mother.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

[fn. 1959] Weka or woodhen. Miners and others in the South Island attached the word `Maori' to many native plants and creatures.

Quote:  If I ever came here again ... I shall certainly come and stay here [in Central Otago] again ... as there are lots of hills ... besides there is lots of shooting ..., maori hens, rabbits and ducks, etc. etc. <i>Ibid.</i> 165 These maori hens are called Wekas and Lady Barker makes frequent mention of them in her book ...
Notes:  1873 Jan 31 G.M.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 160

Maori itch
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: usually aplied to irritating skin eruptions, or the bites of fleas or body lice; hakihaki (ake-ake)
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]

Maori King
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a) the leader of an originally 19th century Maori independence (`king') movement. b) the acknowledged leader of a confederation of North Island tribal groups.

Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]

Maori land
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: land held under customary title or as Maori freehold land
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim Cameron writes: The legal definition of Maori land in DNZE is confusing. <i>Maori customary land</i> is land held in accordance with tikanga Maori. <i>Maori freehold land</i> is essentially (there are minor qualifications) land that has been converted to English freehold tenure and has not been alienated to non-Maori. There are several trusts for various forms of Maori landholding - <i>ahi whenua trusts, kitiakai trusts, putea trusts, whanau trusts</i> and <i>whenua topu trusts</i>. Note also <i> status orders</i>. See Te Ture Whenua Maori Act 1993.
Citations
Date:  0/0/1900
Source:  Tales of the Colonial Turf
Author:  SCOTT
Vol / Page:  113
Edition:
Quote:  I've lost the rent money for the Maori land my father has leased up the river.
Notes:

Date:  26/8/1943
Source:  NZ Farmers' Weekly
Author:
Vol / Page:  7
Edition:
Quote:  Reports from County Councils have shown a marked improvement in rate payments from

Maori land.

Date:  0/0/1988

Author:
Vol / Page:  130

Quote:  Never once do I remember hearing [in Tauranga in the 1930s] about the confiscation of Maori land although the name `the Quarter Acres' for an area of town sections allotted to Pakeha after the Battles of Gate Pa and Te Ranga (1864) was commonly used.
Notes:  (Meikle)

Date:  0/1/1999
Source:  NZWords
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  Maori land and the terms relating to it are of course unique to New Zealand. DNZE defines it (in part) as land for which Maori customary or legal title is recognised as valid. This has a circular air and the contrast of customary and legal tile is confusing, since customary title is itself a title recognised by the law.  At law, Maori land is land owned by Maori under customary or Maori freehold title.
Notes:

Maori option
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the right of a person of Maori descent to choose whether to register on the Maori or the general electoral roll.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Electoral Act 1993, s. 76.
Citations
Date:  4/5/2001
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  4
Edition:
Quote:  As the next election appears on the horizon, a sense of futility is being sown in my psyche. Its source had been traced to the latest bit of political manoeuvring under the convenient title of the Maori Electoral Option... The final burlesque is when one' realises that the Maori option is provided every five years when the electoral cycle is every three years.
Notes:

Date:  0/1/1999
Source:  NZWords
Author:
Vol / Page:  1
Edition:
Quote:  Even the Dictionary of New Zealand English (DNZE) (1997) is patchy in its coverage of legal terms, having for example no entry for disputes tribunal, family protection, incorporated society, Maori option, protection order, resource consent.    The most recent edition of Butterworths New Zealand Law Dictionary (1995) is useful but commonly gives specialist   definitions   taken   from   the interpretation sections of statutes

Maori oven
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a hangi,umu or copper maori consisting of a hole dug in the ground, lined with hot stones, on which the raw food is placed wrapped in leaves, and the whole covered

Maori painkiller

(cf. painkiller)

Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]

Edition:

Notes:  Cite given in Orsman database as "A decoction of the leaves is known as Maori painkiller, and I have heard the tree itself so called. "

Date:  0/0/1925
Source:  NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:
Vol / Page:  8/107
Edition:
Quote:  The New Zealand South Island pepper-plant, <i>Wintera colorata</i> (better known under its old name,

<i>Drimys axillaris</i>), is one of our few magnolias ... Among bushmen a decoction of the leaves used to be much in vogue as a medicine, under the name of `Maori painkiller'. tree itself so called
Notes:   (Finlay)

Date:  0/0/1907
Source:  Plants of NZ
Author:  LAING & BLACKWELL
Vol / Page:  172
Edition:  1940 p. 180
Quote:  <i>Drimys axillaris [(The Pepper-tree)] </i>... A decoction of the leaves is often used by bushmen as a medicine, and has earned the name of "Maori Painkiller.' ... Called by the settlers the Pepper Tree. Maori name <i>Horopito.</i> [The plant is closely related to the South American Winter's Bark.]

Author:
Vol / Page:  247
Edition:
Quote:   ... from the `Sixties' to the early `Nineties' of the last century the peach flourished exceedingly in the warmer areas of the North Island ... Trees were first raised from stones brought to New Zealand by missionaries and early settlers; they were subsequently grown so widely by the Maori that they became known as the `Maori' peach. None survives today; all having been destroyed during the late `Nineties' mainly by two diseases ...
Notes:  Cunningham Plant Diseases

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1971
Source:  NZ Heritage
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/253
Edition:
Quote:   The first permanent European introduction of real consequence to the Bay of Islands was a type of potato, brought by Marion du Fresne's expedition of 1772 and called by the New Zealanders uwhi - the name of one of their own yams. The uwhi potato and other early introduced varieties - known collectively today as `Maori potatoes' although each has its own distinctive name - are still found growing in some home gardens, more especially in the rural areas of the north.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author:  BURTON
Vol / Page:  14
Edition:
Quote:  These early varieties of Irish potato came to be known as `Maori potatoes' and are still found in country areas of Northland.
Notes:

Date:  27/4/1983
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  33
Edition:
Quote:  It is always a great pity our so called Maori potatoes, with their ...purplish-red skins and flecks of purple through the flesh, have been allowed to become virtually extinct.
Notes:

Date:  0/6/1985
Source:  Letter
Author:  A.D. THOMSON
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  By chance in 1984 I received a boole from the International Potato Center at Lima, Peru ... and the cover shows Andean potato cultivars - some very similar to the `Urenika' type. I have speculated that perhaps this similarity provides some support for the notion that lines of the maori potato came to Aotearoa direct from South America and not via Europe.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1983
Source:  Botany Division (DSIR) Newsletter
Author:
Vol / Page:  No. 85/11
Edition:
Quote:  The Maori Potato The ancient potato cultivars commonly referred to as Maori potatoes may be descended from tubers given to the Maori by early explorers, or they may have come direct from South America with the early colonisation of the Pacific. Doug Yen ... now at the Bishop Museum appears to have been the first to collect and study these early potatoes (<i>The Potato Journal summer 1961/61:</i> 2-5) and he refers to the introductions by de Surville in 1769 and 1772 and by Cook in 1773. Yen also refers to the possible introduction direct from South America, since Callao in Peru and Acapulco in Mexico were provisioning ports for whaling vessels. This year I grew `Urenaka' (Yen refers to `Urenika') ... and I understand this cultivar came from the East Coast. It is certainly an unusual potato with purplish stems and tubers. ... Yen ... notes that they resemble the storied (Iodine) potato of Ireland, used as a talisman against illness. ... Audrey [Eagle] said that when she gave some [similar] tubers to a Maori lady she exclaimed `ah, rokekuri'.
Notes:  (A.D. Thomson)

Date:  0/0/1987
Source:  Triennial Report Botany Division
Author:
Vol / Page:  1982-1984/68
Edition:
Quote:  INCIDENCE OF VIRUS DISEASES IN `MAORI' POTATOES [heading] The `Maori' potato is one of our earliest introduced plants and there is documented evidence that James Cook in 1769 gave potato tubers to the Maori people ...
Notes:

Date:  22/7/1922
Source:  Auckland Weekly News
Author:
Vol / Page:  18
Edition:
Quote:  Even the Maori potato clearings barely scarred the primal beauty of forests.

Date:  15/5/1956

Author:
Vol / Page:  427
Edition:
Quote:  In the southern part of Hawera district, early bush flows of nectar can be expected from five finger, Maori privet, and kowhai from September onward. Usually there is a light flow from Maori privet (Geniostoma ligustrifolium) in this area, and this surplus is taken from the bush hives in early November.

The Speaker, Peter Tapsell, came to Banks' defence, pointing out that both Maori and pakeha working in his shearing shed regularly used the term and that Banks' use of it had not harmed race relations.

in a term like <i>Maori P.T.</i> (from the army P T = physical training) to mean lying down and doing nothing, what the Australian calls <i>spinebashing. </i>

Quote:  <i>Maori P.T.</i>: lying down
Notes:  Goldie Brown Collection

Date:  1/7/1988
Source:  Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:   Brown and white there were no differences between the colours then [in WW2]. The happy members of the 28th Battalion referred to themselves as `horis' (I've never known what the word meant, but now to use it is as big an insult as for a white to be called a Pakeha), and spoke of `Maori time' (some time) and `Maori PT' (lying on one's bedroll) and we followed their lead, not knowing that they, and we, were using such appallingly insulting terms to the Maori race that a special Race Relations Conciliator would have to be installed to quell them.
Notes:   (John C. Mcab)

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A

Vol / Page:  72
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Maori PT</i>  taking a rest; jokey, offensive.

Date:  29/6/1988
Source:  Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:  Maori Schools</i> ... The Maori state primary schools (called `native schools' until 1947) were established after 1867 usually in remote, rural, and predominantly Maori communities. The official policy was one of assimilation. The schools provided an English-type education and special instruction in English for Maori children, the majority of whom still spoke Maori as their first language.
Notes:

Date:  31/1/1993
Source:  Sunday Times (NZ)
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  It is 30 years since the state-funded

system of Native Schools (later called

Maori Schools) ceased to exist.

Date:  15/2/2003
Source:  Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  F3
Edition:
Quote:  In the 1960s and 70s, Maori showbands criss-crossed the globe, their names emblazoned in lights above marquees from Las Vegas to London, Hawaii to Hamburg... What was distinctive about Maori showbands, apart from their Maoriness, was the versatility. Members had to be able to mime, dance and do comedy skits as well as sing and play several instruments... But the audience still gets what she describes as the "pure showband" routine, which means frequent instrument and costume changes and lost of comedy (Shirley Bassey and the Bee Gees are favoured spoof subjects) in between the straight songs.
Notes:

Maori sickness
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: mate Maori
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Some Modern Maoris
Author:  BEAGLEHOLE
Vol / Page:  205
Edition:
Quote:   .. he thinks of sickness, particularly that kind of sickness which he calls Maori sickness, as very often caused by spirits as a punishment for the violation of tapu or custom. <i>Ibid.</i> 219 The sign most often taken to indicate this sort of sickness is that the sickness does not appear to be yielding readily to ordinary Maori or to pakeha methods of treatment. It is then considered to be a Maori sickness - a `mate Maori' as the phrase is commonly used - and for sure, safe, and quick results, treatment should be referred to a Maori expert, a tohunga, either male or female, who will use a combination of religious prayer, seance-possession, and magic to restore the sick person to health. The inner bark [of <i>M. fulgens</i>] was also boiled and the liquid was drunk for `Maori sickness'.
Notes:

Date:  31/3/1984
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  19
Edition:
Quote:  The pa wasted away after Te Kere's death about the turn of the century, affected by, among other thing, Maori sickness (mate Maori).
Notes:

Date:  30/1/1853
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  32
Edition:
Quote:  .. week to the psychiatric hospital to diagnose and treat `Maori sickness,' break tapu and sometimes hold Church services in Maori.
Notes:

Date:  0/5/1987
Source:  Metro
Author:
Vol / Page:  100
Edition:
Quote:  If a Maori is genuinely disturbed, in Maori terms, the answer again is to restore their mauri (life force), as for physical illness. This is particularly true for <i>mate</i> Maori, Maori sickness, which arises from spiritual and social causes, not physical ones (Pakehas would call it psychosomatic).
Notes:

Date:  10/3/2007
Source:  Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  A1
Edition:
Quote:  "Maori sickness was pretty strong in the time of our fathers and grandfathers. It is still happening if things are not done in the right manner." In 2000, Tariana Turia, who was then associate Maori Affairs minister [sic], questioned whether psychologists had the appropriate training to deal with issues such as Maori sickness (mate Maori).
Notes:

Edition:
Quote:  A "Maori sidestep" is another term frequently used by rugby men.. to describe the tactic of putting the shoulder down and charging through and over an opponent rather than actually side-stepping him.


Notes:

Date:  0/2/1981
Source:  Avondale College Slang Words in Use
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Maori side-step</i>: direct charge
Notes:  (Goldie Brown Collection)

Date:  21/8/1984
Source:  Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page:  3
Edition:
Quote:  The term `Maori sidestep' was made during the instant re-play of Stone's first-half try, which ended with a powerful, barging dive at the line. Mr Wallace complained that commentator Grant Nisbett described it as `the famous Maori sidestep' while others attribute the remark to Grahame Thorne. Mr Wallace said: `To me that comment means Maoris do not take the peaceful way, or sidestep, they bully their way through anything.'
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  NZ English (Gordon & Deverson)
Author:
Vol / Page:  42
Edition:
Quote:  (Similar expressions include <i>...Maori sidestep</i> = a head-on charge in rugby,

a <i>Maori job/outfit/etc.</i> = something rough or disorganised - compare the use of <i>bush</i> in similar formations.)
Notes:  Gordon and Deverson

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  72
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Maori sidestep</i> headlong knees-threshing barge through a tackle; doubly offensive.

Homonym Number:

Quote:  The boys swung round and round the pole, as with the Maori swing or morere. It was known as the Giant's Stride.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1847
Source:  Savage Life
Author:  ANGAS
Vol / Page:  2/118
Edition:
Quote:  The Maori or native swing is an amusement amongst the Taupo people which is obsolete upon the coast. A pole, generally the trunk of a <i>kaikatea</i> pine, is erected in the centre of an open space adjoining the village; flax ropes are suspended from the top, and, holding on to these, the natives swing round and round, in a manner similar to that which is practised in gymnasia and at country fairs in Europe.
Notes:

Maori time
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a relaxed and flexible view of time as a regulator of people's activities, reputedly a Maori characteristic (compare Pakeha time).
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  20/2/1999
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  61
Edition:
Quote:  The phrase "Maori time" has not been abroad much of late, but recent events have highlighted a linguistic gap that it will fill very neatly. Maori time is a period of 12 days, or the length of time that elapses between a major disaster and the government's getting around to doing something about it when that disaster affects a predominantly Maori community, say, in the Far North.

Maori village settlement
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: scheme to establish villages espressly for Maori
Citations
Date:  3/6/1944
Source:  Star, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  3
Edition:
Quote:  Among the Bills to be introduced by the Government is one for the establishment of a Maori village settlement under the perpetual lease system.   A small rental will be charged, and stringent conditions as to occupancy will be enforced.   The right of transfer will be limited to other Natives, and all precautions will be taken to prevent a transfer to Europeans.   The system will be applied especially to the South Island Natives, many of whom are said to be almost homeless.   The Government will buy the land necessary for the settlement.

Edition:  1981
Quote:  THE MOUNTED RIFLEMAN [title] New Zealanders in these regions are popularly referred to, in their Homeland, as `The Mounteds"; and as being indicative of their pecularities in method of warfare, the term has its value. In origin, the Mounted Riflemen date back to the 'sixties, when that fine soldier, Major Sir Harry Atkinson, formed the settler-riflemen into a mounted force of a nature demanded by the topographical and tactical conditions of the fiercely-contested Maori wars.

Maori Warden
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a semi-official, uniformed volunteer who patrols public places, bars, etc., in ways helpful to Maori people and others.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1999
Source:  Maori & Alcohol
Author:  HUTT
Vol / Page:  73
Edition:
Quote:  Maori Wardens were appointed in 1949 as a result of the Liquor Licensing Bill 1948. Wardens were administered through the Department of Maori Affairs and nominated by tribal executives. Wardens had power over liquor and liqor-related disturbances within tribal districts, with powers over Maori pub patrons and over Pakeha at hui or if there was sly-grogging... In many ways the Maori wardens were following in the tradition of the Ringatu pirihimana, the Ratana katipa and the Kingite watene.
Notes:  See FLERAS <i>A Descriptive Analysis of Maori Wardens in the Historical and Contemporary Context of New Zealand Society</i>", Ph.D, VUW, 1980, esp. pp.269-275

Source:  North Cape to Bluff

Maori wedding
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  Speaking for Ourselves
Author:  OWEN & PERKINS
Vol / Page:  109
Edition:
Quote:  In those days [c1890s] they had what was known as the `Maori wedding', which was not legal to the Pakeha, but was a binding thing among the Maori people themselves. A young couple would decide that they wanted to become man and wife, and they would have to tell their parents they wanted this. Well, at night-time everyone would congregate in the meetinghouse [the matter would be discussed, the boy and girl would be asked whether they wanted to marry, and they would take each other in front of all their people].




Notes:  (Florence Harsant, Taupo)

Date:  0/0/1960

Quote:  Once at a horse sale at Palmerston North, Mr. Bob Waller was selling a draft of what might be termed `Maori Weeds', or rather stunted, but nice condition nags, from the Sandy Country towards Foxton.
Notes:

Date:  31/8/1963
Source:  Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page:  7
Edition:
Quote:  Undoubtedly there was good blood among these horses, though the great majority would come into the somewhat elastic classification of `Maori weed.' In actual fact, there was no reproach in the term, Born and reared on the inhospitable plains, a horse developed a stamina that no finely-bred animal possessed. Well broken in and handled properly, a `weed' would get through more hard toiling in a day than the average equine would put behind him in a week. Looks might be against him, but for downright hard work in the high hill country he had the goods, as they say, and with something to spare.
Notes:  [reference to ca 1910, Kaingaroa Plains]

Date:  5/7/1918
Source:  Chronicles NZEF
Author:
Vol / Page:  IV/47 : 251
Edition:
Quote:  It takes Bill and I two hours to catch

that old roany Maori weed we used for

packing tucker.

Three Taranaki poi parties, six persons representing three Hahi [ed fn: Churches], a gathering representative of the Crown, Parliament (all three parties in the Lower House and the Acting-Leader of the Upper), the Press and Pakeha public and all sections of Maoridom, gathered together all the elements that constitute the New Zealand community of to-day, ...

And there may be others like minded to carry on some of the concrete forms of Maoridom.

Maorihead
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: usu. <i>Carex</i> spp (esp. <i>C. secta</i> and <i>C. virgata</i>)
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: niggerhead
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1856
Source:  Diary
Author:  W H S ROBERTS
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Writing of the Waimea Plain in 1856: - `The ground was well grassed, but the speargrass was too plentiful. The pasturage was very good. There was a good deal of scrub in the bends of the Mataura known as `wire plant' (Olearia virgata). There were also manuka and koromiko. Maori-heads, a kind of grass tree about three feet high, abounded in the swamps, and in some we saw toitoi grass and raupo. We did not pass any cabbage trees to-day ... we proceeded slowly through tomatakuru scrub, speargrass, Spaniard, snowgrass, and other native grasses ... we camped in a bend with good feed at the Elbow and a swamp on one side. Maori cabbage abounded ...'
Notes:  1856 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 18

Vol / Page:  73

Author:
Vol / Page:  66

Quote:  He shifts into galvanising-leader mode, exhorting membership drives, slamming recent government publicity "about-turns" on Maori policy, dismissing the planned 2005 hui tamata (Maori economic summit) as little more than a government publicity stunt, stressing the need to validate Maori knowledge and "take New Zealand with us. We have to do as we preach; we have to help them get over the whakama [embarassment] of saying 'Papatoetoe' [correctly] in front of their friends ... We will Maori-ise New Zealand. ..."

Maoriland
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: This use may be a narrowing of 1, but it would seem to refer to the Maori parts of New Zealand, and not to the whole country or to pre-European New Zealand as a `land of Maori' (Best's examples may be his personal use: or the expression may be mainly `pakeha-maori')

Source:  Old New Zealand
Author:
Vol / Page:  (i)3
Edition:
Quote:   ... it was ... from the deck of a small trading schooner ... that I first cast eyes on Maori land.

It <i>was</i> Maori land then; but, alas! what is it now? Success to you, O King of Waikato. May your<i> mana</i> never be less! <i>Ibid.</i> (vii) 105 There were in the old times two great institutions, which reigned with iron rod in Maori land - the <i>Tapu</i> and the <i>Muru</i>. Pakehas who knew no better called the <i>muru</i> simply `robbery', because the word <i>Muru</i>, in its common signification, means to plunder. But I speak of the regular legalized and established system of plundering as penalty for offences, which in a rough way resembled our law by which a man is obliged to pay `damages'.

Maoriland
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: New Zealand, orig. journalistic or poetic, but later taken up by Sydney <i>Bulletin</i> writers and editors.

Domain: [none]

Edition:

Quote:  There is no doubt that more than the spirit which pervades our people on development work ..., what impressed the Tokerau delegates last year when they visited those districts was the `maoritanga' of the tribes inhabiting that part of the Eastern Maori electorate. It was not a maoritanga of the lips as among the Waikato, but was manifested in persistent cultural traits, carvings, plaiting, marae ceremonial, poetry and song, speech and so forth.

Date:  0/0/1965
Source:  New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author:  CAMERON
Vol / Page:  94
Edition:
Quote:  To a certain extent, in fact, <i>Maoritanga</i> is not a matter of inheritance; it is a matter of

<i>he manawa</i>, of `how one feels.' <i>Ibid.</i> 75 But when Sir James Carroll and other leaders of the Young Maori Party wanted a term to denote the way of life of their people, they took the completely-assimilated modern meaning of the word `Maori' - which, thanks to the <i>pakeha</i>, transcended tribal boundaries - and coined a new meaning for `Maoritanga.' The meaning of the term is debated and discussed, analyzed and defined, used and abused with great frequency in the present upsurge of interest in Maori culture and traditional ways of thinking, feeling, and acting. A second Maori renaissance seems to be under way, aided by this all-embracing term and strengthened by the success of the first one in the early decades of this century.
Notes:

Notes:

mapau
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: often loosely called matipo: a group of shrubs or small trees, of roughly similar general appearance, used mainly as hedge-plants or ornamentals. a) red matipo, having reddish bark. b) loosely used for some Pittosporum species, such as black mapau or matipo; white mapau, tarata. [Maori mapau[a1-macron], mapou[a1-macron] red matipo]. 1. <i>Myrsine australis</i> (formerly <i>Suttonia australis, Myrsine Urvillei, Rapanea Urvillei</i>) (red) matipo, red mapau, =maple


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: also mapauriki, maple
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1867
Source:  Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names)
Author:  HOOKER
Vol / Page:  766
Edition:
Quote:  Mapau, <i>Col[enso]. Myrsine australis. </i>
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  286
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Mapau, n</i>. a Maori name for several New Zealand trees; called also<i> Mapou</i>, and frequently corrupted by settlers into <i>Maple</i>, by the law of Hobson-Jobson. The name is applied to the following. The Mapau - <i>Myrsine urvillei</i>, De C., <i>N.O. Myrsineaem</i>; sometimes called <i>Red Mapau</i>. Black M. - <i>Pittosporum tenuifolium</i>, Banks and Sol., <i>N.O. Pittosporeae; </i>Maori name <i>Tawhiri</i>. White M. - <i>Carpodetus serratus,</i> Forst., <i>N.O. Saxifrageae; Pittosporum eugenoides,</i> A. Cunn.; Maori name, <i>Tarata</i> (q.v.); called also the <i>Hedge-laurel</i> (q.v.), <i>Lemon-wood,</i> and <i>New Zealand Oak</i>. See <i>Oak</i>. The first of these (<i>Myrsine urvillei</i>) is, according to Colenso, the only tree to which the Maoris themselves give the name <i>Mapau.</i> The others are only so called by the settlers.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1907
Source:  Plants of NZ
Author:  LAING & BLACKWELL
Vol / Page:  332
Edition:  1940 p. 353
Quote:  <i>[Suttonia australis (The Red Matipo)<i>] ... Native name <i>Mapau, Mapou</i>, or <i>Matipo</i>. The name Matipo is generally applied by Europeans to <i>Pittosporum tenuifolium</i>, but this is apparently the plant to which the Maoris attached it. This tree bears some resemblance to <i>Pittosporum tenuifolium</i>, but can be readily distinguished by the reddish colour of the leaves. [<i>Rapanea Urvillei</i>, 1907]
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1907
Source:  Plants of NZ
Author:  LAING & BLACKWELL
Vol / Page:  332
Edition:  1940 p. 353
Quote:  <i>[Suttonia australis (The Red Matipo)</i>] ... Native name <i>Mapau, Mapou</i>, or <i>Matipo</i>. The name Matipo is generally applied by Europeans to <i>Pittosporum tenuifolium</i>, but this is apparently the plant to which the Maoris attached it. This tree bears some resemblance to <i>Pittosporum tenuifolium</i>, but can be readily distinguished by the reddish colour of the leaves. [<i>Rapanea Urvillei</i>, 1907]
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1929
Source:  Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.
Author:

[Maori] <i>Ma&#769;.po-u</i>(ma.&#769;.p&omacr.-u;<i> colloq</i>. m&adot.&#769;.pu), <i> (Bot.)</i> A New Zealand tree<i> Myrsine Urvillei</i>), of the order <i>Myrsineae</i>; called also <i>matapou, matapo, matipo,</i> and <i>maple. [Local, N. Z.] Black mapau, </i>name applied incorrectly by New Zealand settlers to the tree <i>Pittosporum tenuifolium</i>, of the order <i>Pittosporeae. - White mapau, (a) </i>The tarata <i>(Pittosporum eugenoides);</i> -called also <i>turpentine tree. (b) </i>The saxifragaceous tree piripiri <i>(Carpodetus serratus); called often mapou.</i> See PIRIPIRI.

maple
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a folk alteration of mapau, mapou, esp. common in southern South Island: (possibly from exudations of gum (see 1769) as well as spelling and pronunciation: final -ou would approach a variant dark -l final) [AND 1889]


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]

Source:  NZ Journal of Science
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/50
Edition:
Quote:  The perversity with which the true `beeches' have become popularly known as `birches,' and different kinds of `mapau' as `maples - a popular name which includes small trees of widely distinct Natural Order, is enough to fill with despair any botanist who desires to foster a system of popular names that will be free from misleading and inaccurate suggestions.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  287
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Maple, n</i>. In New Zealand, a common settlers' corruption for any tree called <i>Mapau</i> (q.v.); in Australia, applied to <i>Villaresia moorei,</i> F. v. M., N.O. <i>Olacinea,</i> called also the <i>Scrub Silky Oak</i>. See <i>Oak. </i>

Vol / Page:  194
Edition:  1940, p. 203
Quote:  [<i>Pittosporum eugenioides</i>] it is often cultivated for its beauty, and is sometimes - though not so often as <i>P. [195] tenuifolium</i> - used to form an ornamental hedge. It is known by a variety of names amongst the colonists, such as <i>Mapau, White Mapau</i>, and even<i> Maple</i>, and <i>Lemon-tree.</i> The Maori name seems to have been <i>Tarata,</i> but it is also called the <i>Mapau. </i>

Date:  0/0/1866
Source:  Station Life in NZ
Author:  BARKER
Vol / Page:  94
Edition:  1870
Quote:  I can give you no idea of the variety among the shrubs: the koromika, like an Alpine rose, a compact ball of foliage; the lancewood, a tall, slender stem, ... with a few long leaves at the top, turned downwards like the barb of a spear, and looking exactly like a lance stuck into the ground; the varieties of matapo ... each leaf a study, with its beautiful tracery of black veins on a yellow-green ground; the mappo, the gohi, and many others ...

Even as firewood it is despised, and bears the all too suggestive name of `Bucket of Water Wood', so little is it calculated by its combustive qualities to enliven the domestic hearth. <i>IBid.</i> 178 Maupariki [Maori name] .. Notes:

marae
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: the courtyard of a Maori meeting-house, the centre of tribal life. [Maori]; enclosed space in front of a house; courtyard; village common (So Williams) Maori, marae pron ['marae], [ma'rae].
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: often now used of the whole complex of courtyard, meeting-house, and ancillary buildings and grounds. Also in modern use as urban marae, a marae complex designed to serve Maori townspeople of mixed iwi affiliation who have moved away from their tribal areas.  Maori meeting-houses as such are post-European: to be distinguished from carved houses : meeting-place the marae; but the Maori marae must be distinguished from the larger ritualistic Tahitian marae
Citations
Date:  0/0/1983
Source:  Bone People, The
Author:  HULME
Vol / Page:  467
Edition:
Quote:  238 Marae = a place for gathering, to learn to mourn, teach, welcome and rejoice
Notes:

Date:  31/3/1984
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  19
Edition:
Quote:  But in its day it was one of the largest marae on the river, with around 1000 inhabitants.

Date:  31/3/1984
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  19

Edition:
Quote:  But in its day it was one of the largest marae on the river, with around 1000 inhabitants.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  Towards Taha Maori
Author:  HOWE
Vol / Page:  21
Edition:
Quote:  Marae - marae are not just the buildings on a piece of land, though we can refer to particular marae. Marae need people and their customs for them to be anything meaningful. The front of the marae is called the atea (from `Te mare nui atea o Tu matauenga' - the big marae of Tu, the god of war). Marae are places where the Maori may assert his/her uniqueness and culture, and are used for tangi, feasts, meetings, weddings and many other reasons.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  Landfall
Author:  GRA
Vol / Page:  156/453
Edition:

Quote:  The marae as we know it today is taken to mean a complex comprising a meeting house, courtyard and dining hall, although this is a relatively modern innovation. Originally the marae was the earthen courtyard in the village, and it was situated immediately outside the chief's house.

The whare wananga beside it, meant to house the kohanga reo, lies uncompleted, torn building paper flapping.

Date:  0/0/1959
Source:  Descriptive Atlas
Author:  McLINTOCK
Vol / Page:  72
Edition:
Quote:  In the country proper the Maori has retained his traditional mode of life which is symbolised in the <i>marae</i> . In a literal sense the term means the open courtyard in front of the communal meeting house; today ... it embraces all aspects of community life - community buildings, tribal gatherings, church activities, and recreation.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1959
Source:  History of New Zealand
Author:  SINCLAIR
Vol / Page:  24
Edition:
Quote:  Among the Maoris the <i>marae</i> , a word which elsewhere in Polynesia meant temple, was the plaza which lay before the meeting-house and was the focus of village life. Most important of all, the <i>marae</i>  was the place where men of influence made their speeches. <i>Ibid.</i> 302 [Maori glossary] <i>marae</i>  Space in front of meeting house; plaza

Author:
Vol / Page:  C6
Edition:
Quote:  Jee Hansen's maral deer are a damn nuisance at feeding out time, he says.... When he tows a trailer-load of hay into the paddock, the marals will jump on to it... The marals are still a relatively rare sight in New Zealand. They are a type of red deer originating from the Caucasus mountains in Russia and are specially prized for their calm temperament. The New Zealand marals all stem from one hind imported 15 years ago.

Homonym Number:

Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Citations
Date:  5/10/2002
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  60
Edition:
Quote:  It provides a perfect metaphor for both the subject and the persona dramatis of this absorbing, well-researched book focusing on the Maramatanga movement, a Maori belief system that grew out of a desire to incorporate the ancient tohunga ways with the teachings of the New Testament... Based around the Ruapehu area and stretching as far as the Whanganui River area, the Maramatanga is a unique series of beliefs. Although the majority of its practitioners belong to the Roman Cathlic branch of Christianity, the teaching of Rikiriki, who was both a prophet and a healer, are designed to being together the old and the new, rather than the outright rejection of the old ways preferred by most Protestant missionaries.
Notes:

Date:  0/11/2002
Source:  Wel-com (Wellington)
Author:
Vol / Page:  16
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Maramatanga</i> literally means <i>enlightenment</i> or <i> understanding</i>. The people of the Maramatanga belong to a prophetic and religious movement who by faith, story, waiata and ritual have sustained their identity and autonomy in the face of an overwhelming Pakeha society.

kelpfish, [266] <i>Odax vittatus.</i> These young fish are yellow-brown with a line of white dashes running down each side ... [Butterfish] are an excellent eating fish, with delicate tasty flesh that prompted the name butterfish ...

Dr. Knox, in the <i>Transactions of the New Zealand Institute</i>, gives the following interesting details of the marare of the Natives : `On the 2nd August, 1870, a large quantity of the kelp-fish were offered for sale in and about Wellington, and though by no means prepossessing in external appearance, being of a dingy-black colour, and covered with a slimy mucus, I found that the fish frequent Cook Strait, more especially off and around the Mana.'

Quote:  [Maori or Settlers' Name] Spotties, Marare .. [Scientific Name] <i>Labrichthys bothryocosmus </i>
Notes:  (P. Thomson, Otago)

Date:  0/0/1933
Source:  Tides of Youth

Quote:  `Reverend Mother talks of when she used to give you marbles for being a good little boy - pee-wees and agates, and stonies and glassies and a big tor. And once she tried to play with you, and you said she funked because her knuckle was inside the ring.'
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1972
Source:  Folkgames of Children
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  174
Edition:
Quote:  Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies.

Edition:
Quote:  <i>Haplodactylus meandratus </i>(Richardson). Marble-fish (granite trout).
Notes:  Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour

Date:  0/0/1956
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  GRAHAM
Vol / Page:  248
Edition:
Quote:  GRANITE TROUT or MARBLE FISH (KEKE) <i>Dactylosargus arctidens maeandratus</i> Richardson The common names of this fish are derived from the resembalance of the skin to marble or granite. The ground colour is black, mottled or waved with slaty-grey. At one time this fish was sold in Auckland and Wellington as Maori Chief but I do not know why this should be, as the true Maori Chief is quite different and not at all like the Granite Trout.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1956
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  GRAHAM

Notes:
Citations
marching
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: women's formation marching as a competitive sport
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: It seems the trail leads back to Aucklandabout 1924 at earliest, first real exhibition probably 1926; competitions between various factories in the clothing trade. The restrictions on uniforms mentioned below were brought in to prevent big firms outspending the smallones by providing splendiferous uniforms. Organisations outside the rag trade do not seem to have been allowed in officially into Interhouse Marching until about 1954.  Despite the evidence below that it started in Auckland under Jean Stevenson, Bateman's Encyclopedia says marching started in Wellington and spread to Auckland later.  It must be wrong. The plot thickens. Passing through London Bookshop today I spotted Gordon Ell's new book on NZ Trivia and Kiwiana and he says Marching Girls started in Dunedin in the 1920s. have I found any early Auckland ones, nothing before 1941 in Wellington. guess is that one or other or both of Jean Stevenson and Kathleen Montgomery started them in Auckland and through the YWCA spread them rapidly throughout the main centres.
Citations
Date:  10/5/2003
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  37
Edition:
Quote:  New Zealanders should be proud of marching. It is the most major sport invented in this country.

Quote:  Charlie Stone, a Wellington businessman,

and Sergeant Major.. G. O'Leary... were

responsible for getting the Wellington

Interhouse Girls' Marching Association

formed, though the Wellington and Kiwi

Amateur Athletic Clubs, with O'Leary one

of the leading lights, were the first to

stage outdoor marching displays in

Wellington.
Notes:

Date:  15/4/1966
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  14
Edition:
Quote:  Girls' marching as a sport or competition

was started in Auckland by Miss Jean

Stevenson, General Secretary of the YWCA

in Auckland in the early 1920s. The idea

was to give some recreation to girls who

did not favour the robust sports of

hockey or basketball... In due course, marching competitions came

to Wellington... You can tell  a marching girl by the way

she carries herself - and by the absence

of round shoulders... The Wellington Inter-house Marching

Association was formed with rules

governing costume to allow the

participants to take part in running and

ball-relay events as well as marching.




Notes:

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  Every Girl
Author:  CONEY
Vol / Page:  179
Edition:
Quote:  The highlights.. [in Auckland, in 1926]

were the massed drill display of 400

girls coached by Kathleen Montgomery, and

the grand march-past... This marching

would develop in skill and complexity

from year to year and eventually lead to

the formation of a marching association

in Auckland.
Notes:

Vol / Page:  4

were seen at the Easter Show Stadium on

was given. The competing teams, of which

there were ten, comprised eight girls,

represent.

Quote:  Despite scurrilous suggestions that marching was an Australian invention, NZ Marching asserts that the sport was introduced to Australia when New Zealand's Grenadier Guards visited there in 1953. It was not until 1977 that trans-Tasman rivals competed in the first inter-dominion championships.

Citations
Date:  0/7/1952
Source:  Here & Now
Author:
Vol / Page:  9
Edition:
Quote:  ... not for a long time have I observed such an odd symptom of our <i>malaise </i>as the business of `marching girls'. This cult has not only established itself firmly in New Zealand: it is even being exported. ... Enquiries I have made as to the origin of this astonishing sport, or prank, ... have so far been fruitless. It has the earmarks of being an American invention, but I cannot be at all sure about this [suggests Air Force training grounds].




Notes:  (A.R.D.Fairburn)

Date:  0/0/2000
Source:  No 8 Wire: The Best of Kiwi Ingenuity
Author:  BRIDGES & DOWNS
Vol / Page:  132
Edition:
Quote:  The first record of 'Marching Girls' is in the official history of the visit of the Duke and Duchess of Cornwall and York in 1901. During the Dunedin celebrations, about 500 girls marched past as a celebration of 'girls' drill'.

an innocent exhibitionism; marching girls

Date:  24/11/1961

Vol / Page:  36
Edition:
Quote:  [Caption] Marching girls in a drill

display at Basin Reserve, Wellington, in

1936... It is not easy to win a marching medal

these days, so when you next see a

marching girl with a display of medals

that would make a Field Marshal envious

you will realise that the walking jingle

represents many hours of hard practice.

Marion
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: Early nickname for `Frenchman'; in pl. `The French'. cf WIWI (from Marion du Fresne, a French Captain killed, with his crew, in a Maori revenge attack, 182?) esp. the TRIBE OF MARION, trans. from Maori
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation: =Tribe of Marion
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1936
Source:  Treaty of Waitangi
Author:  BUICK
Vol / Page:  11
Edition:
Quote:  We have heard that the tribe of Marion is at hand coming to take away our land ...[fn. The French were called by the natives `the tribe of marion' after Captain Marion du Fresne, who met his untimely death at their hands in 1772.]


Notes:  1831 Nov 16 Petition of Chiefs to King William in 1936 Buick Treaty of Waitangi 11

Date:  0/0/1839
Source:  New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author:  LANG
Vol / Page:  16
Edition:
Quote:  One of the natives ..... perceived that M. Lacoste was not an Englishman, and asked Mr. Mair `if he were not a Marion' to which Mr Mair replied in the affirmative. Marion ['s] ... name has ever since [ca1800] been the synonym for `Frenchman' in New Zealand.

market umbrella
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a type of sun umbrella (square/octagonal) doubtless originally used to shade produce at street markets but in NZ more commonly used on patios, decks, etc.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim writes: The term is not in any dictionary I have seen and is not self-defining. It is likely to be international English in the extended as well as the original sense, but may be worth checking.

Marlborough daisy
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: <i>Pachystegia</i> genus
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  1/6/2002
Source:  Dominion Weekend Magazine
Author:
Vol / Page:  9
Edition:
Quote:  In its stony native habitat the Marlborough Daisy is often straggly and less prepossessing, which may explain why it has been notably lacking from private gardens despite their eye appeal and the fact that they were discovered way back in 1853. Its discoverer first classed it with the Olearia genus but it was later given its own genus, <i>Pachystegia</i>, a family which occurs naturally only in New Zealand.
Notes:

Sense Number:

maro
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a traditional Maori dress, a sort of kilt or apron worn by males and females. [Maori] a sort of <i>kilt</i> or <i>apron</i> worn by males and females. (so Williams, 183) Maori, <i>maro</i>
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

Author:  STEVENSON
Vol / Page:  144
Edition:
Quote:  While I believe it to be a fragment of a maro, I admit that the identification is well open to question; indeed, without the knowledge of the Moriori maro it would have been rash to speculate on its original form.
Notes:

Date:  0/6/1946
