Author:
Vol / Page:  55/145
Edition:
Quote:  <i>maro</i>, finely-plaited apron: a fathom is ma[a]ro[o], but that word has never come into common use. (Definition in O.E.D. incomplete).

marooning party
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1777
Source:  Voyage Round the World
Author:  FORSTER
Vol / Page:  165
Edition:
Quote:  It may be curious to know the nature of our marooning parties, as the seamen called them. 1824 Southey 1856 Olmstead Slave States
Notes:

Date:  7/5/1773
Source:  Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The
Author:  FORSTER
Vol / Page:  2/270
Edition:
Quote:  We landed about 2, inorder [sic] to dress our dinner: ... We left the beach at five & went up this Arm, till it was quite dark: & then took up our Quarters for the Night, but as it is highly [271] improbable, for people that have not been at Sea & especially that have not frequented uncultivated Countries to form an Idea of the manner of living on a <i>marooning</i> party, to form an adquate Idea of these parties, we intend to give one here in this place. The first thing is to look out for a good place with a gentle beach with wood & a brook close to it. After landing everybody is busy to get dry wood, a necessary article in so wet a Country as New-Zeeland. [There follows a full description: roast food, grog, jollity and storytelling, etc]
Notes:

marriage celebrant
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a person authorised by law to solemnise a marriage.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim Cameron writes: Before 1976 these persons were called <i>officiating ministers</i>. (Marriage Act 1955 as amended). The use of the word "<i>solemnise</i>" is perhaps of interest; the legislation uses it also in relation to marriages by Registrars. It is not the usual secular term.

Marseille tile
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a burnt-clay roofing tile, commonly used esp. on bungalows and State House.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim writes: Introduced to NZ about 1901 and imported until 1924, after which they were made locally. See Salmond <i>Old NZ Houses</i> p 122 etc. An account of the development of the Marseilles tile roof in Australia is in Robin Boyd <i>Australia's Home</i> p. 151-153. Despite its European name and the original provenance of the tile, this term is not in British dictionaries I have seen. NSOD has only <i>Marseille ware</i> - a type of pottery produced in Marseilles during the 17th and 18th centuries. DEH adds: researching family geneology, I encountered a ship from Marseilles via Genoa to Sydney or NZ in 1909 from Marseille with a cargo of tiles. Many Kelburn houses have Marseilles tiles
Citations
Date:  1/2/2003
Source:  Dominion Post
Author:  F12
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  The tower is topped off with a belvedere ("beautiful sight"), roofed in Australian-made Marseille tiles, which match the bungalow's roof.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1979
Source:  SANZ Glossary Building Terminology
Author:
Vol / Page:  116
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Tile, marseilles</i> - Clay tile similar in form to those originally imported from Marseilles in the early part of the century. Burnt clay tiles are not often used in New Zealand construction.
Notes:

Date:  15/2/2003
Source:  Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  F16
Edition:
Quote:  Mrs Gibson had fallen in love with the cottage which, with its lavendar, Marseille tiles and bay window seemed reminiscent of writer Katherine Mansfield who spent summers in a bungalow a stone's throw away at the turn of the century.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  Old New Zealand
Author:  SALMOND
Vol / Page:  46
Edition:
Quote:  [Caption] The orange Marseille tiles are peculiar to the bungalows of Australasia... <i>Ibid.</i> 122 When Marseille tiles were introduced to New Zealand in about 1901, roofs took on a new colour and texture. The vivid terracotta-orange contrasted strongly with the drab red-oxide paint of iron roofs and the grey of slate.
Notes:

Vol / Page:  152
Edition:
Quote:  <i>MASCOT OF H.M.S. NEW ZEALAND, THE</i>: The Maori `Piu-piu,' or cloak of black and white strips of flax and feathers, and the carved greenstone amulet figure, ("Tiki") worn round the neck (similar to the old battle insignia of Maori chiefs) presented to the battleship

<i>New Zealand</i>. They were given by an old Maori Chief in 1913, with the injunction that they must always be worn when the ship was in action, the chief prophesying that they would keep the ship from harm. Both "Piu-piu' and `Tiki' were worn at the Battle of Jutland by the Captain - to the great satisfaction of the crew, who, it is told, before the battle began took special measures to find out that the Captain was actually wearing the ship's mascot. On another occasion, when an action seemed imminent, the <i>New Zealand</i> mascot was also worn. On that occasion, word was specially passed round the decks among the men - `It's all right, he's got 'em on!' The <i>New Zealand</i> at Jutland escaped with only one shell hit, and had no casualties. Writing home after Jutland an officer said: "This ship bore a charmed life and suffered to the smallest extent though we were right in it the whole time.'
Notes:

Quote:  He was a new chum just out from England, and we took a deal of notice of him at once, because he was the first masher we ever saw. He wore a curly brimmed hat and had curly brown hair, and dark-brown eyebrows that looked as if they were painted.. and he always carried a crutched stick in one hand and a pair of yellow gloves in the other, and he never came out without a flower in his buttonhole... All down our street, they called him "the beautiful mashah," and whenever he went by, we always used to say "Here comes the mashah, the beautifool mashah. Who wouldn' t be mashah? ''

Massey's Cossacks
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: (usu. pl., occas. ellipt. Cossack) a name given by their opponents to the mounted special constables recruited in 1913 to control strikers (see special n. 2 a); also (quot. 1993) occas. misapplied (or transferred) to the special constables recruited to control unemployed protesters in the Depression of the 1930s (see special n. 2 b).
Citations
Date:  0/0/1959
Source:  History of New Zealand
Author:  SINCLAIR
Vol / Page:  206
Edition:

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  NZ Parliamentary Debates
Author:
Vol / Page:  475 : 5161
Edition:
Quote:  I know that the Minister and his officials had considerable difficulty in drafting the Bill, and that there were many dissenting voices about whether there should be masters in the legal structure... The issue of masters being part of the judiciary is a major change. It introduces a new tier in the judicial structure between the district court judges and high court judges, although they would sit in the High Court and would have the authority to deal with interlocutory proceedings in that court.

Notes:

mat
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a Maori cloak often of woven flax (cf flax mat, maori mat) [Williams (313) 2. A garment made from undressed flax leaves]; an old word given by the Europeans to various Maori outer garments, or other coverings, that usually were, or appeared to be, flat pieces of woven material, mainly of New Zealand flax.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  11/10/1769
Source:  Cook's Journals
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/572
Edition:  1955
Quote:  The third sort of Ahou [cloak] seemed to be made of the Cloth Plant coarsely beat out or of a kind of narrow Sedge or course [sic] grass- ... the ends of the stuff of about a foot long were left out so as to form a thick covering layer over layer, and very much resembled what Seamen call thrum-Matts.
Notes:  1769 Oct 11 W.B. Monkhouse in 1955 Cook Journal I-572

Date:  31/3/1770
Source:  Cook's Journals
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/279
Edition:
Quote:   Their common clothing are very much like square thrum'd matts [sic] that are made of rope yarns &c. to lay at the doors or passages into houses to clean one[sic] shoes upon, these they tye [sic] round their necks the thrum'd side out and are generally large enough to cover the body as low as the knee; they are made with very little preparation of the broad glass plant before meantioned. <i>Ibid.</i> 2/740 Their Cloathing (both Men [and] Women) is a kind of matt or cloth made of silk grass or fine flax, curiously wove and tied about the shoulder that reaches to their knees ... [they] call it an <i>Ahow</i>, [fn <i>ahu</i>] and over it they have one of a coarser sort made of Grass well thrumbed with the same to keep out the wet which they call a Bugy Bugy. [fn] <i>pakepake</i> often made of undressed flax.
Notes:

Date:  15/8/1822
Source:  Letter
Author:  KING
Vol / Page:  254
Edition:  1934
Quote:  `August 15th. - When an husband dies the widow laments and lives in a small house called the aretaua (<i>Whare-taua</i>), making mats to wrap the corpse in when taken up again. She must not wet her fingers with her spittle while making the mats, called watu-tangi-knitting - crying (<i>Whatu-tangi</i>); the mat is called kakaho-wroimate, mat (of) tears, or bed-wet-with-tears-while-making (<i>Kakahu-roimata</i>), a mat of sorrow; a widow of Rangeehoo (Rangihoua) made two for her departed husband and one for herself.
Notes:  1822 Aug 15 John King in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 254

Vol / Page:  30
Edition:  1963
Quote:  Moyterra ... sent back two large Pigs, and a Cacahow [<i>kakahu</i>] mat, [fn below] in return to Col Arthur, and said he should report this to his People and Friends at the time he gave his Sharkatty or Harkatty [<i>hakari</i>], meaning a Feast, ... he covered himself with his Cacarhow or Native Cloak ... [1963 fn] The word `mat' is a marginal interpolation; below Markham gives the more accurate rendering, `cloak'. <i>Ibid.</i> 40 Cacahows are now getting very scarce and a Ki tuck-er [<i>kaitaka</i>] or Mat Cacahow, [with] ornamented borders, is rarely to be seen in the present day... [Natives] have no other Costume [than English blankets] except a mat which goes round the Middle nearly down to the Knees.

Date:  0/0/1866
Source:  Polynesia
Author:  ANGAS
Vol / Page:  155
Edition:
Quote:  Before the introduction of blankets, the clothing of the New Zealanders consisted entirely of garments manufactured from the fibres of the native flax. These garments, or `mats,' as they are generally termed, display great ingenuity and taste in their fabrication; the threads are interwoven longitudinally, with others placed crosswise, and every thread is carefully fastened at intervals of about half an inch.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1871
Source:  AJHR
Author:  MAIR

mat sugar
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1939
Source:  First White Boy Born in Otago
Author:  BEATTIE
Vol / Page:  97
Edition:
Quote:  Sugar] came in mats, the big ones weighing 180 lbs, and was often called `mat sugar'. This mat was native made, being a pleated plant, and was pretty well square. Outside this mat, and covering it, was a coarse bag called a soojee (or suji?) bag. A familiar saying of the early days was, `As rough as a soojee bag', and this saying was applied to both people and things. Up to 1863 I never saw sugar except in mats ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1873
Source:  Birds of New Zealand
Author:  BULLER
Vol / Page:  20
Edition:  1888 2nd edn 1/195
Quote:  [The morepork castings in the Canterbury Museum] are hard pellets, of an oval form, and of the size of a Sparrow's egg, composed chiefly of the hard elytra and heads of various coleopterous insects, among which I noticed particularly the shiny covering of the mata (<i>Feronia antarctica</i>), a handsome ground-beetle which is found on the Canterbury Plains, but does not occur in the North Island.

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  morr
Vol / Page:  289
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Matagory, n</i>.a prickly shrub of New Zealand, <i>Discaria toumatou</i>, Raoul.; also called <i>Wild Irishman</i> (q.v.). The Maori name is <i>Tumatakuru</i>, of which <i>Matagory</i>, with various spellings, is a corruption, much used by rabbiters and swagmen. The termination <i>gory</i> evidently arises by the law of Hobson-Jobson from the fact that the spikes draw blood.
Notes:

matagouri flat
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:

matai
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a native forest tree with hard timber and a tall straight trunk; [Maori matai] <i>Podocarpus spicatus</i>  a timber tree or its timber, black pine, mai

matai beer
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a sappy liquid exuded by matai trees, possibly fermented.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1900 Marlborough bushmen.
Citations
Date:  10/2/1921
Source:  Quick March
Author:
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:  I have frequently drunk the matai beer which gushes out of the centre of the tree.
Notes:

Date:  10/12/1920
Source:  Quick March
Author:
Vol / Page:  11
Edition:
Quote:  I dimly remember as a youngster in the days when the Forty-Mile Bush was still standing, such a drink as 'matai beer' was sometimes spoken of amongst bushmen.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1976
Source:  From the Beginning: chronicles of a county
Author:  KERR
Vol / Page:  294
Edition:
Quote:  In New Zealand, Maori men knew that cracks in the heart-wood of old matai trees often exude a liquid, matai beer, a stimulating drink that weary white bushmen later discovered.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1999
Source:  Maori & Alcohol
Author:  HUTT
Vol / Page:  14
Edition:
Quote:  Matai beer was described by a Taihape newspaper in 1912 as tasting "like used machine oil... When a deep swig is absorbed, one has all the sensations of having swallowed a lighted kerosene stove."
Notes:  see McKay <i>Puborama</i> 1961, p. 95

Date:  10/12/1920
Source:  Quick March
Author:
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:   ... I dimly remember as a youngster in the days when the Forty-Mile Bush was still standing, such a drink as `matai beer' was sometimes spoken of amongst bushmen. Apparently it was made from the sap of the matai tree, extracted by the simple process of boring an auger-hole in the trunk. ... Can any old-timer axeman give any information concerning this liquor.
Notes:

Date:  10/2/1921
Source:  Quick March
Author:
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:  When I was a boy I lived in Carterton, and that was in the 'sixties, when there was little else than bush there ... I have frequently drunk the matai beer which gushes out of the centre of the tree when the axemen get to the heart. The flavour varies, but always has something of the tang of resin about it, though it is not at all a bad drink. ... I never heard of this matai beer being intoxicating; ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1961
Source:  Puborama
Author:  MACKAY
Vol / Page:  95
Edition:
Quote:  In the rip-roaring times of the King Country, Matai beer was a favourite with those who were strong enough and tough enough to drink it. It went out of favour when `cruisers' for the various timber mills complained that much good yellow pine was being ruined through the number of deep axe cuts and even auger holes in the standing trees, made to let the potent juice run into waiting pannikins or buckets. The favourite recipe for this form of wood alcohol represented the addition of three or four cupsful of the sap to each gallon of `ordinary' liquid refreshment. That the resultant mixture had a pretty hefty kick to it may be judged from this description handed in to the Taihape newspaper (1912): `Matai beer is the term used to describe a certain brand or grade of alcoholic brew. It may be identified easily. It smells like an ancient bar room the morning after. It tastes like used machine oil, only a very low grade of machine oil.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  Speaking for Ourselves
Author:  OWEN & PERKINS
Vol / Page:  65
Edition:
Quote:  But [bushmen] used to make concoctions of their own, and the most popular ... was matai beer. ... When you felled a big matai, a really mature black pine ... you would see the main artery in the heart of the tree gushing out the life liquid. ... It wasn't the sap; this was not related to that. It was a pure clear liquid, and it gushed out like the main artery gushing blood. But that used to be prized, and it would be caught in a billy. That was really something. It was beautiful and cool and sweet to drink as it was, but some of the blokes used to bung in maybe a handful of raisins and sugar and cork her up and let her ferment, and whether that fluid had any other properties in it or not I don't know, but you could get quite a potent drink from it.
Notes:   (Bob Edwards, bushman)

Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Maori Food and Cookery
Author:  FULLER
Vol / Page:  83
Edition:
Quote:  MATAI BEER [title] I have been told by old bushmen and Maoris about making beer from the sap of the matai tree ... Apparently when the tree was being cut down the watery sap was collected, more water was added and also some ordinary beer, or yeast. It was left to ferment and was reputed to be quite strong though I have not been able to find any written evidence of this.
Notes:

Notes:

Date:  16/9/2005
Source:  NZ Herald
Author:
Vol / Page:  A11
Edition:
Quote:  Last month Parliament declared the coastline from Whirinaki to 28km north a "mataitai" - a reserve that recognises and provides for customary food-gathering by Maori in areas special to tangata whenua. ... The mataitai off Whirinaki is known as "Moremore". ... Mataitai were introduced as part of the Treaty of Waitangi (Fisheries Claims) Settlement Act 1992 to provide a tool for Maori to manage all non-commercial fishing grounds. ... Rock Lobster Council chief Dary Sykes said Moremore was the first mataitai to affect commercial fishing. ... Between 78 tonnes and 105 tonnes of seafood a season came from the Kirakau area and mataitai could result in $2 million lost income.
Notes:

Vol / Page:  3

Author:  8/30
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  `Matamoe' is the term used by Wellington Maoris to refer to the adult <i>Anguilla australis;</i> but the three stages of growth are also known. The first stage, called `hao,' or `tuna heke,' is a small silver-bellied eel ... It is common in swamps and is sometimes called `swamp-eel' by settlers. The second stage is called `tahu' ...
Notes:  (Phillipps)

Matariki

Sense Number:

Origin: [none]

Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim writes: now an occasional celebration by urban as well as rural Maori. Known to me from posters etc. Not in DNZE.

Date:  12/7/2003

Vol / Page:  9

It did not occur to me that this might be misconstrued as a suggestion that Maori had been celebrating Matariki here for millennia.

Notes:

Date:  0/8/2001

Quote:  Towards the end of May each year the constellation Matariki, also known as the Pleiades, rises on the north-east horizon around half an hour before dawn.
Notes:

Date:  14/6/2001
Source:  City Voice
Author:
Vol / Page:  4
Edition:
Quote:  [Hdg] Matariki celebrations continue at Te Papa... In the last week of May, the star cluster Matariki, or Pleiades, appears in our dawn sky. For most iwi, the Maori New year begins with the first new moon after the appearance of Matariki.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1992
Source:  Fence Around the Cuckoo
Author:  PARK
Vol / Page:  70
Edition:
Quote:  At Te Kuiti I never saw the Pleiades because of the hills. Years afterwards, when I lived on the broad plains, I saw that heliacal rising, a handful of sparks on the horizon, until the sun blew them out. Mr Tawhai called them Te Matariki.
Notes:

Date:  7/6/2003
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  But what is Matariki and why has this ancient tradition, which hasn't been much practised by

Maori for the past 150 years, suddenly taken off again? Matariki is the Maori name for the beautiful little cluster of stars that is commonly known as the Pleiades or the Seven Sisters, Roughly translated, it means "little-eyes".... At the end of May, Matariki reappears in the morning sky, rising just before dawn... So Matariki is linked to the universal celebration of midwinter. It's the antipodean equivalent of the Scots' hogmanay or the Chinese New Year - in fact it has traditions that go back further than the Roman Saturnalia.
Notes:

matata
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a small bird associated with bracken-fern and raupo swamp. [Maori matata[a's-macron]]; also called fernbird, swamp-sparrow; <i>Bowdleria punctata</i>, fern-bird,, grass bird (also Chatham, North, Snares, South Island fernbird) fern-bird. = ko[o]ta[a]ta[a].:


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]

Pronunciation:

Date:  15/3/1842
Source:  Journal of Ensign Best
Author:
Vol / Page:  335
Edition:  1966
Quote:  A Mauri brought me two specimens of the Matata a small bird which lives in swamps.

[ed fn 1966] Matata or fern bird (<i>Bowdleia punctata</i>), a small bird of limited flight, brownish red above and white beneath, speckled with black. It is now rare as many of the swamps, its home, have been drained.

Date:  0/0/1859

Vol / Page:  1/25

Quote:   The family <i>Luscinidae </i>has five species. The Matata, a small low-flying bird with a shrill cry, and the Riro or wren, the smallest bird in New Zealand, are the only species worthy of notice. The Matata has four long and four short tail feathers, similar in texture to those of the Kiwi.

[284] Thirty years ago it was one of the most common species that affected the open country about Rockwood in the Malvern district; the lads called it `utick' from its note.

Vol / Page:  16
Edition:
Quote:  Other well-known [drinking] games are Hokonui Swindle, Bottles, Fluffy Ducks, Bunnies are Hovering, Cardinal Huff, All Blacks, Matches, and The Amazing Grimaldi Brothers. All these games involve either a complicated intellectual exercise, tongue twisters, mathematical calculations or aerobatics in a confined space; High Candelabras for example, involves intoxicated individuals attempting to traverse the four walls of a room without touching the floor.

matchhead
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Kolstad says there was an entry of "matchhead moss" <i> Cladonia cristatella</i>) written but not included in Vol.3 of Dictionary of American Regional English. Kerry Carman (Sep. 2000) writes : This is a very localised Southland/Otago colloquialism for the Grape Hyacinth <i>Muscari armeniacum</i>. The only literary reference I can give you, apart from Frame, is from Invercargill writer Olive Dunn's <i>Delights of Colour in a New Zealand Garden </i>p. 16. Other Southern writers such as Essie Summers also use the term I am told but I can not supply a reference. The origin remains a mystery but it may stem from the old blue topped wax Vesta matches. Dianne Bardsley says she knew the term well from the Wairarapa, but it is not known in Taranaki.
Citations
Date:  0/0/1976
Source:  Gold of Noon, The
Author:  SUMMERS
Vol / Page:  142
Edition:
Quote:  Matchheads formed a solid blue edge to the border.
Notes:

Date:  9/12/2000

Vol / Page:  45
Edition:
Quote:  Matchheads could stem from the old blue-topped wax Vesta matches - which were once widely known in the area.

Quote:  One man exclaimed So help me there lies the finest horse that ever crossed the Terahmacow and all echoed him. Another said Matey never own a good horse, another said, Justly you might as well tell an overlander to drown himself at once as ride a bad horse ... Half the township would have shouted for me if I would have drank ... and I was asked all down the river if I was the man that lost a fine horse saying Well mate, I am sorry for you. Fate.

Vol / Page:  40
Edition:  1962
Quote:  Mr George Munroe - referred to in Mr. Gillies' letter - is still residing in the Tuapeka District, and in response to my inquiries he has favoured me with an interesting account of Gabriel Read's first appearance on the scene:- ... `It was in June, 1861, that Read came, and I met him at the foot of what is now called Munroe's Gully, when he accosted me, saying - `Can you tell me, mate, where Black Peter was working?' I gave him the information required, and asked him to come and stay with me for the night, which he did. ... He found it there the next day. I came upon him working in the creek, when he sang out: `Hullo, mate! - I have got him.' And so he had. Both of us worked hard for a week or so, and got a few ounces with a tin dish. Read stayed with me during the time. He wanted me go `mates' with him and find him in `tucker', and we would keep it quiet for a few months;

mate
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 4
Definition:  one whose loyalty one can depend on often used instead of PAL, etc.; often refers to a faithful friendship between two men, and the term then implies loyalty of the most constant kind; a term essential to the Australian and New Zealand vocabulary -

mate
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a) a habitual companion or fellow worker: `my mate and I worked the shearing sheds around here for almost 30 years'. b) hence a common form of address (= friend). -->perhaps from early whalers and sailors, adopted by goldminers and early colonial labourers `partner and friend', developing into `friend'; and also, through a form of address, to `fellow; JOKER; SPORT'. (cf MATING vbl n.) [AND 1. a. equal partner in an enterprise 1838; b. go mates 1876 2. acquaintance, person engaged in the same activity 1841 3 ... a sworn friend 1891 4. a mode of address, often to a casual acquaintance 1843
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  18/4/1855
Source:  Lyttelton Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  6
Edition:
Quote:  He [McKenzie] stated that he had no mates with him, although traces of other men could be seen... After talking with him ... the dogs began to ko-hi. Upon being questioned what he [McKenzie] was kohi-'ng for, he stated that `they were his mates,' but witness was not to be afraid, they would not hurt him.

mate Maori
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: Maori sickness
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Some Modern Maoris
Author:  BEAGLEHOLE
Vol / Page:  219
Edition:
Quote:   The sign most often taken to indicate this sort of sickness is that the sickness does not appear to be yielding readily to ordinary Maori or to pakeha methods of treatment. It is then considered to be a Maori sickness - a `mate Maori' as the phrase is commonly used - and for sure, safe, and quick results, treatment should be referred to a Maori expert, a tohunga, either male or female, who will use a combination of religious prayer, seance-possession, and magic to restore the sick person to health.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1963
Source:  Ratana
Author:  HENDERSON
Vol / Page:  9
Edition:  1972
Quote:  To break the law of<i> tapu</i> was to die of <i>mate Maori</i>, the sickness caused by an uneasy Maori conscience or the influx of demons.
Notes:

Date:  0/5/1987
Source:  Metro
Author:
Vol / Page:  100
Edition:
Quote:   If a Maori is genuinely disturbed, in Maori terms, the answer again is to restore their mauri (life force), as for physical illness. This is particularly true for <i>mate</i> Maori, Maori sickness, which arises from spiritual and social causes, not physical ones (Pakehas would call it psychosomatic).
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1979
Source:  Mihaia
Author:  BINNEY et al.
Vol / Page:  25
Edition:
Quote:  Inexplicable sickness, <i>mate Maori</i>, is often attributed to evil forces living in the human body; their extraction, possible only by faith in the healer, is a major part of the role of a tohunga.
Notes:

Date:  13/4/1986
Source:  NZ Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  3
Edition:
Quote:   Her son had refused to go to hospital for treatment of his mental condition, after an earlier visit to a local doctor. It has been revealed the youth was angry over such things as social and political issues in New Zealand and South Africa, as well as the nuclear issue. There is a suggestion that the youth also suffered from a form of spiritual illness, called mate Maori. The youth had been to see a Maori spiritual healer, a tohunga, but his mother said tapu forbids her from discussing his diagnosis.
Notes:

Date:  10/3/2007
Source:  Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  A1
Edition:
Quote:  In 2000, Tariana Turia, who was then associate Maori affairs minister [sic], questioned whether psychologists had the appropriate training to deal with issues such as Maori sickness (mate Maori). Victoria University's head of Maori studies [sic], Peter Adds, said mate Maori was a fairly common condition.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1980
Source:  Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A
Author:  LELAND
Vol / Page:  64
Edition:
Quote:  <i>mates rates</i>: If you happen to be a plumber, storekeeper, paperhanger, etc. Mates rates is what you charge your friends, considerably DISCOUNTED from what you charge the general public.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Collins Concise English Dictionary
Author:
Vol / Page:  696
Edition:
Quote:  <i>mate's rates</i> pl. <i>n. N.Z. inf</i>. discounted or preferential rates of payment offered to a friend or colleague (esp. in <i>at mate's rates): he got the job done cheaply by

a plumber friend at mate's rates. </i>
Notes:  [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 302]

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  72
Edition:
Quote:  <i>mate's rates</i> payment that may not involve tha Inland Revenue department, usually for trade work, not necessarily involving mates; eg `I can work on your boat weekends. Strictly cash. Mate's rates, eh?'
Notes:

Date:  27/2/1988
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  65
Edition:
Quote:  First there are those New Zealand words [in Collins English Dictionary, 2nd ed.] ... for example, ... <i>solo mother, walk socks</i> (but not <i>walk shorts</i>),<i> block, kiwi</i> (as in Golden Kiwi), <i>mate's rates, ... Maori Warden. </i>
Notes:  (G. Kennedy)

Author:
Vol / Page:  179
Edition:  1950
Quote:  One man exclaimed So help me there lies the finest horse that ever crossed the Terahmacow and all echoed him. Another said Matey never own a good horse, another said, Justly you might as well tell an overlander to drown himself at once as ride a bad horse ... Half the township would have shouted for me if I would have drank ... and I was asked all down the river if I was the man that lost a fine horse saying Well mate, I am sorry for you. Fate.

The friendliness of it, the - the - Just to prove how happy she was, just to show the tall fellow at home how she felt, and how she despised stupid conventions, Laura took a big bite of her bread-and-butter ... She felt just like a work-girl.

matipo
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: red matipo, mapau


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1853
Source:  Flora NZ
Author:  HOOKER
Vol / Page:  I Flowering Plants 172
Edition:
Quote:  Suttonia <i>australis</i>, A.Rich. ... Nat. names, `Mapau', `Sipau', and `Matipo', Middle Island, <i>Lyall</i>. `Tipau', north of the Thames river, and `Mapua', south of that river,

<i>Colenso</i>. ... A small leafy tree, very closely resembling <i>Pittosporum undulatum</i> in appearance.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1867
Source:  Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names)
Author:  HOOKER
Vol / Page:  766
Edition:
Quote:  Matipo, Middle Island, <i>Lyall. Myrsine Urvillei. </i>
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1907
Source:  Plants of NZ
Author:  LAING & BLACKWELL
Vol / Page:  332
Edition:  1940 p. 353
Quote:  <i> [Suttonia australis (The Red Matipo)</i>] ... Native name <i>Mapau, Mapou,</i> or <i>

Matipo</i>. The name Matipo is generally applied by Europeans to <i>Pittosporum tenuifolium,</i> but this is apparently the plant to which the Maoris attached it. This tree bears some resemblance to <i>Pittosporum tenuifolium,</i> but can be readily distinguished by the reddish colour of the leaves. [<i>Rapanea Urvillei</i>, 1907]
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1940
Source:  Plants of NZ
Author:  LAING & BLACKWELL
Vol / Page:  199
Edition:
Quote:  This species is largely used for the formation of ornamental hedges and is then called the `Matipo.' This is a misomer, as the Maories apparently applied this name to a species of <i>Suttonia. P. Tenuifolium</i> was called by them the <i>Tawhiwhi </i>or <i>Kohuhu.</i>
Notes:

Date:  0/6/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:  ANDERSEN
Vol / Page:  55/153
Edition:
Quote:  <i>matipou</i>, a tree (Myrsine Urvillei), commonly mispronounced matipo, the `o' with the non-Maori sound of the English diphthongal `o'; the Maori `o' is the sound of `awe' or matapo: the Maori shortening of he word is mapou.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
Author:  McLINTOCK
Vol / Page:  3/705-712
Edition:
Quote:  Red matipo .. .. matipo .. .. <i>Myrsine australis </i>

Author:
Vol / Page:  2/8
Edition:
Quote:  Sir, - Your gardening correspondent (September 21) recommends two native trees which he calls `Lemon Matipo' and `Black-stemmed Matipo'.... The only true Matipo has red stems and is also named Mapou (Myrsine australis). Pittosporum eugenioides I have always known as Lemonwood or Tarata; P. Tenuifolium is properly called Kohuhu.

Sea perch are similar in shape and appearance to the scorpion fish but have smoother heads ... It is a deep water species ... more common to the south of Cook Strait. ... In deep southern waters sea perch are a fairly uniform pale yellow-brown with a white belly and further work may show this to be a separate species.

Author:  McLINTOCK
Vol / Page:
Edition:  3/689
Quote:  In addition to the rock wren, there is another species, <i>Xenicus longiceps</i>, the bush wren or matuhi. This bird is also very small, of darker green colouring and with a white throat. It is found in damp rimu and beech forests on the West Coast of the South Island, and builds its nest in hollow trees and, like the rock wren, lines it with feathers.

matuka
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: possibly for matuku, bittern; no Maori word <i>matuka.</i>


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Fisherman's Bible
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  83
Edition:
Quote:  The fact that large, wet flies tied in a particular way to imitate small fish are known by three different names causes a lot of confusion. In America, England and elsewhere they are called `streamer' flies; in New Zealand they are called `matukas'; in Australia, `longtails'. As patterns from all three countries are used here, the confusion can be understood. If the angler remembers why each name is used, the confusion disappears. ... / The word `matuka', as used for the New Zealand patterns, is the name of a bird (now protected) whose feathers were first used to tie this kind of wet fly.
Notes:

Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/153
Edition:
Quote:  matuku, two birds, 1, Botaurus poeciloptilus, bittern, and 2, Demigretta sacra, blue-heron; the Maori distinguished these two according to their habitat: 1, matuku-hurepo (swamp matuku) and 2, matuku-moana (sea-matuku). When the Pakeha mentions the matuku he always refers to the bittern; the other he always calls blue-heron.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Date:  31/1/1770
Source:  Cook's Journals

There is a smaller species of bittern, a blue heron, and possibly others of the family, all known under the common name of matuku.

Date:  0/0/1926
Source:  Weeds of New Zealand
Author:  HILGENDORF
Vol / Page:  61
Edition:  1967, p. 61
Quote:  WIREWEED (<i>Polygonum aviculare</i>), also called road weed, mat weed, knot grass, [pig weed,] and hog weed, is common in cultivated land all over the country. It is an annual, with stems up to 2ft. in length trailing over the ground. The stems have swollen nodes (`knot grass') and are very tough (`wireweed').

Quote:  <i>HYMENO PHYLLUM ... rarum</i> ... Filmy Fern. MAUKU (for all the filmy ferns).

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  NZ Medicinal Plants
Author:  BROOKER et al.
Vol / Page:  25
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Asplenium bulbiferum</i> Forst f. Common name: <i>Hen and chickens fern</i> Maori names: <i>Mauku, mouku</i> ... `Mauku' has been identified as <i>Asplenium bulbiferum, Cordyline pumilio, </i>and <i>Hymenophyllum</i> spp. by Williams and as <i>Asplenium bulbiferum</i> by Best. `Mouku' has been identified as <i>Asplenium bulbiferum</i> by Williams and as <i>Marattia salicina</i> by Tregear. <i>Asplenium bulbiferum </i>is a common fern throughout New Zealand forests.
Notes:

mauri
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: spirit; the life force or principle. [Maori]


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  3/10/2001
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  25
Edition:
Quote:  In a moving ceremony at the marae, it was granted back to the soldiers to carry the mauri (spirit) of their fallen comrades back to Tuahiwi.
Notes:

Date:  20/7/1936
Source:  Na To Hoa Aroha
Author:
Vol / Page:  3/227
Edition:
Quote:  No doubt the face presented by the ensemble of marae and camp organisation, ... together with the mauri of the meeting of diverse, scattered tribal elements, might be characterised as excellent ...
Notes:  (Ngata)

Date:  6/7/1983
Source:  Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page:  4
Edition:
Quote:  He also held the title of mauri, `life and soul' of those tribes and of the Ringatu Church.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1983
Source:  Bone People, The
Author:  HULME
Vol / Page:  468
Edition:
Quote:   374 Mauri/Mauriora = Life principle, thymos of humans; talisman or material symbol of that secret and mysterious principle protecting the mana (power/vitality) of people, birds, land, forests, whatever ... [sic]
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  Towards Taha Maori
Author:  HOWE
Vol / Page:  21
Edition:
Quote:  Mauri - ethos, life-force or principle, life-style, belief. This term applies to both animate an inanimate things. Houses, land, trees, forests, buildings, hills etc. can have a life-force of their own. So can the front (atea) of a marae, a speech, the kumara, or the taniwha of a river. Maoris strongly believe in mauri, and just as a life force may wax or wane depending on a person's health or status, so can his or her `mauri'. Lack of mauri can cause a person to die.
Notes:

Date:  0/5/1987
Source:  Metro
Author:
Vol / Page:  100
Edition:
Quote:  If a Maori is genuinely disturbed, in Maori terms, the answer again is to restore their mauri (life force), as for physical illness. This is particularly true for <i>mate</i> Maori, Maori sickness, which arises from spiritual and social causes, not physical ones (Pakehas would call it psychosomatic).
Notes:


Date:  0/7/1910
Source:  Kai Tiaki
Author:
Vol / Page:  104
Edition:
Quote:  The mind of every Maori is well stored with those different `karakia' ... to protect the life principle (Mauri) of man.

may
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: OED, <i>Crataegus Oxyacantha</i> blossoms of the hawthorn; hence occas the tree itself : so called becouse it blooms in the mouth of May. The word is inappropriate to NZ seasons, so

<i>hawthorn</i> is used exclusively. <i>Hawthorn</i> bushes themselves are relatively uncommon, and the term is often (mistakenly) extended to include <i>barberry. </i>


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

They're the ones with bullet-points on their Christmas cards" - and the suspicion that for graduates from some courses, the words MBA stand for Medicore But Arrogant, it's less clear from the failings of companies such as Air New Zealand and Brierley Investments that corporate performance in New Zealand has to improve if the country is ever to achieve its targeted four per cent growth.

Author:
Vol / Page:  23
Edition:
Quote:  Although bales now come in all shapes and sizes, the product inside is what counts. Quality is measured in the percentage of ME - metabolisable energy, which the cow can convert to milk solids .. It costs just as much to harvest low quality feed as good, and the cows need to eat more, so the cost is higher with a lower ME crop.

meal and water
Homonym Number:

See:

Citations
Date:  0/0/1967
Source:  Tang of The Bush
Author:  KEENE
Vol / Page:  107
Edition:
Quote:  Dipping was hot, thirsty work so we had frequent recourse to the meal and water, staple drink of farmers in the field. Ehtel [sic] made a very good brew; four tablespoons of oatmeal and a little water into a seven pound treacle billy where it was squeezed to a cream with the back of the spoon, and the billy filled water. Wherever we were working in hot weather the `meal 'n water' went too, hanging on the hames or packed on the sledge.

Quote:  Another description which I have heard him give is that the mower, or rather the forage harvester, is used as a 'mechanical cow.' To be fully utilised grass has to be eaten at its most nutritious stage and the idea of this 'mechanical cow' is that the herd is grazed over the pasture at its best stage, but when growth begins to outstrip the herd, the 'mechanical cow' - the forage harvester - is brought out and run out over these paddocks.

medical centre
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a group practice of two or more doctors, sometimes with specialist, ancillary or para-medical service.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim Cameron writes : See Yellow Pages. There are also places called <i>Health Centres</i>. The definition of a health centre in NSOD and Collins, is premises owned by a local authority providing health care, usually housing a group practice, nursing staff, etc. premises. OED defines it as a local centre for a group practice. It seems to be used loosely in NZ, sometimes simply as a variant of medical centre, sometimes in relation to para-medical services eg <i>Chiropractic Health Centre</i>. Medical centre is not in any dictionary. But see use in Ruth Rendell <i>Harm Done</i>. [medical centre is given as illustr. at medical in ODE - TD]
Citations
Date:  0/0/2000
Source:  Kokopu Dreams
Author:  BAKER
Vol / Page:  122
Edition:
Quote:  George, a GP who had lived through the fever and as soon as he could had moved back home from Taupo where he'd been a partner in a medical centre, wouldn't let Sean get up.
Notes:

meeting house
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a Maori meeting house: the concept is post-European: distinguish from earlier CARVED HOUSE, which often seemed to be a chiefly dwelling or used for a special purpose: check Cook etc. call them CHIEF'S HOUSES


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1873
Source:  Wonderland of the Antipodes
Author:  TINNE
Vol / Page:  9
Edition:
Quote:   ... enjoying dry ... quarters at the great `whare-puna', or meeting-house, of the tribe.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1973
Source:  Brown Man's Burden
Author:  FINLAYSON
Vol / Page:  135
Edition:
Quote:  8. `the meeting-house'. Meeting houses have often been the focus of community effort and pride. They are long halls used for meetings and for the accommodation of visitors. They have a verandah at the entrance with a carved gabled front and are richly decorated inside, with patterned reed panels, with black and white painted scrolls on the rafters, and with carvings or paintings of ancestors and incidents in the mythological history of the people on whose marae the meeting-house is built. Supporting the ridge-pole is a centre-post on which are figures of ancestors. The floor is often covered with flax matting, and visitors take off their shoes before entering. Another meeting house is described in the first part of `Hemi's Daughter'.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  Speaking for Ourselves
Author:  OWEN & PERKINS
Vol / Page:  109
Edition:
Quote:  In those days [c1890s] they had what was known as the `Maori wedding', which was not legal to the Pakeha, but was a binding thing among the Maori people themselves. A young couple would decide that they wanted to become man and wife, and they would have to tell their parents they wanted this. Well, at night-time everyone would congregate in the meetinghouse [the matter would be discussed, the boy and girl would be asked whether they wanted to marry, and they would take each other in front of all their people].
Notes:  (Florence Harsant, Taupo)

Date:  22/11/1988

Author:
Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:  Wood used for carving and building carries with it the spirit of the tree, the spirit of place including the name of the place, and the spirit of the carvers who create the powerful images of tribal ancestors which decorate wharenui (meeting houses). ... Anyone who has spent time in a carved house (wharenui) will know the depth of feeling the carvings evoke, for they make the wharenui a living thing.

megaherb
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a large herb
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/3/2003
Source:  NZ Geographic
Author:
Vol / Page:  62/62
Edition:
Quote:  Megaherbs, the flamboyant flowering plants for which New Zealand's offshore islands are well known, are represented by just one species on the Snares: the large-leaved punui, <i>Stilbocarpa robusta</i>)...
Notes:

Date:  0/6/1999
Source:  NZ Journal of Botany
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Evolution of <i>Stilbocarpa</i>. a megaherb from New Zealand's sub-antarctic islands... The humid climate, cool equable temperatures, locally abundant nutrients, and absence of herbivores are ecological features of the sub-antarctic islands that may have contributed to the evolution of the unusual megaherb, <i>Stilbocarpa</i>, from these diminutive apiaceous ancestors.
Notes:  Paper by Mitchell, Meurk & Wagstaff

Date:  0/0/2003
Source:  Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Megaherb describes certain plant species that grow on the Sub-antarctic Islands of New Zealand. They are usually quite colourful and have large leaves considering their native environment. These species have adapted very well to growing in a harsh environment but have become so specialised they are dificult to grow elsewhere. <i>Anisotome latifolia</i> is an example of one of these megaherbs.
Notes:  Http://davesgarden.com

Date:  0/0/2002
Source:  Campbell Island: Land of the Blue Sunflower
Author:  FELL
Vol / Page:  54
Edition:
Quote:  The name 'megaherb' was coined by Britain's Sir James Clark Ross during his 1839-43 Antarctic voyage, accoppanied by a botanist from Kew Gardens, Sir Joseph Hooker, whose name is honoured by the Hooker sea lion.
Notes:

Date:  0/9/2002
Source:  NZ Geographic

Vol / Page:  No. 59/58

Quote:  The large-leafed megaherb punui.. is a feature of the southern islands, including Whenua Hou.

Quote:  <i>Caulopsetta scapha</i> Forster. This species referred to as the `brill' in my former list, is a totally different fish. This specific name belongs to the megrim, or witch, a common form, not sold as a food fish on account of its lean, bony character.

Vol / Page:  4/121
Edition:
Quote:  CAULOPSETTA SCAPHA (Forster). Megrim. Known as `witch' or `lantern-fish' at Napier. Taken by trawlers in sandy localities as far north as Hauraki Gulf. Not popular as a food fish. ... Distribution: New Zealand coasts (unknown North Auckland Peninsula).

All are excellent food fish-again with the exception of the megrim, once dubbed `cadgers' - fish' because of its suitability for palming off on those who hover round landing fishing-craft in the hope of perks, especially flatfish. <i>Ibid.</i> 218 [Caption] Fig. 66: FLATFISHES. I. <i>Turbot.</i> 2. Brill;(<i>both </i>Colisteum <i>spp</i>). 3. Flounder, <i>Rhombosolea</i>. 4. Sole, <i>Peltorhamphus</i>. 5. Megrim or witch, <i>Caulopsetta</i> (eyes left!). 6. Lemon sole, <i>Pelotretis. </i>

In Napier it is known as Lantern-fish, but for what reason I am unable to say, unless it is from the peculiar transparency when it/is held up to a strong light. Another name given to this useless fish by local fishermen, in Port Chalmers at least, was that of Cadger's-fish.

Notes:

Date:  4/11/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Men's hut</i>: House where the station hands live. On some stations it is called the <i>station house</i>, and now often the <i>whare</i>, which word was, I suppose, brought from the North Island stations. Originally the men cooked, ate, and slept in a one-roomed hut, with a fireplace and colonial oven at one end and bunks in two or three tiers round the walls. Nowadays most <i>m. hs.</i> are reasonably comfortable houses with separate rooms. ([1898 Morris Austral-English], under <i>hut</i>)
Notes:  Acland Glossary

MEPS
Homonym Number:
Word Class: abbreviation
Sense Number:
Definition: Minimum Energy Performance Standards
Origin: acronym
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: aka E3; Joint NZ-Aust governments' initiative for energy efficiency
Citations
Date:  0/0/2010
Source:  Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Motors from 185 kW up to and including 265 kW will only be accepted into the scheme when the efficiency of the replacement motor meets or exceeds the MEPS 2006 level for 185 kW motors.
Notes:  http://www.motorbounty.co.nz/criteria.htm

Date:  0/0/2010
Source:  Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  New Zealand works with Australia on a joint programme called the Equipment Energy Efficiency (E3) Programme. The E3 programme develops energy efficiency measures for a range of residential, commercial, and industrial products which economic and environmental benefits to consumers and businesses. The E3 allows both countries to honour their commitments under the Trans-Tasman Mutual Recognition Arrangement (TTMRA).
Notes:  http://www.eeca.govt.nz/standards-and-ratings/minimum-energy-performance-standards-and-labelling

Date:  17/6/2008
Source:  Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Will I have to replace all my light bulbs once the MEPS come into effect?

No. The MEPS is intended to stop the product being sold, but does not affect those already in use.
Notes:  http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PA0806/S00228.htm

Date:  12/5/2010
Source:  Horowhenua Chronicle
Author:
Vol / Page:  5
Edition:
Quote:  New Minimum Energy Performance Standards (MEPS) came into effect 1 April 2010.   The New Zealand and Australian governments have a joint task force to help us to become more energy efficient.

Date:  0/0/1889

Author:  McKAY
Vol / Page:  16
Edition:
Quote:
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  290
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Mere</i>, (pronounced <i>merry</i>), a Maori war-club; a <i>casse-tete</i>, or a war-axe, from a foot to eighteen inches in length, and made of any suitable hard material - stone, hard wood, whale-bone. To many people out of New Zealand the word is only known as the name of a little trinket of <i>greenstone</i> (q.v.) made in imitation of the New Zealand weapon in miniature, mounted in gold or silver, and used as a brooch, locket, ear-ring, or other article of jewelry.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1830
Source:  Poems (various authors)
Author:  LANG
Vol / Page:  116
Edition:  1873
Quote:  `Beneath his shaggy flaxen mat/ The dreadful marree hangs concealed.'

Quote:  I had an instance to-day of the great value the natives sometimes set on their ornaments of green stone maries (meri), as the whites call them.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/153
Edition:
Quote:  <i>mere</i>, battledore-shaped weapon of greenstone; a most valued weapon, both to Maori user and Pakeha collector. A very commonly-used word, and almost invariably mispronounced like Mary; but both vowels have the same sound, as in mere(tricious) or in the proper name Mere(dith).
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Edition:
Quote:  These [skate's] eggs are passed off in horny, oblong capsules and are known to fishermen and others as Skate Barrows, Sailors' Purses, Mermaid's Purses and Mermaid's Pinboxes, and are often picked up on the shore after storms. Each capsule contains one egg. The shape is like a miniature pillow, with four horns (one at each corner).

Date:  29/8/1987
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  44
Edition:
Quote:  Aunt Mag had a nasty habit of asking you to go to the grocer's or the butcher's on some message or other, just when you were planning to do something quite different.
Notes:  (Davin)

Date:  0/0/1960
Source:  Tangahano
Author:  KEINZLY
Vol / Page:  33
Edition:
Quote:  Under the shop verandahs young boys and girls scorched golden by the heat paraded for each other, and pakeha and Maori children ambled home with their messages and change, wonderfully cool in the shade of slabs of coloured ice on sticks.
Notes:  Jim Cameron says <i>run/go messages</i> is recorded in DNZE but (as a citation shows) phrase and meaning are slightly wider than the definition there, comprehending the shopping itself and what is obtained... Whatever its initial NZ currency the phrase is general NZE and not special to Southland as sometimes suggested.

Date:  6/3/1972
Source:  Tapanui Courier
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  [Hdg] A Tapanui reader has sent me a recent issue of the local Courier, drawing my attention to two `Past Events' items. ... a paragraph about tote betting back in 1896, where it was stated that those attending the Tuapeka races `saw the splendid business done by several metallicians'. It's a new word to me ... [entry from <i>Oxford English Dictionary</i> [John Roberts, Box 962, Dunedin] metallician 1.<i>Racing slang.</i> A bookmaker ...

1874 <i>Notten's Slang Dict. Metallician</i>, a racing bookmaker. Bookmakers use metallic books and pencils. 1887 Daily Tel. 12 Mar. 5/2 In Australia the bookmaker has to pay dearly ... As for the long-suffering Australian public, they are mulcted as heavily as the much-taxed metallician.]
Notes:  Old Slang?

Mick
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the tail of coin (in two-up)
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1938
Source:  With the Cameliers in Palestine
Author:
Vol / Page:  198
Edition:
Quote:  The New Zealanders are very religious men. Their priests lead them out to a quiet spot where they can pray. The priest spreads out a holy mat with marks on it which means something they have great faith in. He kneels down beside the mat, then a row of worshippers kneel all round him, with another row bending over them, and another row standing behind them. The worshippers throw their offerings on to the holy mat, and the priest places two coins on a short piece of polished wood which he calls a kip, and raising his eyes to the sky, he throws up the coins as an offering to Allah. All the worshippers raise their eyes also to the sky, and then bow solemnly over the mat, and say together, `God Almighty', and the priest answers, `A pair of Micks', which means that the offerings are not accepted, or he may say, `Oh Lord, he has done 'em again', and the joyful cries of some of the worshippers show that Allah is pleased, and so they, too, are glad.
Notes:

micron creep
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a change in records of fleecewool core size [often due to imprecise measurement.]


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/2002
Source:  Wool Grower
Author:
Vol / Page:  Spring 26
Edition:
Quote:  The phenomenon [of wool core becoming coarser on testing] has been noted by farmers using all forms of fleece testing, and has been commonly refered to as 'micron creep' or 'diameter shrinkage.' Micron creep occurs when fleeces which have been objectively tested are lotted into discreet micron bins. The actual cause of micron creep is imprecision of the measurement.
Notes:

For three years the Export Institute wrestled with the concept of a new national emblem which would uniquely identify New Zealand goods and services.

mike
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: ? scrounge; bludge; ?loaf; a scrounge; a nap; hence to have a mickey (mostly Army) 1948
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: [? Les Cleveland's or P note:] `I haven't found anybody who has heard this usage in N.Z. after this 1939 occurrence.' L.C. notes: <i>Micky's Broken Doll</i>, a 1939 N.Z. adaptation of <i>Aussies Broken Doll,</i> a WWI song probably from A.I.F. micky = Mick Savage [? <i>mike</i> a play on Michael Savage] Part: <i>Dict of Force Slang </i>1948 cites <i>Mike</i>. A scrounge, a nap; hence to have a mike [mostly army] <i>Miker. </i>A work-shy L.C. notes: <i>Micky's Broken Doll</i>, a 1939 N.Z. adaptation of <i>Aussies Broken Doll,</i> a WWI song probably from A.I.F. micky = Mick Savage [? <i>mike</i> a play on Michael Savage] Part: <i>Dict of Force Slang </i>1948 cites <i>Mike</i>. A scrounge, a nap; hence to have a mike [mostly army] <i>Miker. </i>A work-shy

miki-miki
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: mingimingi; usually <i>Cyathodes acerosa (C. juniperina, </i>Williams) or <i>Coprosma </i>spp., esp. <i>C. propinqua, C. linarifolia</i>, a thorny shrub. [|Cyathodes <i>have prickles</i>; Coprosmas <i>not: ?separate out on that characteristic: whether Cyathodes or Coprosma: also note that Leucopogon now - Cyathodes] </i>
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

milk bar

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  University Entrance English
Author:
Vol / Page:  3
Edition:
Quote:  milkbar (forerunner of dairy with more limited stock) <i>Ibid.</i>6
Notes:  Once when she couldn't have me Dad let me go to the flicks by myself. He gave me some extra money, so I went to the milkbar and bought a gobstopper and some other lollies. I stuffed my face, and felt crook all the way home. He bought new footy boots for my eldest brother too, and an Art Union ticket for Mum. He must have had a beaut time up the RSA that day, I reckon.

Source:  Street Society in Christchurch
Author:  CROWTHER
Vol / Page:  1
Edition:
Quote:  During the early months of this year [1956] much publicity was given in the Christchurch newspapers to the fact that large numbers of young people were to be seen, especially at the weekends, in the central areas of the city. These young people congregated in the streets and milk-bars. Many of them had motor-cycles ... At various times these young people were referred to as `Teddy Boys', `Milk Bar Cowboys' and `Bodgies and Widgies'.

milk thistle
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: not necessaarily NZ exclusive
Citations
Date:  0/0/1841
Source:  Rambles in NZ
Author:  BIDWILL
Vol / Page:  51
Edition:  1952
Quote:  The natives had a large copper mowrie to cook the pork they had brought with them, and for the first time I saw them eat the common milk-[52]thistle. They cook it as constantly as the leaves of the wild turnip and cabbage, and seem to relish it just as much. It is so precisely like the English milk-thistle that I am almost inclined to think it must have come with the potatoes.
Notes:

Date:  16/8/1844
Source:  Diary
Author:  TUCKETT
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  ... the prevailing species of trees are remo [rimu], totara, and tall manuka, all indicative of inferior soil.... The bush-like woods on the east side are of white birch, likewise no recommendation of the soil, but the chief objection to the district is, that the prairie soil affords scarcely any food for cattle ... it grows only the wiry tree grass [tussock] ... and

<i>Phormium tenax</i> [flax], no aniseed, perennial groundsel, or milk thistle, and very little couch grass.
Notes:  1844 Aug 16 Tuckett's Diary in 1898 Hocken contributions 223-224



Date:  0/0/1869
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/III/30-31
Edition:
Quote:  The Puwha, or [31] Milk-thistle (<i>Sonchus oleraceus</i>), the large-leaved variety was common, though not (it is reasonably suspected) too plentiful; and this was abandoned for the smaller-leaved European kind (after its introduction) as being less bitter and more palatable.
Notes:  (Colenso Botany North Isd)

Date:  0/0/1969

Author:
Vol / Page:  78
Edition:
Quote:  MILK THISTLE (<i>Silybum marianum</i>), sometimes called St. Mary's thistle, variegated or spotted thistle, and, near Akaroa, French thistle ... . It is abundant in scattered localities in both islands, sometimes forming dense masses. It is an annual or biennial, grows up to 6 ft. in height, and has large leaves without wings.
Notes:

Nat. name `Towai', <i>Raoul. </i>

Date:  11/5/2002
Source:  Dominion Weekend Magazine
Author:
Vol / Page:  4
Edition:
Quote:  Hysterical squirts and zig-zags of milkbar cowboy material, namely artificial strawberry, chocolate and lemon syrups, painted the plate like a drunken Picasso.
Notes:

Date:  1/4/2000
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  52
Edition:
Quote:  Hamilton Beach's deco brackets, their pods poised above gleaming mixer arms that de;ivered milkshakes in cool, tall aluminium beakers, were the heart of the milk bar at a time when milk was the cool drink. So cool that heavy dudes, Harley riders, even, were known as milk bar cowboys and jukebox music was eroding the moral fabric of the nation. Great milk bars were places of style and social consequence when pubs were slop houses and restaurants served no wine; serious places that demanded serious drinking, and there was nothing more serious than a milkshake.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1956
Source:  Street Society in Christchurch
Author:  CROWTHER
Vol / Page:  1
Edition:
Quote:  During the early months of this year [1956] much publicity was given in the Christchurch newspapers to the fact that large numbers of young people were to be seen, especially at the weekends, in the central areas of the city. These young people congregated in the streets and milk-bars. Many of them had motor-cycles ... At various times these young people were referred to as `Teddy Boys', `Milk Bar Cowboys' and `Bodgies and Widgies'. <i>Ibid.</i> 2 Milk Bar Cowboys show more individual variation in their dress, and do not display the cleanness and neatness of the Teddy Boy. Leather jackets and trousers tucked into the tops of high wool-lined boots are common. Their interests centre round motor-cycles and cars; many wear one or more of the badges issued by motor-cycle manufacturers. Youths of this type are common in the Christchurch streets at the week-end. It is worth noting that whereas the name of Teddy Boy is accepted proudly, that of Milk Bar Cowboy is not. Boys who appear to conform to this type will repudiate the label.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1972
Source:  Half-Gallon Quarter-Acre Pavlova Paradise, The
Author:  MITCHELL
Vol / Page:  183
Edition:
Quote:  <i>larrikin</i>: Young people of whom you happen not to approve. Note that all the terms of disapprobation for rumbustious youth left the rest of the world when youth took it over and crawled off to die in New Zealand where the old have such a strong hold. Expressions still used are `milk-bar cowboy', `flagon wagon gang' and even occasionally `Teddy boy.'
Notes:

milking cow
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: (mining)
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary)
Author:  McARA
Vol / Page:  314
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Caving method</i>: Also known as the `milking cow'; it applied to an area of several acres where the Mine Lake is now. The method started with the collapse of the large arches on the Martha reef about No. 1 shaft, and was later systematically developed by a series of sub-levels on Nos 7, 8 and 9 levels which were used to weaken this section of country and cause it to run so that it could be drawn off through chutes. It operated for a quarter-century and is conservatively estimated to have yielded over a million tons of good run-of-mine grade ore. <i>Ibid.</i> 327 <i>Milking Cow or Caving Block</i>: (See also caving method). A block of country between Nos 1 and 6 shafts and Junction Road, where the Mine Lake is now, which originally contained a network of large reefs and which collapsed after the removal of undergound support pillars and arches and became a caving area. It is estimated that over 1,000,000 tons of ore of good grade was obtained on Nos 7 and 8 levels by caving methods during a period of 25 years.
Notes:

Quote:   Some [saw]mill terms have died out. One is <i>mill time.</i> This was a setting of the clocks an hour early so that the working day, eight to five by mill time, was really seven to four. It was a kind of localized summer time to allow the saw sharpeners to work in daylight after working hours.

mimosa
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: KOWHAI [AND Acacia 1959] (an occasional and mistaken name - occas. NATIVE MIMOSA from the yellow colour of both Austral, wattle and kowhai blooms)
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1848
Source:  Handbook for New Zealand, The
Author:  WAKEFIELD
Vol / Page:  144
Edition:
Quote:  Everywhere are to be seen ... the beautiful mimosa, called Kohai, (<i>Edwardsia microphylla</i>,) covered with clusters of yellow flowers.  [but cp op. cit. 152 `some mimosas from N.S.W. [have been introduced]']
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1868
Source:  Contributions to NZ Botany
Author:  LINDSAY
Vol / Page:  73
Edition:
Quote:  <i>S. tetraptera</i>, Aiton, var. <i>microphylla,</i> Jacq. ... The `Kowhai' of the North Island Maori; the `Kowai' of settlers, - or as the word is variously corrupted and spelt by them, - `Goai' or `Ghoai,' `Goa' or `Ghoa.' According to Hector, the type is known to Otago Maoris as `Houma;' while the term `Kowhai' is applied to var. <i>grandiflora</i> in common with its other varieties. Var. <i>microphylla </i>is also sometimes designated by the colonists the Native `Laburnum' or `Mimosa,' from the similarity of its foliage, in the arboreous condition, to that of these familiar ... European trees.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1869
Source:  AJHR
Author:
Vol / Page:  D-6
Edition:
Quote:   ... no permanent mining industry of any extent has been established in New Zealand. ... The alluvial diggings ... in Otago and West Coast can hardly with any propriety be termed mines, or those who work them, miners. For the sake of convenience, I shall, in the following essay, observe a distinction between the alluvial digger, by whom I understand one who gathers gold from the surface ;and from later deposits only, and the alluvial miner, ... that is ..., one who works the deeper deposits or deep placer mines as they are called.
Notes:  (R.H. Eyton Essay on Gold-mining Population)

Citations
Date:  0/0/1907
Source:  NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin
Author:
Vol / Page:  No. 4 (NS.):122
Edition:
Quote:  In the upper levels of the mines the ore - shoots are said to have been intimately associated with what are termed `mineral heads' or `bars'. These are apparently layers of sedimentary rock, which originally proved more permeable to the circulating ground-waters than the general mass of rock, and supplied aqueous precipitants of gold and silver to the vein channels. <i>Ibid.</i> 124 A much more extensive shoot of ore was mined in former years from the intersection of a rather large mineralised stratum (`mineral head') with one of the veins
Notes:  Fraser & Adams, Coromandel

miner's lantern
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a bottle lantern
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  10/11/1872
Source:  Letters from Canterbury, NZ
Author:  HARPER
Vol / Page:  172
Edition:  1914
Quote:  My host had given me a miners' lantern. ... It is made of a clear glass bottle, the bottom of which is cut off by means of a worsted thread, soaked in paraffin oil, tied around it, and set alight. In the neck of the bottle, inside, a piece of candle is lit, the bottle carried by its neck upright, and, provided there is no rain, no lantern is more effective, amd, if needs be, it can be stuck upright in the ground.
Notes:

miner's right
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a licence to dig for gold, etc. [AND 1855]  (cf. Prospectors' Right (1971))


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:

mingimingi
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: Any of several native shrubs with small and often sharp-tipped leaves belonging to the families Epacridaceae and Rubiaceae. See also miki-miki.
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: p.c. John Dawson 28.10.88 C. juniperina--> now = C. acerosa-->: earlier <i>C. acerosa</i> (=prickly) the SI species: now generally popularly divided into PRICKLY MINGIMINGI and SOFT MINGIMINGI: generally found e.g. on beech-forest floors: mingimingi with twisted grain probably
Citations

Source:  Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine)

Quote:  The best is mingimingi, a vine that settlers amd gold-diggers would pull from thet trees to stuff their mattresses with or make hinaki for catching eels.

mining tenure
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: one of various forms of land holding in <i>mining districts</i> (a term not specifically recorded in DNZE) under successive Mining Acts - <i>residence site licence, business site licence</i> and <i>special licence</i> - granted by a <i>Warden's Court</i>(DNZE).
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim Cameron writes: Largely historical. These tenures have been brought under the land transfer system by the Mining Tenures Registration Act 1962. (I do not know if they still exist as such).

Ministry
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: In New Zealand until quite recently (Ministry of Works, 19 ), only the former of the two main `governmental' senses of Ministry was commonly used: OED 5 from 1710, the body of ministers forming the government' eg. the Seddon ministry, etc. As the name of a Stare department (OED 6, from 1877) it was introduced when the name of the `Public Works Department (see P.W.D.) was for various reasons changed to Ministry of Works. Since then the reorganisation and extension of responsibilities of the Transport Department has given a new Ministry of Transport. -->`Ministry' is felt to be a more inclusive (perhaps grander) name than `department' in the NZ State Services system. (Based partly on a note by R. Mason) -->cf EWD 5.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1940
Source:  Fishes NZ
Author:  PHILLIPPS
Vol / Page:  25
Edition:
Quote:  NEW ZEALAND MINNOW <i>Galaxias attenuatus</i> (Jenyns) ... This is the inanga of the Maori; but the term is not used in the same sense by all tribes. Some call whitebait inanga and use the term in a general sense, others apply it to the adult and others strictly to the young of the minnow which form the main constituent of whitebait, Galaxias attenuatus. Hiwi is a name used in the Bay of Plenty for the parent fish, and numerous other names have been applied to this important fish by Maoris in all parts of the country.
Notes:

Source:  Native Animals of NZ
Author:  POWELL
Vol / Page:  63
Edition:
Quote:  [T]he complete life history of <i>Galaxias attenuatus</i> [whitebait], or the New Zealand Minnow, as it is often termed, was made known.

(C.) [<i>M.</i> musk, used for flavouring tobacco, is Celmisia novae-zelandiae A.W.]

Edition:
Quote:  <i>Galaxias attenuatus</i>(Jenyns). Minnow, whitebait. <i>Hiwi, inanga</i>. ...The only marine record is that of a number of specimens 3 1/4 ins. ... caught in a garfish bunt in the Otago Harbour in February, 1931.
Notes:   Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour

Date:  0/0/1956
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  GRAHAM
Vol / Page:  118

Edition:
Quote:  MINNOW or WHITEBAIT (INANGA) <i>Austrocobitis attenuatus</i> (Jenyns)... For a long time it has been known to the Maori and to Europeans that our New Zealand Whitebait is the young of a native freshwater fish commonly known as Minnow, or Inanga or Hiwi to the Maori, and erroneously called a Trout. ... The early settlers called it Maori Trout, Native Trout, Rock Trout and Minnow. But it is not a Trout. Nor is it a Minnow, through it resembles the English freshwater Minnow. While the name Trout is not correct, it is and will always be known as such by farmers and naturalists. In the Bay of Plenty, Whitebait is known to the Maori as Porohoe.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Sea Anglers' Guide
Author:  DOOGUE & MORELAND
Vol / Page:  195
Edition:
Quote:  INANGA (WHITEBAIT) ... <i>Other names: Galaxias attenuatus</i>; minnow; jolly tail (Australia).
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1971
Source:  Dictionary of the Maori Language
Author:  WILLIAMS
Vol / Page:  77
Edition:
Quote:  <i>I[i]nanga, inanga</i>, n. <i>1. Whitebait</i>, the adult of the minnow, <i>Galaxias attenuatus</i>(also the fry), and the fry of the smelt, <i>Retropinna retropinna.</i> ... Maoris distinguish between <i>inanga papa</i>, a variety of smelt, <i>Retropinna</i>, and <i>inanga tu[u]tuna,</i> a spotted variety of minnow, <i>Galaxias. </i>
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Fisherman's Bible
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  288
Edition:
Quote:  MINNOW Another name for the `Inanga'. Given by early settlers because of its resemblance to the English minnow, - of which it is no relative.

miro
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: <i>Podocarpus ferrugineus</i> black pine (Otago) and its wood; a tall native forest tree with hard timber, aromatic foliage and red fruit. [Maori]
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]

Pronunciation:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/154
Edition:
Quote:  <i>miromiro</i>, a bird (Petroeca toitoi), North Island tomtit; white-breasted tit it differs from the South Island form (P. macrocephala) yellow-breasted tit in the colouration of the breast. Whilst miromiro was the name of the North Island bird, both of them bore the name ngirungiru, so that has been adopted for the South Island form, though the South Island Maori would probably give the `ng' sound scurvy treatment and call the bird kirukiru, as he calls ngaio kaio.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Date:  0/0/1947

[40] Its note in the early morning is like the Maori syllables <i>ngi-i-ru, ngiru-ngiru</i>, from which it derives its name, the first syllable being rather prolonged. <i>Ibid.</i> 126 [1/42] MYIOMOIRA MACROCEPHALA. (YELLOW-BREASTED TIT \{SOUTH-ISLAND TOMTIT\}.) <i>Native names</i>. Miromiro, Komiromiro, \{Pimiromiro,\} Ngirungiru\{, Pingirungiru, and Pipitori\}. ...

Notes:  (?Bill Atkinson, Nelson, 15 years)

Citations
Date:  13/5/1844
Source:  Diary
Author:  TUCKETT
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  This is the locality [Mataura] for wonderful stories of wonderful beings; the Maories declare that there are hairy giants, who inhabit a mountain near these valleys; they call them Miroroi, and have a great dread of them; we were very anxious to procure a specimen, and quite willing to hazard the capture, thinking it would be a fine spec., other resources failing, to return to England with.
Notes:  1844 May 13 Tuckett Diary in 1898 Hocken Contributions 220

Date:  0/0/1964
Source:  Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock
Author:  MILLS ET AL
Vol / Page:  85
Edition:
Quote:  Ewes with lambs will not 'follow on' the same as dry sheep will. Instinctively they know that once in a mob they will mis-mother. Under no circumstances should ewes and lambs be bunched to the extent that they mis-mother.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1940
Source:  Te Waimate
Author:  STUDHOLME
Vol / Page:  114
Edition:  1954
Quote:  The manager of an adjoining station once told me that he saw about 5,000 Merino ewes and lambs yarded on one occasion by an inexperienced man, and about 200 were smothered before the men started tailing. Then they let the ewes and lambs out on to a big block,

<i>yard by yard as they finished,</i> the result being that fully 500 lambs were mis-mothered, some of the ewes being miles away before the mob was through.
Notes:

missionary
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a (usually Protestant) Christian Maori (contrast PIKOPO, a Catholic Christian; and DEVIL) spg also mihorari--> (?a mistranscription or misprin a re-borrowing of Maori <i>mihinare</i> `missionary' (in modern Maori also `Anglican': Williams, appendix) originally a maoricisation of <i>missionary.</i> a Maori Christian convert spg mihinare--> mitanere-->, mitonare
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1834
Source:  Extracts From a Journal
Author:  McDONNELL
Vol / Page:  35
Edition:  1979
Quote:  I certainly have never been able to discover any great difference in the conduct of the converted and the unconverted - if any difference really exists, it seems by general consent to be given in favor of the latter - indeed, the word Missionaries is used by the Europeans here only to distinguish those rogues, for whose superior rascallity we have no other sufficiently comprehensive term in our language. The fact is, they are all whether converted or unconverted, radically bad - and it is my own opinion as well as that of every one else whom I have conversed with on the subject, that no permanent good can be done among them until they are placed under a power, which shall be at once their terror, their protection, and their model.
Notes:

Missus
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: constr often THE MISSUS, as a frequent contemporary male familiarity (cf THE WIFE, THE OLD WOMAN) as an often now un-contempuous reference used as much (or more) by New Zealanders as by other English speakers. In earlier days used by employees, especially on stations or farms, as a form of polite reference or address to the `boss's' wife.
