mistletoe
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: Any of several genera of parasitic shrubs belonging to the plant families Loranthaceae and Viscaceae; esp. Ileostylus micranthus (formerly Loranthus micranthus) with greenish-yellow flowers, Peraxilla spp. (formerly Elytranthe) with scarlet flowers, parasitic shrubs of southern beeches (Nothofagus spp.), and Tupeia antarctica (see also pirita 2) (all fam. Loranthaceae).
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/7/2005
Source:  Open Space
Author:
Vol / Page:  No 64
Edition:
Quote:  While <i>Ileostylus micranthus</i> can be locally abundant it, too, is declining in some parts of New Zealand.
Notes:

Date:  0/7/2005
Source:  Open Space
Author:
Vol / Page:  No 64
Edition:
Quote:  Types of mistletoes:

Beech;

<i>Alepis falvida</i>        Yellow mistletoe

<i>Peraxilla colensoi</i>    Scarlet mistletoe

<i>Peraxilla tetrapetala</i> Red mistletoe

Extinct;

<i>Trilepetala adamsii</i>   Adam's mistletoe

Green;

<i>Ileostylus micranthus</i> Small flowered mistletoe

<i>Tupeia antartica,</i>     White mistletoe

Dwarf;

<i>Korthalsella clavata</i>  Leafless mistletoe

<i>Korthalsella lindsayi</i> Leafless mistletoe

<i>Korthalsella salicornioides</i> Leafless mistletoe.

All are endemic to New Zealand except for <i>Ileostylus micranthus</i>, which also occurs on Norfolk Island.

Quote:  <i>NOTHOFAGUS MENZIESII, silver beech. </i>A hardy tree, growing from sea level to timber line and often forming pure forests, especially in Nelson and Southland. ...Some stems become malformed through infestations of mistletoe, <i>Elytranthe colensoi,</i> and it is the only known host for our three species of <i>Cyttaria</i>, strawberry fungi which cause large galls.

Source:  Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The
Author:  FORSTER
Vol / Page:  2/296
Edition:
Quote:   ... Now & then [in Queen Charlotte Sound] I found large detached pieces of <i>Basaltes</i>, which the natives employ to make their <i>Imettees</i>[e1-grave] or Instruments for engaging their enemies quite close: it is of an oval Shape, flat edged away on both sides, so as to form a sharp edge, & it ends into a handle with a kind of head or knob at its extremity; it is perforated & commonly a string run through it, to hold it by. [[ed. fn] Miti, a stone weapon, now generally known as <i>patu onewa; he</i> is the indefinite article.

moa hunter
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a term used to describe a member of an early stage of New Zealand Maori culture. -->The early Polynesian culture in New Zealand which is associated with hunting of the moa and use of its bones for artefacts.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1977
Source:  Moa-Hunters of NZ
Author:  DUFF
Vol / Page:  xi-xii
Edition:
Quote:  THE [AUTHOR'S] USE OF THE TERM MOA-HUNTER [heading] [XII] ... Because this hunting economy and imported artifact styles coincided with the then unknown period of the extermination of the Moa in particular, Skinner, Duff and Buck revived the term Moa-hunter Maori to distinguish the first phase of ecological adaptation from the climax Classic Maori phase of the eighteenth century, with such new elements as agriculture, the fortified village, warfare, and artifact styles evolved within New Zealand. [XII] The term Moa-hunter follows the practice in culture-phase designation of coining a label of contrast. Although Moa-hunter Maoris gathered shell-fish and hunted all available birds, fish, seals and small whales, the cultural and economic phase is conveniently designated from the Moa as the largest and most spectacular game animal available during man's first adaptation to the environment and the one no longer available in the Classic Maori era. The term Moa-hunter is preferred here to the longer `Archaic Phase of New Zealand East Polynesian', too easily corrupted to `Archaic Maori', with `Archaic' meaning only `early'.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Collins Concise English Dictionary
Author:
Vol / Page:  724
Edition:
Quote:  <i>moa hunter n. N.Z.</i> an anthropologist's term for an early Maori.

Citations
Date:  21/1/1991
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  80
Edition:
Quote:  [Anderson].. notes that most of the moa-hunting activities occurred south of Cook Strait... He concludes that, although some coastal sites are immense and must represent the slaughter of many thousands of moa, "moa-hunting was generally a temporary, perhaps seasonal, activity" which seldom provided more than a quarter to a half of the moa-hunters' total sustenance... His broad conclusion is that moa-hunting occurred between the 11th and 17th centuries, but peaked early in the 123th century in most areas.
Notes:

mob
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a grouping of farm stock [ as distinct from herd or flock in New Zealand.]


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Loughnan Glossary
Author:  LOUGHNAN
Vol / Page:  53
Edition:
Quote:  mob: as distinct from herd or flock which, though grammatically incorrect, mean the sum total of a man's cattle or sheep, a mob means an integral part of that herd or flock. (eg held in a particular paddock.) A mob also means a collection of beasts, possibly of one or more owners, all boxed together and being driven, in which case it is never a herd or flock. When a mob of sheep or cattle is put up for sale, it is then referred to as a line.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1856
Source:  Journal
Author:  SEWELL
Vol / Page:   II 215
Edition:
Quote:  How to get your Sheep out of a mixed mob - that's a trial for human patience.
Notes:  Journal (1980)

Date:  1/10/1863
Source:  Chudleigh Diary
Author:
Vol / Page:  105
Edition:  1950
Quote:  [We] began mouthing sheep. Polhill who has bought the run and the sheep took down the mouths on paper as the sheep are to be paid for according to their ages. ... You catch a sheep in your arms, carry it to the gate where the mouther stands, hold the mouth open for him to look at and you at the same time call out two, four, six, full or whatever it may be. ... So you know the number age sex etc. of your whole mob.

The horses are led or ridden, as the ground allows; ... but in driving through unknown country, the halts are made very much where the explorers find themselves at sundown.

Date:  4/11/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Mob</i>.- Any number of sheep, cattle, or horses together. The words <i>herd</i> and <i>flock </i>(q.v.) are not used in this sense in New Zealand. <i>M</i>. is also applied to birds wild animal; e.g., ducks, quail, deer, or pigs. When a <i>m.</i> of sheep or cattle is offered for sale, it becomes a <i>line</i> (q.v.).
Notes:  Acland Glossary

Date:  0/0/1939
Source:  First White Boy Born in Otago

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1947
Source:  Early Runholding in Otago
Author:  BEATTIE
Vol / Page:  12
Edition:
Quote:  A few more cases [of our indebtedness to Australia for much of our early pastoral vocabulary includes] the word `mob' for a collection of animals whether it be horses, cows, sheep, goats, or pigs. Although the words `herds' (of cattle) and `flocks' (of sheep) were occasionally used, they were too pedantic for ordinary use, and the word `mob' was indiscriminately used on nearly all occasions.
Notes:

mob grazing

Sense Number:

mob stocking
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1

Date:  0/0/1950
Source:  NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page:  95(4)/389
Edition:
Quote:   The grazing management system was modified to a considerable extent from that of traditional set stocking to one known as mob stocking or mobbing. In such a method of grazing, paddocks are heavily stocked in turn so that the pasture herbage available is used to the fullest extent in the shortest possible time.

mobbing
Homonym Number:
Word Class: adjective
Sense Number:

moccasin
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1927
Source:  Sheep & Wool Industry
Author:  SMITH
Vol / Page:  75
Edition:
Quote:   ... the shearers at the pen gates arrayed in their working clothes, with bowyangs (a strap over their trousers, below the knees, which allows them to bend with more comfort), and moccasins on (a kind of shoe made out of wool-pack, after the style of the foot-covering [76] of the Red Indian) ...
Notes:

Date:  27/1/1934
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Woolshed terms.</i>-The <i>water pot</i> is a tin of water (usually disinfected) which a shearer has tied by him to wet his shears in. To <i>gap</i> shears is to make (accidentally) a g. in the edge. <i>Sweat rag:</i> kept by the shearer to wipe his brow. <i>To grind</i> (shears) is always used without the noun. A shearer never `grinds his shears.' <i>Moccasins</i> are the sacking slippers which most shearers make to work in. Unless the owner of the station is a careful, observant man, he will hardly recognise his own wool pack tops.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1952
Source:  Station Days in Maoriland
Author:  MEEK
Vol / Page:  110
Edition:
Quote:  MOCCASINS: Shearer's footwear, made of jute, cut from a woolpack.

Vol / Page:  56
Edition:
Quote:  Take all skin and bone away from some cold white fish and flake the flesh into pieces about the size of whitebait.   Roll in flour, and leave them a little time;  then fry in a frying basket with plenty of boiling fat until they are crisp and brown.   Serve at once very hot after dusting with a little pepper.   Serve lemon and cayenne pepper with them.

Date:  4/3/1919
Source:  Evening Post

Vol / Page:  2

Date:  8/2/1936
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  19
Edition:
Quote:  Mock Whitebait. - Raw fish (any kind), 2 tablespoons flour,  teaspoon salt, cayenne, egg glazing, breadcrumbs, frying fat, lemon.   Free the fish from the bone, and cut into strips about one and a half inches long.   Mix flour, salt, and cayenne.   Dip the pieces of fish in the flour, then in egg, and coat with crumbs.   Fry a golden brown in hot fat.   Drain.   Serve piles high on a hot dish, garnished with slices of lemon.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1928
Source:  Everybody's Cookery Book of Tested Recipes
Author:
Vol / Page:  67
Edition:
Quote:  <i>MOCK WHITEBAIT </i>One egg ... potatoes ... Pepper and salt. ... Drop in spoonfuls onto boiling fat.

[1951 Glossary merely has after `melanura': The bird is sometimes still called a `mockie'.] ([1874 Lady Barker Station Life],p.93; [1898 Morris Austral-English])
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1934
Source:  Windy Island
Author:  HARPER
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  [glossary] Mako-mako; New Zealand bell-bird, popularly known as the `mocker' or `mockie'
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/147
Edition:
Quote:  <i>tui</i>, a bird (Prosthemadera novaeseelandiae), the most characteristic of the smaller Maori birds, kept by the Maori as a pet and by them taught to speak, it being an excellent mimic, and so by the settlers called the mocking-bird, shortened to mockie, and called parson-bird because of the two white curled tufts of feathers at its throat. Then, because some folk thought mockie was short for makomako, a name of the bell-bird (korimako) in some parts, some thought it was the korimako which was the mimic, and hence both birds have been called the mocking-birds.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Birds of New Zealand
Author:  FALLA et al.
Vol / Page:  218
Edition:
Quote:  BELLBIRD <i>Anthornis melanura Other names</i>: Korimako, Makomako, Mockie.

obscura</i> FALLA, 1948. ... <i>Chatham Island Bellbird A.m. melanocephala</i> GRAY, 1843. ... OTHER NAMES: <i>Korimako, makomako, mockie. </i>

mocking bird
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1830
Source:  New Zealanders, The
Author:  CRAIK
Vol / Page:  187
Edition:
Quote:  The most remarkable bird is one to which Cook's people gave the name of mocking-bird, from the extraordinary variety of its notes. There is also another which is called by the English the poe, or poi bird, from a little tuft of white curled feathers which it has under its throat, and which seemed to them to resemble certain white flowers worn as ornaments by the people of otaheite, and known there [188] by a similar name.
Notes:

Moemoe, which is grown commercially near Pukekohe, is sometimes seen in our better restaurants, such as The White House and The Boulcott Street Bistro... Another dish in Morgan's repertoire.. is to slice moemoe into rounds and cook them in a mixture of half duck fat and half olive oil for 40-60 minutes at 170C.

Moeraki Boulders
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: (in North Otago)
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/11/2003
Source:  NZ Geographic
Author:
Vol / Page:  No. 66/12
Edition:
Quote:  The Moeraki boulders are an assemblage of near-perfect spheres that lie like discarded cricket balls on an east Otago beach. The largest of them span more than two metres in diameter and weigh over seven tonnes.[15] Claims have been made that the Moeraki boulders are the only rocks of their kind in the world... The truth is that concretions are common, but are usually only a few centimetres in diameter, irregular in shape and unlikely to impress... To Moeraki's Ngai Tahi residents, the boulders' origin is intertwined with the arrival of kumara from distant Hawaiki. According to Te Rungana o Moeraki, the great waka Arai-Te-Uru was wrecked during a fierce storm at Matakaea (Shag Point), just south of Moeraki. The boulders are food baskets that washed ashore after being thrown overboard to lighten the load. The Katiki concretions are said to be kumara tubers and seeds from the same wreck.
Notes:

Date:  6/4/1985
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  91
Edition:
Quote:  Along the way she [sc. Shona McFarlane]

also looks at natural art. "Sculptures

like the Moeraki boulders, the Cathedral

Cliffs at Gore Bay, the Oamaru stone

quarry.

Vol / Page:  104
Edition:
Quote:  PILCHARD (MOHIMOHI) <i>Sardinops neopilchardus (Steindacher) The Pilchard is known from the northern end of the South Island as the Picton Herring, and off Picton large shoals of these fish have from time to time been recorded. It has no relation to the so-called New Zealand Herring or Yellow-eyed Mullet (Agonostomus forsteri). </i>

Date:  0/0/1903
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  35/319
Edition:
Quote:  ...<i> large numbers of aua or kataha (Agonostoma forsteri); about 60 lb. ... weight of pilchard or mohimohi (Clupea sagax), two varieties; ... hundreds of young red-cod, rarii (<i>Lotella bacchus</i>), and what I believe are young rock-cod, or kokopu or rawaru (<i>Percis colias</i>). The red-cod were from 3 in. to 4 in. in length, and the rawaru, or, as the natives here call them, `toitoi' or `panepane', from 2 in. to 6 in. long.
Notes:  Mair Fish in Piako River

Quote:  CERTHIPARUS ALBICILLA, Less. Mohoua
Notes:  (Potts Birds)

mohua
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a small South Island bird with yellow head and breast reputed to appear in flocks just before a rain; also called bush canary, rain bird, storm-bird, yellow-head


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: yellowhead
Pronunciation:
Notes: Compare upokotea, white-head. [Maori]

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1873
Source:  Birds of New Zealand
Author:  BULLER
Vol / Page:  48
Edition:
Quote:  Possessing excellent powers of mimicry, and useful to the natives as a decoy-bird, the kaka is much sought after, and almost every native village has its `mokai'. <i>Ibid.</i> 89 \{1888 2nd edn 1/96\} I had been addressing a large meeting of natives in the Whare-runanga, or Council-house [at Rangitikei], on a matter of considerable political importance, and had been urging my views with all the earnestness that the subject demanded: immediately on the conclusion of my speech, and before the old chief, to whom my arguments were chiefly [sic] addressed, had time to reply, a Tui, whose netted cage hung to a rafter overhead, responded, in a clear emphatic way, `Tito!' (false). The circumstances naturally caused much merriment among my audience, and quite upset the gravity of the venerable old chief Nepia Taratoa. `Friend,' said he, laughing, `your arguments are very good; but my <i>mokai</i> is a very wise bird, and he is not yet convinced.'
Notes:

moki
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: New Zealand sea fishes of two families; the South Island species is blue-grey (occasionally called blue moki), the main North Island species is red (red moki or nanua).
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: also painted moki, moki shark, moki trumpeter
Pronunciation:
Notes: early spellings mogge, moka etc.

roused great interest and was attended

with some ritual.

Author:
Vol / Page:  167
Edition:
Quote:  Of the sea-fishes that are used as food in New Zealand, we have among the constant residents on all parts of our coast the hapuku, tarakihi, trevally, moki, aua, rock-cod, wrasse, and patiki; and while the snapper, mullet, and gurnet are only met with in the north, the trumpeter, butterfish, and red-cod are confined to the south.

Quote:  The warehou, tarakihi, and gurnet are common in the north, and the moki, butterfish, and frost fish in the south, while the kahawai, hapuku (the groper of Dunedin), blue cod, barracouta, the little sea mullet, sometimes called the herring, and the flat fish are found all round the coast. <i>Ibid.</i> 73

-->1902 Drummond and Hutton Nature in NZ 73

The butterfish lives amongst kelp, or sea-weed, and is generally found where kelp is plentiful. Neither it nor the moki takes bait freely.

Notes:

moki
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: shorter form of mokihi, a raft made usually of bundles of dry flaxsticks or raupo
Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Tales of Pioneer Women
Author:
Vol / Page:  119
Edition:
Quote:  There was no boat, so they collected bundles of dry flax sticks, tied them together into a "moki," and crossed the river on that.


Notes:  Writing of 1940

Date:  16/1/1900
Source:  NZ Mines Record
Author:
Vol / Page:  233
Edition:
Quote:  It [sc. a Maori expedition] consisted of twenty <i>mokis</i>, well freighted with pounamu.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1838
Source:  New Zealand  (Polack)
Author:  POLACK
Vol / Page:  1/218
Edition:
Quote:  ... a bundle of these rushes are often tied together, to anable a person to cross a stream. These ... are called mokis' [sic], are very buoyant, and resist saturation for some time.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1840
Source:  Manners & Customs of the NZers
Author:  POLACK
Vol / Page:  1/226
Edition:
Quote:   In the absence of canoes, a quantity of dried bulrushes are fastened together, on which the native is enabled to cross a stream by sitting astride and paddling with his hands; these humble conveyances are called <i>moki</i>, and resemble those made use of by the Egyptians in crossing among the islands of the Nile.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1858
Source:  AJHR
Author:
Vol / Page:  C-3-18
Edition:
Quote:  We crossed the river on mokies. ... By means of large mokis carrying upwards of a ton.... moki navigation.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1873
Source:  Wild Will Enderby
Author:  PYKE
Vol / Page:  3/iii/82-83
Edition:  1889,1974
Quote:  For the benefit of the unlearned ... let me here explain that a `Mokihi' is constructed of `Koradies'; - <i>Anglice</i>:- the flowering stalks of the flax, - three faggots of which, lashed [83] firmly in a point to the small ends, and expanded by a piece of wood at the stern, constitute the sides and bottom of the frail craft, ... <i>Ibid.</i> 115  ... a `mokihi' is constructed of koradies ... three faggots of which lashed firmly in a point at the small ends, and expanded by a piece of wood at the stern, constitute the sides and bottom of the frail craft which, propelled by paddle, furnishes sufficient means of transpor for a single individual.
Notes:

mokihi/moki
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a raft made of rushes or flax-flower stems.


Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

Quote:  <i>mokimoki</i> or <i>moki</i>, a fern (Polypodium pustulatum), used by the Maori for scenting oil, and highly valued for this purpose. A hill in Napier was named Puke-mokimoki because this fern was abundant there; but the hill was levelled to fill a gully and made a recreation reserve in the town.
Notes:   Andersen Maori Words in English

Quote:  First among the New Zealand list of disfigurations is tattooing, a Polynesian word signifying a repetition of taps, but which term is unknown in the language of the New Zealanders; <i>moko</i> being the general term for the tattooing on the face, and <i>whakairo</i> for that on the body.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1894
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  26/436
Edition:
Quote:  It only so far denotes rank as showing that the possessor of a handsome moko must have had the wherewithal to well remunerate the artist.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  299
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Moko, n</i>. the system of tattooing practised by the Maoris. See <i>Tattoo</i>. It is not a fact - as popularly supposed - that the `moko' was distinctive in different families; serving, as is sometimes said, the purpose of a coat-of-arms. The `moko' was in fact all made on the same pattern - that of all Maori carvings. Some were more elaborate than others. The sole difference was that some were in outline only, some were half filled in, and others were finished in elaborate detail.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page:  2027
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Mo&#769;.ko&#769;.</i>, (m&omacr.&#769;.ko.&#769;.), n. [Maori.] The kind of tattooing practiced among the higher ranks of the Maoris. ... <i>Mo&#769;.ko, v. t.</i> To tattoo in the Maori manner.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/161
Edition:
Quote:  <i>moko</i>, tattooing on the face or body: - `their bodies and faces were more marked with the black stains which they call Amoco; they had a broad spiral on each buttock,' <i>Cook, Voyages,</i> 26 Nov., 1769 (Ed. 3, 1785), vol. 3, p. 253. "but the grand ornament of all was the <i>moko</i>, or tattoo; this was in general use, all ranks adopted it; a <i>papatea</i>, or plain face, was a term of reproach."<i> Taylor, Ika</i>, Ed. 2 (1870) 319. `The term tattoo is not known in New Zealand; and the name given to the decorative marks in question ... in in New Zealand moko.' <i>Robley, Moko</i> (1896), 3. `The native name for tattooing ... is <i>moko</i>, the verb being <i>ta</i>, or <i>ta moko</i>, as it is usually employed.' <i>Best, The Maori </i>(1924), vol. 2, 546; (<i>ta</i>, a prefix having apparently a causative force similar to that of <i>whaka</i>.)
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

signatures or `<i>moko</i> marks' of the different Maori chiefs.

Date:  22/11/1769
Source:  Banks Journal
Author:
Vol / Page:  203
Edition:  1896
Quote:   `They had a much larger quantity of<i> amoca</i>[sic] or black stains upon their bodies and faces. They had almost universally a broad spiral on each buttock, and many had their thighs almost entirely black, small lines only being left untouched, so that they looked like striped breeches. In this particular, I mean the use of <i>amoca</i>, almost every tribe seems to have a different custom.'

Quote:  The chisel was constantly dipped in a [172] liquid made of soot from a particular tree, and afterwards mixed with water, which communicates the blackness or, as they call it, the amoko

(moko). I observed proud flesh rising in some part of the breech which had been cut almost one month before. The operation is too painful to bear the whole tattooing at one time. They appear to be several years before they are perfectly tattooed.

moko skink
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a small skink with an unusually long tail, found in coastal areas on the mainland and many islands from Bay of Plenty northwards.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: <i>Oligosoma moco</i>  aka Northern brown skink - see http://www.reptilepark.co.nz/nzlizard.htm.
Citations
Date:  12/9/2005
Source:  NZ Herald
Author:
Vol / Page:  A11
Edition:
Quote:  The tiny population of moko skinks (Oligosoma moco) was found at the council-run Shakespear [sic] Regional Park on the Whangaparaoa peninsula, about 30 minutes from central Auckland. ... Moko skinks were common throughout the upper North Island before Europeans settled in New Zealand but the introduction of rats and mice saw some skink populations plummet. ... Moko skinks are mostly confined to islands such as the Hauraki Gulf's Tiritiri Matangi.

moleskin
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a) a strong, cotton fabric. b) (plural) trousers made from this fabric, formerly commonly worn by workmen.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]

moll
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a girl or woman
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: a derogatory term for a woman, in the 1930's and 40's not necessarily a prostitute; but, so H. Beaton p.c., not with that association here; used (ca1935+) espec. by schoolchildren for any girl (esp. if she had a reputation, for being fast).
Citations

Source:  Horse
Author:  BAXTER
Vol / Page:  66
Edition:
Quote:  That bloody moll up the road just about killed me. She tore the skin off my back with her nails.
Notes:  c1962 Baxter Horse (1985) (Breaking and Entering) 66

mollies
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1984
Source:  NZ Yesterdays
Author:  KEITH & MAIN
Vol / Page:  288
Edition:
Quote:  Marbles were the currency of childhood and there were an astonishing number of names for them, some referring to the material or colour, others to value or function in the game. There were agates, aggies, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cats-eye, [sic] chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, mollies, peelies, peewees, pisswees, pretties, Scotties, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers and whities. The march of technology added ball bearings - ballies or steelies - which were unbeatable when it came to smashing an opponent's miserable glassie. World War II[roman] brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles.
Notes:

Momley Peg
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: stagknife
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1972
Source:  Folkgames of Children
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  171
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Stagknife</i> (K-31), a universal game of nineteenth-century childhood, was important because it was played with the most treasured play object of all boys, the pocket knife. Although known in nearly all parts of New Zealand by the name of Stagknife, the game was also known as Bites, Jackknife, Stabknife, Knifey, Momley Peg, and Throwing the Knife. ... There were generally two players ... who each sought to deflect the point of the pocket knife from certain parts of the body by a flick of the hand in such a way that the blade would stick firmly into the ground. ... Every movement had to be done three times. [172] Typical movements were: (1) Place the open pocket knife (loose) [name of movement] [sic] on the closed knuckles of the right hand, point the knife towards the thumb, then with a quick upward flick of the hand to the left, deflect the point of the knife into the ground.
Notes:

mongrel
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: 1952 Feb 16 R.Gilberd notes on Mongrel Reading `Talking of Words' (Cecil Hull) p21`We might objectively and scientifically describe him, if he were ours, as a dog of mixed breeds - ... we would not be pleased if an acquaintance calls that dog a mongrel.'  In town where dogs are kept largely for appearance and display `mongrel' I think has only one meaning - that a dog is of mixed breeding (with a note of disapproval or contempt). In the country mongrel has two independent meanings.  (i) A dog of mixed blood. Objective - no emotional content. Indeed `pedigreed' is acquiring something of the mongrel taint, in that if a good dog has a pedigree it is mentioned with a faint note of surprise.  (ii) A `no-good' whether man or animal.  `He turned out mongrel' (Rod Macaulay speaking of a pedigreed mastiff that took to sheep worrying.)  `When Bill brought him home I knew he'd turn out a mongrel. Sort of a cow-y look about his head.' (Walter Hull discussing a pedigreed `Totara Park' Friesian bull which proved sterile.)  Talking of dogs:  An `eye-dog' is a specialised type of header which works very quietly, never taking its eyes off the sheep it is trying to pen. Sheep men generally seem to think the dog hypnotises the sheep into being penned quietly. I believe that the fixity of its gaze and its complete concentration enable it to detect and counter any rebelliousness on the part of the sheep before the sheep have quite made up their minds.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations

mongrel
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: cf. cur; mong
Pronunciation:
Notes: [HWO distinguish from racist connotation =halfcaste, and the Australasian offensive epithet]
Citations
Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Some Modern Maoris
Author:  BEAGLEHOLE
Vol / Page:  299
Edition:
Quote:  Skin colour and the mixture of blood which is responsible for it [sc. high visibility in a white world] are often commented on by one Maori to another. The terms `mongrel', `black mongrel', `dago', or `black nigger', for instance, are often used by Maoris either in referring to themselves or to other Maoris in the neighbourhood. Thus one informant, in introducing herself, remarked: `I'm only a mongrel' - meaning only a mixed-blood Maori.
Notes:

Date:  16/2/1952
Source:  Personal Communication
Author:  R. GILBERD
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:   `We might objectively and scientifically describe him, if he were ours, as a dog of mixed breeds - ... we would not be pleased if an acquaintance calls that dog a mongrel.' In town where dogs are kept largely for appearance and display `mongrel' I think has only one meaning - that a dog is of mixed breeding (with a note of disapproval or contempt). In the country mongrel has two independent meanings. (i) A dog of mixed blood.  Objective - no emotional content. Indeed `pedigreed' is acquiring something of the mongrel taint, in that if a good dog has a pedigree it is mentioned with a faint note of surprise. (ii) A `no-good' whether man or animal. `He turned out mongrel' (Rod Macaulay speaking of a pedigreed mastiff that took to sheep worrying.) `When Bill brought him home I knew he'd turn out a mongrel. Sort of a cow-y look about his head.' (Walter Hull discussing a pedigreed `Totara Park' Friesian bull which proved sterile.)

Quote:  But hang on, you cry, we need a bit more mongrel at the top level... Fair call, but what the Hurricanes are doing isn't "mongrel" rugby. Mongrel rugby is putting in big hits. Not taking a backward step. Sorting out opposition foul play the old-fashioned way, rather than bleating to an incompetent referee to do something.

Citations
Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Sea Anglers' Guide
Author:  DOOGUE & MORELAND
Vol / Page:  263
Edition:
Quote:  SPOTTED STARGAZER ... <i>Other names: Geniagnus monopterygius</i>; catfish, monk, dogfish; kourepoua (Maori).
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1970
Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
Author:  SORENSON
Vol / Page:  37
Edition:
Quote:  <i>MONKFISH </i>(a) Scientific name: (i) <i>Geniagnus monopterygius</i> (ii) <i>Kathetostoma giganteum.</i> (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (both) Whitefish. (c) Other common names: (both) Monkfish, Monks, Stargazer, Flathead (also applied at times to export gurnard); Churchills, Toebiters, Bulldogs, Spotted Stargazer, Maori Chief (Dunedin); Muddies. (d) Principal localities where taken: Napier, Cook Strait, Nelson, Banks Peninsula, Bluff-Stewart Island. ... Monkfish is a general term for species of the Families Uranoscopidae and Leptoscopidiae.
Notes:

Date:  23/7/1986
Source:  Codes for Species in NZ Waters
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  species name] stargazer .. [scientific name] <i>Kathetostoma giganteum</i> .. [other name(s)] monkfish, boofs, bulldogs, churchills, flathead monk, giant stargazer, monks, muddies, spotted stargazer, toebiters, whitefish, sandcod

monkey
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the cover of a wool press
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1913
Source:  Country Work
Author:  CARR
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  Pressing. - When there is sufficient wool in one bin, the pressers (generally two) get to work. One gets into the `box' as the lower portion of the patent presses is called, while his mate ... hands him ... the fleeces. These are placed in tiers, and tramped down until the lower box is full. An upper box is then swung ... or [16] lowered on to the lower one, and the process repeated. When full, the `monkey' or cover is put into position, the spears (wire rope) affixed, and the two men lever the cover down until the top box is clear.
Notes:

Quote:  Monkfish, which is sweetish in flavour, can be covered with a potato sauce and then dusted with cocoa for a bitter contrast... Martin is deperate one day to be allowed to buy a whole monkfish, so he can get at the liver and have a play. In Europe, chefs pay a fortune for monkfish liver, which is described as the foie gras of the sea, whereas New Zealand fishermen fillet the monkfish on board their boats and probably toss the liver overseas.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1970
Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
Author:  SORENSON
Vol / Page:  37
Edition:
Quote:  <i>MONKFISH</i> (a) Scientific name: (i) <i>Geniagnus monopterygius</i> (ii) <i>Kathetostoma giganteum</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (both) Whitefish. (c) Other common names: (both) Monkfish, Monks, Stargazer, Flathead (also applied at times to export gurnard); Churchills, Toebiters, Bulldogs, Spotted Stargazer, Maori Chief (Dunedin); Muddies. (d) Principal localities where taken: Napier, Cook Strait, Nelson, Banks Peninsula, Bluff-Stewart Island. ... Monkfish is a general term for species of the Families Uranoscopidae and Leptoscopidiae.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Fisherman's Bible
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  208
Edition:
Quote:  SPOTTED STARGAZER Similar to his cousin the Common Stargazer but thicker and with more distinctive, spotted markings on body and fins. ... Other names are Catfish, Monkfish and Dogfish.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Collins Guide
Author:  AYLING
Vol / Page:  271
Edition:  1984
Quote:  <i>GIANT STARGAZER</i> (Monkfish) <i>Kathetostoma giganteum</i>
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author:  BURTON
Vol / Page:  78
Edition:
Quote:  Also known as stargazers because of their upward-looking eyes, monkfish are widely distributed in New Zealand waters, especially to the south.
Notes:

Date:  22/8/1984
Source:  Marlborough Express
Author:
Vol / Page:  6
Edition:
Quote:  The hoki are sent down first and are by far the major species caught in this area designated G in New Zealand's exclusive economic zone. But there are also ling and school shark, headed and gutted before they are boxed, squid and silver dory, fat blue nose and silver warehou, hake and sharp-toothed southern kingfish, ugly green monkfish and slimy flathead, electric skates and others with saw toothed snouts.
Notes:

Date:  23/7/1986
Source:  Codes for Species in NZ Waters
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:   [species name] stargazer .. [scientific name] <i>Kathetostoma giganteum</i> .. [other name(s)] monkfish, boofs, bulldogs, churchills, flathead monk, giant stargazer, monks, muddies, spotted stargazer, toebiters, whitefish, sandcod
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  PAUL
Vol / Page:  118
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Monkfish Kathetotoma giganteum</i> ... Also occurs in southern Australia. Known by a number of local names: giant stargazer, flathead, bulldog, boof, etc. The name monkfish is well established for this species in New Zealand, whereas overseas it is used for similarly shaped but unrelated anglerfishes.
Notes:

Date:  24/6/1987
Source:  Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page:  8
Edition:
Quote:  About 500 kilograms of monkfish sat on the Greymouth wharf yesterday as a local fisherman and the Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries argued over its fate.

monoao
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a scrub plant with slender, rigid leaves found especially on the North Island volcanic plateau. [Maori] Common Error: do not confuse with MANOAO.

<i>crydium] Colensoi, Hook. </i>A small tree 20-40 ft. high ..., very similar in mode of growth to <i>intermedium, ..</i>56] <i>ver-pine; Monoao</i>. The wood is yellowish-white, ... very durable. Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  73
Edition:
Quote:  <i>monte </i>a certainty, often in reference to a likely winner; from the three-card monte trick of Spanish American card game; eg `Put your money on Bluebell in the Fifth, she's a monte.' - a fine person or thing, by extension; eg `Old Claude's a monte, he'd do anything for you.'

moonlight starlight
Homonym Number:

Register:

Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Citations
Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  History of Children's Play
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  53
Edition:
Quote:  Perhaps the most common of the outdoor dusk He games was `Moonlight, starlight, Bogey won't come out tonight.' We had several paddocks divided off by hedges, and the neighbouring children always congregated for games after their chores were done. We usually ended with Moonlight Starlight. As the bogey was at liberty to move 'round, one never knew where the next pounce was coming from. (1910; Nelson)

Citations
Moore filter
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: mining
Citations
Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary)
Author:  McARA
Vol / Page:  327
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Moore filters</i>: Large `baskets' of canvas-covered filter-frames weighing about 16 tons and connected to a vacuum
Source. First the basket was lowered by an overhead electric-crane into a tank of thickened pulp, previously treated with cyanide solution for several days. The vacuum caused a layer or cake of slime one or two inches thick to build up on the frames, while the clean solution, now laden with gold and silver, was pumped to the precipitators. When the cake reached the required thickness the basket was lifted and placed in a tank of barren cyanide solution, which was sucked through the cake removing the residual gold-bearing solution. After this the basket was placed in a `wash water' tank to remove all the solution, and then it was lifted and placed over the discharge bay; the vacuum was then released, allowing the cake to fall off (with some encouragement from a wooden scraper) into a waste sluice. [328] This process was repeated at about two-hourly intervals, with several bays working at the same time.
Notes:

mopoke
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an owl
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  301
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Mopoke, n.</i> aboriginal name for an Australian bird, from its note `Mopoke.' There is emphasis on the first syllable, but much more on the second. Settlers very early attempted to give an English shape and sense to this name. The attempt took two forms, ` <i>More-pork</i>,' and <i>`Mope-hawk'</i>; both forms are more than fifty years old. The r sound, however, is not present in the note of the bird, although the form <i>More-pork</i> is perhaps even more popular than the true form <i>Mope-hawk</i> seems to have been adopted through dislike of the perhaps coarser idea attaching to `pork.' The quaint spelling <i>Mawpawk</i> seems to have been adopted for a similar reason. [1827 Tasmania]
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1899
Source:  In the Shadow of the Bush
Author:  BELL
Vol / Page:  241
Edition:
Quote:  As Old Dan turned and walked towards the whare [e-acute] a `mopoke' owl that had settled on the ridge of it, and had been uttering at intervals its mournful cry, shrieked and flew away.

Australian settlers distinguish a podargus by a similar name, whence the colonial epithet (whether of Australian or New Zealand origin is uncertain) applied to a dawdling person, who is often described as `a regular old morepork'

Quote:  He has had a rough time of it surveying a block on the ranges up the Wai-o-hine in the Wairarapa ...[sic] Once ...[sic] they had nothing to eat but a tui and a more-pork. ... They were stewing the two birds when a kuku-pa (bush pigeon) flew up and perched. Bob shot it ... This is not exactly what the Britishers call `sport' - but there is more of nature about it than 30 gents in pink and tops ... waiting for a wretched little fox who, when he is killed, is not equal for culinary purposes to a more-pork. Once coming up the Waikato in 1851 your Uncle James got a pot-shot at a lot of parera (grey duck) ...

Edition:

and then catch a small variety of carp

called 'morihana'... Their Maori name,

'morihana', was a translation of

introduced the fish to Taupo and Lake

Rotorua

Moriori myth
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1979
Source:  Maori Origins and Migrations
Author:  SORRENSON
Vol / Page:  53
Edition:
Quote:  Then in 1937 he published an essay called `The Maruiwi myth'. This was concerned largely with the first part of the legend of the coming of the Maori - `that the first Polynesian settlers who arrived with Toi ... found the North Island - possibly both islands - inhabited by a non-Polynesian race, known as Maruiwi or Mouriuri, whom they subsequently exterminated; a small remnant alone escaping to colonize the Chatham Islands'.
Notes:  1979 Sorrenson Maori Origins and Migrations 53 quoting 1937 H.W.Williams J.P.S. 46/105-122

Date:  0/0/1877
Source:  Tikera
Author:  WISNIOWSKI
Vol / Page:  301
Edition:
Quote:  This passage embodies an early version of what has become known as the `Moriori myth'. Except for the name Moriori, which was borrowed from the Chatham Islands and applied by 1880 to supposed pre-Maori inhabitants of New Zealand, the theory is all here in a book published in 1877, based on material collected in the mid-1860s. A black-skinned, curly-headed people with timid dispositions, presumably negroid or Melanesian, were supposed to have been found in possession of New Zealand by the first Polynesian settlers and exterminated by them except for a few with whom they intermarried, so that their racial traits appeared from time to time among the Maoris.
Notes:  1972 ed. note in 1877 WISNIOWSKI Tikera (trans. Podstolski 1972) 301

Vol / Page:  135
Edition:
Quote:  CONVOLVULUS [BINDWEED] (<i>Convolvulus arvensis</i>), is also called bindweed and black bindweed, cornbind, and morning glory. it is an introduced weed found in fields, gardens and waste places in many localities. It has a perennial creeping underground stem, trailing or twining [aerial] stems with leaves 1 to 3 inches long, shaped like a spear head, and handsome bell-shaped flowers an inch or more in diameter- ...

Source:  Weeds of New Zealand

Vol / Page:  135
Edition:
Quote:  CONVOLVULUS [BINDWEED] (<i>Convolvulus arvensis</i>), is also called bindweed and black bindweed, cornbind, and morning glory. it is an introduced weed found in fields, gardens and waste places in many localities. It has a perennial creeping underground stem, trailing or twining [aerial] stems with leaves 1 to 3 inches long, shaped like a spear head, and handsome bell-shaped flowers an inch or more in diameter- ...

morning wood
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: kindling set aside to start domestic fires. More common in NZ than <i>kindling</i>, but perhaps now (1984) old-fashioned
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: "As a child it was one of my chores to cut and bring in the "morning wood". I guess it was so named because in the days of coal ranges, if you didn't have the "morning wood" to light the fire there would be no cuppa', no porridge or whitebait fritters in saseon! and no water for a bath." (Valerie Young); ca1920's (R. Mason) Kindling for lighting the fire in the morning. ca1983 Sept Canvastown : `the morningwood's too wet' - said of difficulty in lighting the Trout Hotel open fire at 5.00 pm.
Citations
Date:  0/0/1959
Source:  Greymouth Evening Star
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Dad used to split thin wood and place it up the chimney to dry for morning's wood and often that wood caught fire.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary)
Author:  McARA
Vol / Page:  328
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Mortar-box</i>: The large cast-iron box fitted with heavy cast-iron dies in which five head of 1250 lb stamps dropped 110 times per minute on to the quartz, reducing it to pulp which passed 10-mesh screens at the rate of about 7 tons per 24 hours. There was a constant flow of water through the box which carried away the crushed material through the screens for classification and further grinding in the tube-mills.

mossbank
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: mounds of partly decayed vegetable matter lying on the soil surface to a depth of up to ten feet or more, formed in much the same way as peat and common in former forestland.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  20/9/1916
Source:  NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page:  198
Edition:
Quote:  The Catlins District Mossbanks: In the Catlins district, South Otago, there are large tracts of country more or less covered with what is known as "mossbank." These mossbanks are mounds or heaps of partly decayed vegetable matter lying on the surface of the soil and varying in depth from 1 ft to 10 ft or more.  The acidity of mossbanks is very marked .. Under all mossbanks is to be found a hard pan at varying depths, and generally of undulating formation.
Notes:

mother country
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: England; later, Britain, the UK. Used as a sentimental expatriates' term from almost the beginning of settlement, and as an indication of the nature of the ties of loyalty to Britain. Since WW2 would, I think, be generally regarded as too sentimental for born-Kiwi use, and more suited to recent, unassimilated immigrants. Cf. Home
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

mother up
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition:  to match motherless lambs with lambless ewes


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  15/6/1956
Source:  NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page:  296
Edition:
Quote:  Wherever ewes are lambing there will always be lambs to mother up.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1953
Source:  Breakfast at Six
Author:  SCOTT
Vol / Page:  146
Edition:
Quote:  Whenever he brings a lamb in, he insists on mothering it up to some other ewe as soon as he can.
Notes:

Date:  15/5/1945
Source:  NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page:  502
Edition:
Quote:  I mother up more than 100 lambs each year and rarely lose more than six this way. I put the ewe and lamb in a catching pen for a day or so to start with, and in difficult cases tether the ewe to a fence for a while.
Notes:

mother up
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition:  [ewes and lambs] to reunite after being moved or after a docking muster.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1964
Source:  Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock
Author:  MILLS ET AL
Vol / Page:  85
Edition:
Quote:  ..after getting them [ewes and lambs] over, be sure to wait a while to give them a chance to mother-up and string quietly away.
Notes:

Date:  8/2/1956
Source:  Weekly News
Author:
Vol / Page:  45
Edition:
Quote:  I was to keep them [sc. sheep] there until dark to "mother-up".
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1958

Author:  STEVENS
Vol / Page:  48
Edition:
Quote:  This reduced number is less difficult to provide with shelter during a storm, is easier to mother up and present fewer difficulties in shedding the ewes and lambs on to saved pasture or green feed, while tailing mobs can be built up with ease.

Date:  0/0/1966

Quote:  Some farmers allow the ewes with the undrafted lambs to mother-up in a holding paddock near the yards.

Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition:  a lambing paddock [where ewes and young lambs from larger station blocks are kept.]

mothering pen
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a small sheep pen used for matching a motherless lamb with a lambless ewe, or a lamb with a reluctant ewe mother.

mothering up
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition:  a matching or reunion of natural ewe and lamb in a large mob of sheep and lambs [especially after a muster, docking.]


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]

mothering-on
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the matching of motherless lamb and lambless ewe by enclosing both in a small pen [often with the dead lamb's skin over the adoptee].


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1964
Source:  Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock
Author:  MILLS ET AL
Vol / Page:  94
Edition:
Quote:  Mechanised inspection also permits several ewes and lambs to be transported to the home environs where the job of mothering-on may receive closer attention. Another mothering-on method where fences are at a premium is to screw or drive auger-shaped fence standards into the ground to which the ewe may be tied.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1987
Source:  People, Places & Paddocks
Author:  GORDON
Vol / Page:  58
Edition:
Quote:  For the old shepherds, the best method of mothering on was to skin the dead lamb and fit this coat over the new one.
Notes:

mottled kauri
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a valued variety of kauri or totara timber that presents a mottled appearance. -->1882 Hay


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1882
Source:  Brighter Britain
Author:  HAY
Vol / Page:  2/189
Edition:
Quote:  Mottled totara is as much esteemed for cabinet work as mottled kauri. Some of the largest and soundest kauri timber has richly mottled shading, which appears to be an abnormal growth, due to the bark being entangled in the ligneous growth, causing shaded parts, broad and narrow, according as the timber is cut relative to their planes. This makes a rich and valuable furniture wood, and in the market is known as `mottled kauri'.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1925
Source:  Allen Adair
Author:  MANDER
Vol / Page:  61
Edition:  1971
Quote:  Besides this, Peter picked out as a gift mottled kauri for the front room and the ceiling and some fine bits of bird's-eye totara for the doors and cupboards. [also <i>mottling</i>]
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1888
Source:  Kaipara and Waitemata Echo
Author:  BARLOW
Vol / Page:  113
Edition:
Quote:  Mottled Kauri trees are usually found in rocky situations.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1875
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  7/376
Edition:
Quote:  <i>On Mottled Kauri</i>. by James Stewart, C.E.
Notes:

Vol / Page:  92
Edition:
Quote:  Mottled Moray (spotted moray, saw-toothed moray).. Common around the offshore islands from the Bay of Islands north... The only species of moray that is aggressive enough to stand its ground when approached by a diver and if provoked will make a lightning fast bite before retreating.

Quote:  Motunau Coal, Canterbury Plains, resembles that of Massacre Bay in its general character, but ignites more readily, and burns with less smoke; it contains a great quantity of sulphur but no traces of bituminous matter; its residue is composed of hard clinkers of brownish colour, and of powdery charcoal-like substance.

Mount Cook buttercup
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: <i>Ranunculus lyallii</i>, an alpine plant
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Environment
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: also known as giant buttercup
Citations
Date:  0/11/2002
Source:  Forest & Bird
Author:
Vol / Page:  306/2
Edition:
Quote:  The giant buttercup <i>R. lyallii</i> grows from Kahurangi National Park south to Stewart Island... [Alan Mark]described the 1973 distribution of <i>Ranunculus lyallii</i> - the world's largest buttercup - as follows: 'Introduced game animals have caused its decline to that large plants now tend to be restricted to inaccessible bluffs.'

Date:  11/2/1988

Author:
Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:  During Victorian times Ranunculus lyalli,

the Mt Cook or Mountain Buttercup, was

known in England as the "Rockwood

Lily."... The exact connection between

the "Rockwood Lily" and a Canterbury

sheep station presents an interesting

puzzle... Rockwood Station, owned by

Henry Phillips, was one of the earliest

established homesteads... However, the

precise connection with Rockwood.. has

yet to be discovered.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1907
Source:  Plants of NZ
Author:  LAING & BLACKWELL
Vol / Page:  166
Edition:  1940, p. 175
Quote:  <i> Ranunculus Lyallii (Lyall's Ranunculus)</i> ... The plant is known to colonists as the Mountain, Shepherd's, or Mount Cook Lily. The name is [167] most inappropriate, as the plant is not a lily, but a large white buttercup. However, any large-leaved herbaceous native plant is called by the colonists a lily, especially if it has white flowers.

Notes:

mountain
Homonym Number:
Word Class: adjective
Sense Number:
Definition: as a distinguishing epithet with names of plants often merely translates the specific <i>alpinus, montana</i>, etc. rather than originating in a general observation expressing itself in a given vernacular descriptive term: e.g. <i>Phyllocladus alpinus,</i> mountain toa toa -->a. chiefly botanical (rather than popular) uses include MOUNTAIN -BUTTERCUP, -COTTONWOOD, -FOXGLOVE, -HOLLY, -LANCEWOOD, -PALM, -PIRIPIRI, -TREE-DAISY, -TWITCH, WINEBERRY; b. popular (often local) uses distinguishing alpine or sub-alpine species include: (though often the vernacular name may have originally been botanically given.) e.g. MOUNTAIN-BEECH, MOUNTAIN-PINE, MOUNTAIN-RIBBONWOOD. (see Andersen Popular Names of NZ Plants Tr NZI; and 1933 Acland.) -->for animals see DUCK, KIWI, MINNOW, PARROT, TROUT -->as a distinguishing epithet in the names of plants see AKEAKE, ASTELIA, ASTER, BEECH; BEECH, SOUTHERN; BIRCH, BLADDERWORT, BUTTERCUP; BUTTERCUP, YELLOW; CABBAGE-TREE, CASSINIA, CEDAR; PINE, CELERY; CLUB-MOSS, COTTONWOOD, COTULA, CURRANT, DAISY, DANTHONIA, EVERLASTING; FERN, FILMY; FERN, SHIELDFERN; FERN TREE-FERN; FERN UMBRELLA; FLAX, FORGET-ME-NOT, FOXGLOVE, GENTIAN, GRASS, OAT-GRASS; GRASS, TWITCH; HOLLY, HYPERICUM, IVY-TREE, KOROKIO, LANCEWOOD, LILY, MARGUERITE, MOP, MUSK, MYRRH, PALM, PANAX, PINE; PINE, CELERY; PIRIPIRI, PRIMULA, RATA, RIBBONWOOD, RIMU, SEDGE, SNOWBERRY; TAUHINU, TAWHEOWHEO, TOATOA, TOETOE, TOTARA, TREE-DAISY; TUSSOCK-GRASS; TUTU UNCINIA, VIOLET, WILLOW-HERB, WINEBERRY


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Date:  0/0/1918
Source:  NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/308
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Fagus cliffortioides.</i> - This tree much resembles <i>F. Solandri</i>, but it is found generally only at high altitudes; it is unlikely to be of much value as a timber, though it is of great use to retard soil-erosion. The most suitable name for it is `mountain-beech.'
Notes:  (E. Phillips Turner)

Date:  0/0/1906
Source:  Manual NZ Flora
Author:  CHEESEMAN
Vol / Page:  643
Edition:
Quote:  <i>F. Cliffortioides, Hook.f</i>. ... A small tree, usually from 20 ft. to 40 ft. high ... Mountain districts ... <i>Tawhai-rauriki; Mountain Beech or Birch. </i>

Vol / Page:  10
Edition:  1979
Quote:  Usually it is silver beech with small toothed leaves but in the drier areas, especially Canterbury, eastern Nelson and Marlborough in the South Island and on the highly porous soils of the volcanic plateau in the North Island, silver beech [<i>Nothofagus solandri </i>var. <i>cliffortioides</i>] is replaced by mountain beech with small, smoothed-edged leaves.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks
Author:  DAWSON
Vol / Page:  121
Edition:
Quote:  Five species of <i>Nothofagus</i> were formerly recognised in New Zealand, but more recently two of these have been combined as varieties of one species. ... <i>Nothofagus solandri</i> var. <i>cliffortioides:</i> mountain beech (grows mainly at higher altitudes than other beeches).
Notes:

Vol / Page:  186, 188
Edition:
Quote:  As we ascend the character of the vegetation changes, the mountain beech [fn <i>Fagus cliffortioides.</i>] replaces that of lower altitudes, and the undergrowth consists largely of the alpine celery pine [fn <i>Phyllocladus alpinus</i>.], an almost unique member of the order <i>Coniferae</i>, with the [188] customary needle-like leaves replaced by flattened leaf-like branches, ...

Notes:  The house nestles under a forest of Mountain Birch, so-called, but really a beech, with very small leaves, ...

Date:  0/0/1884
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  17/298
Edition:
Quote:  <i> [Notho]fagus Cliffortioides</i>, Hook. f. ... Mountain beech. Black Birch of portions of Wellington, Canterbury, Otago and Southland. White Birch of Nelson, and in part of Otago and Southland. Barely distiguished by the woodman from Entire-leaved beech. The mountain beech bears a close resemblance to the entire-leaved beech in general appearance, although it never attains the extreme dimensions of that species.]
Notes:  (Kirk, NZ Beeches)

As adjective, often used as part of the name of a species found in the back country, mostly smaller than their down-country relatives, e.g. m. pine, totara, minnow, duck (blue duck), daisy, lily (Mount Cook lily). (C.)  [M. musk, used for flavouring tobacco, is Celmisia novae-zelandiae A.W.]

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks
Author:  DAWSON
Vol / Page:  156
Edition:
Quote:  On the more sheltered aspects, so-called mountain flax (<i>Phormium cookianum</i>) may form a close cover <i>Ibid.</i> 181 The term `flax' for the genus <i>Phormium</i>, although firmly established, is yet another inappropriate common name as <i>Phormium</i> and true linen flax

(<i>Linum</i>) have in common only the possession of useful fibres. Mountain flax is <i>Phormium cookianum</i> and its tufts of narrow, leathery leaves may be conspicuous in poorly drained places in tussock herbfield and shrubland.

Sense Number:

Quote:  (And)<i> Ranunculus Lyallii </i> mountain lily
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1889
Source:  Art Album NZ Flora
Author:  FEATON
Vol / Page:  6
Edition:
Quote:  RANUNCULUS LYALLI ...The `SHEPHERDS' OR MOUNTAIN LILY'. ... It is indigenous to the Middle Island ... at an elevation of 2000 to 3000 feet ... It has been named by the shepherds of Otago the `Water Lily' on account of its fancied resemblance to that plant. <i> Ranunculus godleyanus </i> ... The most graphic description would fail to give any adequate idea ... of the purity and charm of these Alpine Flowers [sc the white <i> R. Lyalli </i>] growing ... side by side with the yellow Mountain Lily  (<i> R. Godleyanus </i>), and interspersed with Alpine marygolds (<i> Senecios </i>) and the little star-like <i> Montias </i>.... the shepherds or Mountain Lily ... <i>Ranunculus Lyalli.</i>

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1900
Source:  Canterbury Old & New
Author:
Vol / Page:  203
Edition:
Quote:  On both sides [of the Southern Alps] grows the sub-alpine vegetation in all its beauty. You may walk knee-deep in Mountain Lilies, you may pick Edelweiss [fn] by the handfull [sic]; the air at a certain season of the year is full of the fragrance of the Alpine Broom [fn 2]. [fn] The Mountain Lily is ... a buttercup, and the Edelweiss does not belong to the same genus as its European namesake.  [fn 2] <i> Carmichaelia grandiflora </i>, var.<i> alba </i>.


Notes:  L.Cockayne

Date:  0/0/1906
Source:  Manual NZ Flora
Author:  CHEESEMAN
Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:  [<i> R. Lyallii, Hook.f.</i>] It has received many local names, as the `mountain lily', `shepherd's lily', `Mount Cook lily', &c.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1907
Source:  Plants of NZ
Author:  LAING & BLACKWELL
Vol / Page:  166
Edition:  1940 p. 175
Quote:  <i> Ranunculus Lyallii (Lyall's Ranunculus)</i> ... The plant is known to colonists as the Mountain, Shepherd's, or Mount Cook Lily. The name is [167] most inappropriate, as the plant is not a lily, but a large white buttercup. However, any large-leaved herbaceous native plant is called by the colonists a lily, especially if it has white flowers.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1910
Source:  NZ Plants

Date:  4/11/1933

Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  As adjective, often used as part of the name of a species found in the back country, mostly smaller than their down-country relatives, e.g. <i> m.</i> pine, totara, minnow, duck (blue duck), daisy, lily (Mount Cook lily). (C.) [M. musk, used for flavouring tobacco, is Celmisia novae-zelandiae A.W.]

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
Author:  McLINTOCK
Vol / Page:  2/680
Edition:
Quote:  English names of animals and plants are sometimes mistakenly applied. the great buttercup of the alps, <i> Ranunculus lyalli </i>, is called the mountain lily; the indigenous black nightshade, <i> Solanum nigrum </i> is often called deadly nightshade which is a very different species.

mountain mop
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: <i>Dracophyllum traversii</i>, neinei


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/8/1946
Source:  Bulletin of the Wgtn Botanical Soc.
Author:
Vol / Page:  14/8
Edition:
Quote:  R. Mason notes: f. tufts of leaves at end of bare branches. In use amongst Canterbury Mountaineers. I first heard it 1943, at first aquaintance with a Canterbury mountaineer and the plant in the field together.
Notes:

Date:  0/9/1958
Source:  Tararua
Author:
Vol / Page:  30
Edition:
Quote:  It is unnecessary to write at length in general of New Zealand plant names, but mention may be made of the <i>Tararua dishmop</i> and the <i>mountain mop</i>. Apparently the first is given to <i>Raoulia  tenuicaulis</i>, one of the scabweeds, by Heretaunga Tramping Club. No doubt plenty of Tararuas have used it with sand or ashes to clean out a billy, little thinking that their actions might inspire a new plant name, given to it by Canterbury mountaineers apparently, from the tufts of leaves at the ends of the branches.
Notes:  Ruth Mason `Track and Trail

Date:  0/0/1961
Source:  Flora NZ
Author:  MARTIN
Vol / Page:  227
Edition:  1929
Quote:  This might be described as a miniature of the MOUNTAIN MOP or NEI-NEI (D. traversii).
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1961
Source:  Flora NZ
Author:  MARTIN
Vol / Page:  227
Edition:  1929
Quote:  This might be described as a miniature of the MOUNTAIN MOP or NEI-NEI (D. traversii).
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1988

Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  74
Edition:
Quote:  <i>mountain mop Dracophyllum traversii </i>plants used by trampers in Canterbury area as cleaner for pots and billies. (Cf Tararua dishmop.)

Vol / Page:  218
Edition:
Quote:  This shelter [on the Karangarua River, Westland] we named `Musk Camp', because here our only firewood was mountain musk, as it is generally called. It is a shrub of the myrtle species, of a sage green colour, and grows to a height of four feet [only above 2500 ft level].
Notes:

Source:  Plants of NZ
Author:  LAING & BLACKWELL
Vol / Page:  446

Quote:  South Island: sub-alpine scrub ... Mountain musk, Incense-plant. ... <i>Olearia moschata (The Musky Olearia)</i> ... Mountain musk, Incense-plant. <i>O. nummularifolia</i> is another species of the sub-alpine scrub.

mountain mutton
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: venison (in the days when espec. commercial shooting or use was a punishable offence)
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1900
Source:  Reminiscences
Author:  ELVY
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  It pulled up at the Pelorus Hotel, Canvastown, and ... the travellers went to the dining room, where mine host, Tom Dillon, presided at the head of a long table and carved the joints. `What'll you have, beef or mountain mutton?' he asked. ... The young man gave his order ... and was served with slices of juicy, tender venison. In those days deer were protected, to be shot only in season, and under licence, so what the travellers ate was poached. It was a feature of the hotel, under mountain mutton.
Notes:  [ca1900] W.J. Elvy Reminiscences in 1953 Millar High Noon (1965) 88

Notes:

mountain oysters
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: lamb testicles [boiled or roasted over fire out-of-doors along with lambs tails and regarded as a great delicacy at the completion of a docking day.] [occ. used for other animals.]


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author:  MCGILL
Vol / Page:  73
Edition:
Quote:  mountain oysters: lamb testicles, for some a gourmet delight.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1994
Source:  From Drover to Director
Author:  PLUMMER
Vol / Page:  35
Edition:
Quote:  We also had a frying pan and when we knocked off for lunch, as well as boiling the billy, we would fill the frying pan up with lambs balls, which the best people called 'mountain oysters.' The mountain oysters went down very well with most of us .. Jim Case took a poor view of those mountain oysters.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Loughnan Glossary
Author:  LOUGHNAN
Vol / Page:  54
Edition:
Quote:  mountain oysters: testicles of young lambs, saved at tailing time. Rural gourmets consider them not unlike an oyster in flavour.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1993
Source:  Station Country I
Author:  HOLDEN
Vol / Page:  35

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  304
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Mountain-Trout, n.</i> species of <i>Galaxias</i>, small cylindrical fishes inhabiting the colder rivers of Australasia, Southern Chile, Magellan Straits and the Falkland Islands. On account of the distribution of these fish and of other forms of animals, it has beeen suggested that in a remote geological period the area of land above the level of the sea in the antarctic regions must have been sufficiently extended to admit of some kind of continuity across the whole width of the Pacific between the southern extremities of South America and Australia.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1899

Author:
Vol / Page:  31/88
Edition:

Quote:  The correct name of the Mountain Trout or Black Kokopu is <i>Galaxias argenteus</i> Gmelin and the Barred Trout or Kokopu is apparently the young, with conspicuous markings.
Notes:  (Whitley and Phillipps)

Date:  0/0/1945
Source:  Maori Place-Names of Canterbury
Author:  BEATTIE
Vol / Page:  63
Edition:
Quote:   Koukoupara - is a fish like the kokopu, but differently marked, and following the example of one of his informants, the translator [sc Beattie] has translated this as `mountain trout'. Koukoupara is the spelling adopted in the lists, but the [Maori] compilers have varied this with kopara, koupara, and kokaupara. Never once do they use the southern form of kokopara, which the southerners pronounced kokobala, which the early settlers soon turned into `cockabully'.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1956
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  GRAHAM
Vol / Page:  399
Edition:

Author:
Vol / Page:  Second Series 2/16
Edition:
Quote:  THE MOUNTED RIFLEMAN [title] New Zealanders in these regions are popularly referred to, in their Homeland, as `The Mounteds'; and as being indicative of their pecularities in method of warfare, the term has its value. In origin, the Mounted Riflemen date back to the 'sixties, when that fine soldier, Major Sir Harry Atkinson, formed the settler-riflemen into a mounted force of a nature demanded by the topographical and tactical conditions of the fiercely-contested Maori wars.

mouther
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: one who tells a sheep's age from its mouth
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  1/10/1863
Source:  Chudleigh Diary
Author:
Vol / Page:  105
Edition:  1950
Quote:  [We] began mouthing sheep. Polhill who has bought the run and the sheep took down the mouths on paper as the sheep are to be paid for according to their ages. ... You catch a sheep in your arms, carry it to the gate where the mouther stands, hold the mouth open for him to look at and you at the same time call out two, four, six, full or whatever it may be. ... The mouther has to be very quick and catch the mouth at once and put a dot under whatever age it may come on paper. So you know the number age sex etc. of your whole mob.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Fisherman's Bible
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  118
Edition:
Quote:  Most gurnards are brownish-red but larger specimens are often bright red on top and white below. The Stargazer is sometimes known as the Mud Gurnad, River Gurnard or Mud-Grubber Gurnard but is in fact no relation. Similarly the Sea Perch is sometimes called a Rock Gurnard - ... <i>Ibid.</i> 208 STARGAZER A distinctive estuarine fish which spends most of its life buried in mud up to the eyes. ... Comes in two varieties - the Common Stargazer and his tubbier cousin the Spotted Stargazer. ... Other names are River Gurnard, Mud Gurnard, Flathead Gurnard and Mud Grubber.

Date:  0/0/1970
Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
Author:  SORENSON
Vol / Page:  37
Edition:
Quote:  <i>MONKFISH </i>(a) Scientific name: (i)<i> Geniagnus monopterygius</i> (ii) <i>Kathetostoma giganteum.</i> (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (both) Whitefish. (c) Other common names: (both) Monkfish, Monks, Stargazer, Flathead (also applied at times to export gurnard); Churchills, Toebiters, Bulldogs, Spotted Stargazer, Maori Chief (Dunedin); Muddies. (d) Principal localities where taken: Napier, Cook Strait, Nelson, Banks Peninsula, Bluff-Stewart Island. ... Monkfish is a general term for species of the Families Uranoscopidae and Leptoscopidiae.

mudfish

(Neochanna apoda). It is usually found in

rivers when they are in flood.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1873
Source:  Birds of New Zealand
Author:  BULLER
Vol / Page:  237
Edition:
Quote:  ... he produced a dish of water containing some `mudfish' which [the Bittern] instantly ... devoured. This singular fish (named by Dr. Gu[dieresis]nther <i>Neochanna apoda</i>) is very common in the Hokitika district, being found in all the creeks and surface-ponds in the woods ...On the pools becoming dry these mudfish burrow into the moist soil or clay, ... remaining there for an indefinite time, or until the return of the rainy weather rendered their pools habitable again.

Vol / Page:  305

Quote:  <i>Mud-fish, n.</i> a fish of Westland, New Zealand,  <i>Neochanna apoda</i>. Gunth. Gunther says <i>Neochanna</i> is a `degraded form of Galaxias [see <i>Mountain-Trout</i>], from which it differs by the absence of ventral fins. This fish has hitherto been found only in burrows which it excavates in clay or consolidated mud, at a distance from water.'

mug
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: (to make) preliminary love-play; pet
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca 1940 at least Wellington (The term <i>mug</i> etc is now obsolescent (perhaps obsolete) except in the occas. slang use <i>muck up</i>. It was most popular in the begining of the 20c up to, say, the 1930's. The common sense now (1984) is `to rob with violence'.)

muka
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the prepared fibre of New Zealand flax


Origin: Maori
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1840
Source:  Manners & Customs of the NZers
Author:  POLACK
Vol / Page:  1/175
Edition:
Quote:  The flax (<i>korari</i>,) forming the dresses is of two or [176] three kinds; the most coarse, called muka, is employed for working the common garment (<i>kakaou</i>[a1-acute] <i>maori</i>[a-acute].) This flax is also made use of for laying up ropes, lines, &c. The superior dress called Kaitaka[a2-a3-acute], is made from silken flax, <i>(hunga hunga</i>[as-acute].)
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1869
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/III/48
Edition:
Quote:  Muka of the natives, as the dressed fibre of the Harakeke, or Flax Plant)
Notes:  (Colenso Botany North Isd)

Date:  0/0/1870
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  2/117
Edition:
Quote:  The Korari is the name of the flower stalk, often, but wrongly, used as the name of the plant. The edible root is the Aruhe. The word `Muka' is commonly applied to the dressed fibre; it is the correct name for the inner leaves. Cleared bush-land is suitable for the cultivation of the flax plant, and even swamp-land is improved by drainage. In the various flax swamps near nelson ...the finest plants grow upon the soil that has been thrown out of the ditch ...
Notes:  (Heaphy NZ Flax)

Date:  17/3/1931
Source:  Na To Hoa Aroha
Author:
Vol / Page:  2/128
Edition:  1987
Quote:  The renovation of `Rangiatea' is a much bigger undertaking. ... The wall tukutuku are about 16 feet high while in the gables they run up to 30 feet. The old fellows must have put in a lot of thought to piece together such lengths against a real kakaho backing, with muka [ed fn: Prepared flax] binding to keep the whole in position. To keep the horizontals from sagging with the sheer weight of the material the muka binding was passed through holes bored into the edges of the poupou - an adaption of the rauawa technique.
Notes:  (Ngata)

Date:  0/9/2005
Source:  Air New Zealand inflight magazine
Author:
Vol / Page:  12
Edition:
Quote:  Aesthetically beautiful and entirely natural, the stunning Hapene range is exclusively designed and produced in Fielding, and uses a patented method to release the muka, or fibre, within the leaf.

Date:  0/0/1868
Source:  Contributions to NZ Botany
Author:  LINDSAY
Vol / Page:  82
Edition:
Quote:  In Otago the general name of the [flax] plant, as a whole, is `Korari,' - or as metamorphosed by the settler, pronounced and spelt `Kouradi,' [a-macron] or `Coradi' [a-macron]. The same term is applied in the North Island equally to the whole plant, and to the dried flower-stem when cut for rafts or other purposes; or exclusively to the flower-stalk. In the North [83] Island, the Flax-plant is also known as `Harakeke,' or `Herekiakia,' - its usual name there. ... The lower part of the flower-stem is `Kaikaha;' the outer part of the leaf `Parakoka;' [a1, o-macron] the refuse of the leaf `Hunga-hunga;' the flax, dressed or not, or scraped fibre, manufactured from the leaf, `Whitau,' or `Muka.'
Notes:

Date:  0/0/2007
Source:  Ask the Posts
Author:  Ihimaera
Vol / Page:  252
Edition:
Quote:  'You will need stitches,' Paraiti says. She makes a thread of muka and uses a wooden needle to sew the wound.

Date:  22/7/1984
Source:  Guardian Weekly, The
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Under his tutelage New Zealand learned to live beyond its means as it had never done before, to such an extent that nobody seems to know quite how large its total foreign debt has become, except that it is certainly huge and may be a per capita world record. Its welfare state, which has often been held up as an example to the world, was allowed to swell as its traditional and all-important agricultural markets shrank. As the budget deficit widened, Sir Robert became an apparently immovable fixture, the political Mr Micawber of the southern hemisphere. Now the voters have awoken to the unreal nature of what long since became known to them as `Muldoonism', its creator and chief exponent could not bring himself to accept his stinging defeat, like many another unseated authoritarian before him.

mullein
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: also called Aaron's rod, flannel-leaf, tobacco plant, tobacco weed; any of several plants of dry soils and riverbeds, having a rod-like stem rising from a rosette of woolly, flannel-like leaves and ending in a shaft of yellow flowers.


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1926
Source:  Weeds of New Zealand
Author:  HILGENDORF
Vol / Page:  155
Edition:  1967
Quote:  FLANNEL LEAF (<i>Verbascum thapsus</i>) is commonly called mullein in England, and is frequently so called here as well. Its commonest local name is probably tobacco plant, or native tobacco, a name for which there is no justification in either appearance or use. Velvet mullein woolly mullein, golden rod, and Aaron's rod are other appellations, but flannel leaf, one of the common sheep-station names is both descriptive and distinctive. The plant is found in dry soil and river beds ... in both islands.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1969
Source:  Standard Common Names for Weeds
Author:
Vol / Page:  51
Edition:
Quote:  <i> mullein [=] moth mullein: white mullein: woolly mullein</i> [s]
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1973
Source:  Unreturning Native
Author:  DOWLING
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  By the dusty roads are blues and yellows and reds/ Of bugloss and furred mullein, stonecrop and centaury,/
Notes:  (`By Lake Wanaka')

mullet
Homonym Number:

Definition: a fish
Origin: [none]
Register:
