Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: also muddy fish, settler
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1897
Source:  AJHR
Author:
Vol / Page:  H-17/2
Edition:
Quote:   This variety of mullet [which feeds in the ocean and shoals along the coast] is known to the fishermen and the [Northland] settlers as the `clean-gut', `clean-run', or `sea-mullet'. ... The other variety [which stays in the harbour] is known to the fishermen as the `settler' or muddy fish'. When opened they are not clean and bright ... but full of slimy mud ...


Notes:   (Hector Protection of Mullet)

Date:  6/1/1894

Author:  CARTER
Vol / Page:  101
Edition:
Quote:  The name of mullet-boats dates back to the very early days of New Zealand's colonization, and although there is no record for the first boat which was built in Auckland, there is sufficient evidence to say the type was evolved somewhere  about the year 1880.  The boats were designed for a specific purpose, the netting of mullet which abound in the shallow tidal reaches, creeks and estuaries of the Hauraki Gulf, and its environs.

mullibar
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: psg molly-bar, mully-bar cf mulabar
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1972
Source:  Folkgames of Children
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  174
Edition:
Quote:  Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies

got stuck in the mullock, when it was

first spread, before it had dried.

See:

Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1879
Source:  Spangles and Sawdust
Author:  WHITWORTH
Vol / Page:  5
Edition:
Quote:  I was down there with Old Ashmore's lot, doing the trampoline, and so on; but things was very quizby. Everything went crooked somehow, and the gorger had a hawful cramp in his kick. Well, ramp was the word, and vamose we did, the lot on us; some here, some there. I was reg'lar beached, and I tell you when a cove 'as to spout his smish it's about time to look out. However, I got a job at a livery stable, but although that kep' me in grub, and I slep' in a spare stall, the billet was very multy, and I kep' on the kivvy for something better. [fn] 1. [trampoline] Vaulter. 2. [quizby] Bad. 3. [crooked] Wrong. 4. [cramp in his kick] Emptiness in his pockets. 5. [ramp] Clear out. 6. [vamose] Go. 7. [beached] Hard up. 8. [smish] Shirt. 9. [multy] No good. 10. [kivvy] Look out (qui vive.)
Notes:

Date:  21/9/1907
Source:  NZ Truth
Author:
Vol / Page:  118/5/1
Edition:
Quote:  This was the multy show that was so roughly dealt with in `Truth' some months ago.
Notes:

Mum
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: (rarely <i>mother</i>) a boarding-school nickname for a fussy, maternal, and, usually kind hearted, boy who takes an interest in smaller or younger boys
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca 1941 St Patrick's College, Silverstream
Citations
Mum
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: the missus, the old woman, the wife, espec. in hotel bars (`No more for me; I'm going home to mum'), and sometimes used as a general name and form of address for a publican's wife, especially in country pubs (ca 1920 at least: J.Columbus; ca 1940-50, Marlborough)

(These uses are not of course related to the English servant's, etc, use of mum as a vulgar variant of <i>ma'am</i> (P: 19-20c) see Barker


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]

Notes:

munga
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: [The word was adopted during WW2, and survived a few years in NZ after, say, 1950, but is now (1984) Italian<i>mangiare</i> etc; perhaps from, or reinforced by, French <i>manger</i> (cf WW1 <i>mungey</i> `food', probably from French). It is unlikely that Maori <i>maanaga</i>, the remains of food (after a meal) influenced the Army use, except perhaps, the sense I given by Partridge, which I have not recorded from elsewhere. It may, however, helped to give the NZ use `a Maori shape', as Partridge says; but I am not aware of Maori <i>maanga</i>ing any currently in NZ English in spite of Davins spelling.]

Date:  19/5/2003
Source:  Personal Communication
Author:  RUD WARD
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Munter: Most commonly male. Below average intelligence. Buffoon. Little regard for what others think of him. Liable to do stupid things at regular intervals. Finds these acts humorous ... Munter means to me: male, generally has a mullet [type of haircut] and drives around in a classic car, sometimes hangs off rafters at certain Ponsonby bars, has also been known to go jet-skiing in the early morning munted [=pissed]... Usually sells weed [<i>cannabis indica</i>, as I'm sure you'll know!]. Ex-painters are automatically classified as munters. [God knows why!!] Will have a strong preference for Fords or Holdens. [Again God knows why!]
Notes:  Collected by his 26-year old son from his contemporaries

He bares his gum, and through the crumbs I see two bleeding holes which lately housed two obstinate baby teeth.

Vol / Page:  68
Edition:
Quote:  <i>murder house</i>: At most large schools, and for each collection of small ones, there is a small prefabricated building set slightly apart in which you can find one or more School Dental Nurses who do all of the preventive, and most of the corrective dental work (free) for the children in their schools. The children, unlike you and I?, consider a visit to the SCHOOL DENTAL CLINIC an unpleasant necessity, at best. Hence the name.

Date:  0/0/1939
Source:  Outside the Law
Author:  BELTON
Vol / Page:  28
Edition:
Quote:  Each player paid two shillings for a numbered wooden marble which the banker would throw from a basket container which he held in his hands and shook occasionally. The person receiving the marble with the highest number was paid the pool less banker's percentage .... The game, or rather gamble, was called Murrumbidgee which probably indicates, that it was originated, or at least was played, in that part of Australia [ca 1928].

Author:  BUDDLE
Vol / Page:  24
Edition:
Quote:  Now there is to be no `muru', <i>i.e</i>. no plundering to obtain <i>utu</i> for insult or wrong ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1863
Source:  Old New Zealand
Author:  MANING
Vol / Page:   (vii) 105
Edition:
Quote:  There were in the old times two great institutions, which reigned with iron rod in Maori land - the <i>Tapu</i> and the <i>Muru</i>. Pakehas who knew no better called the <i>muru</i> simply `robbery', because the word <i>Muru</i>, in its common signification, means to plunder. But I speak of the regular legalized and established system of plundering as penalty for offences, which in a rough way resembled our law by which a man is obliged to pay `damages'.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1878
Source:  Forty Years in NZ
Author:  BULLER
Vol / Page:  85
Edition:
Quote:   ... I heard that a <i>muru</i>, or robbery, had been perpetrated.

Edition:
Quote:  Another curious custom of the Maoris was the <i>muru</i>; the word means `plunder' - and some folks might call it robbery, ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1900
Source:  Canterbury Old & New
Author:
Vol / Page:  151
Edition:
Quote:  Death was not always the punishment that followed a violation of the law of tapu, sometimes a violation was visited by temporal punishment, in accordance with the institution of muru ... [The sick or unfortunate were] plundered of their worldly goods ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1904
Source:  Maori Race, The
Author:  TREGEAR
Vol / Page:  103
Edition:
Quote:  The plantations were far apart, for fear that either an enemy's war party or a friendly

plundering (<i>muru</i>) party might ruin the results ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1904
Source:  Maori Race, The
Author:  TREGEAR
Vol / Page:  139
Edition:
Quote:  A remarkable custom was that of `plunder' (<i>muru</i>). ... a method by which an offence was expiated. It consisted of a band of persons <i>taua</i> visiting the offender and stripping him of all his movable property, ... If a man allowed one of his boy children to get hurt, the tribe would <i>muru</i> the father for the [140] loss ... since the boy probably would have been a future warrior. ... <i>Ibid.</i> 141 Perhaps `damages' rather than `plunder' is the best translation of <i>muru</i>.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1840
Source:  Manners & Customs of the NZers
Author:  POLACK
Vol / Page:  1/202fn
Edition:
Quote:  Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales, called<i> para</i>[as-acute] <i>paraua</i>[a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale, <i>mungu nui</i> (black physeter); right whale, <i>tohora</i> (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis); sun-fish (diodon mola); large-lipped whale (balaena mysticetus); large-lipped whale (balaena musculus); hump-back (balaena gibbosa); shark, <i>mango</i> (squalus); hammer-head (zygaena); pilots, (scomber); flying-fish (exocaetus volitans); and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes.

mushy
Homonym Number:

Sense Number:  1
Definition: [wool] weathered; showing no pronounced staple or lacking character.

mussel
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an aquatic mollusc with two hinged shells, the edible, marine form of which attaches itself to rocks, etc.; in New Zealand, mainly <i>Mytilus</i> or <i>Perna</i> spp. Common salt-water kinds are a blue mussel, a green-lipped mussel (commercially farmed), and a large horse-mussel. mussel farming the cultivation of green-lipped mussels from ropes attached to rafts or buoys. See (or check) razor mussel, date mussel, horse mussel, green mussel, blue mussel, pipi 2, freshwater mussel.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/1/2001
Source:  Cuisine
Author:
Vol / Page:  133
Edition:
Quote:  Having lived for years in the south of France, he is at home there as anywhere, and equally at ease with a glass of Grand Cru Burgundy or a billy of mussels cooked on the beach over a driftwood fire.
Notes:

Date:  19/2/1994
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)

Vol / Page:  58

Quote:  Most of the others [sc. mussels] - flea mussels, mud mussels, date mussels and nesting mussels - are too small to be worthy of the pot.

Quote:  <i>Mussel. n</i>. Some Australasian species of this mollusc are <i>Mytilus latus</i>, Lamark., Victoria, Tasmania, and New Zealand; <i>M. tasmanicus</i>, Tension Woods, Tasmania; <i>M. rostratus, </i>Tasmania and Victoria; <i>M. hirsutus</i>, Lamark., Tasmania, South Australia, Victoria, New Zealand; <i>M. crassus</i>, Tenison-Woods, Tasmania. Fresh-water Mussels belong to the genus <i>Unio. </i>

Anim.</i>, p.30], a small Blenny, both caught under the rocks at low water mark; some Starfish, Coats of mail water spouts, Centipus, Muscles & Turbines, besides in the Evening a Lamprey ...

Source:  Cook's Journals
Author:
Vol / Page:  2/787
Edition:
Quote:  ... there are not wanting Several Sorts [of fish] that are well known; such as Mullet, Cavallas, Guard-Fish, Horse-Mackeral. Amongsyt the crustaceous Tribes we found Craw-fish, Muscles. [sic] Cockles, Scollops, Whelks, Periwinkles, ...
Notes:  1773 Wales Journal in Cook Journal (1961) 2/787

Date:  0/2/1777
Source:  Journal
Author:  ANDERSON
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  The rocks are abundantly furnish'd with great quantitys [sic] of excellent muscles, one sort of which that is not very common measures above a foot in length. ed. fn The `great quantitys' would be <i>Mytilus edulis aoteanus</i>; the `not very common' ones <i>Perna canaliculus</i>. If the latter were `above a foot in length' they must have been giants indeed: one of 7 inches would now been reckoned large. (HWO note: Could they have been `horse mussels' rather than `green-lip mussels'? Check)
Notes:  1777 Feb Anderson's Journal in Cook Journals (1967) 3/808 (Queen Charlotte Sound)

Author:  POLACK
Vol / Page:  1/202fn
Edition:
Quote:  Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks ... and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes.

Quote:  MUSSEL'S BEARD (<i>Sertularia bispinosa</i>). A yellowish-brown, fine, hair-like mass which grows commonly amongst low tidal sea-weeds, in rock pools and especially upon the shells of living mussels.
Notes:

Notes:

muster
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a round-up of livestock, especially sheep for shearing, etc. musterer, a person who musters sheep, etc. [Latin monstrare to show]
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See: also tailing muster
Pronunciation:
Notes: (The word seems to have been introduced to Canterbury) Acland (1933) notes the following musters on high-country stations. -->So far as I know the usual ones are (beginning in the spring): <i>the cutting and tailing muster; shearing</i> muster; <i>straggle</i> muster (in the old days the shorn sheep were always turned not before the country .us;was straggled, <i>so that they would lead the woolies in); dipping or wearing </i>m.; <i>straggle </i>again; then <i>scratch</i> m. or <i>`lock-over' </i>to get the last of the sheep off the summer country before winter. This last is an undress sort of muster, the men catching what stragglers they can in the basins. There are always other partical musters of the flock; e.g., ewes to ram, or eye-slipping of hoggets.
Citations
Date:  16/10/1912
Source:  Otago Witness
Author:
Vol / Page:  16
Edition:
Quote:  It knocks the sheep about too much to do

other than have one principal muster for

docking.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1878
Source:  Boy Colonists
Author:  ELWELL
Vol / Page:  172
Edition:
Quote:  The mode of mustering adopted by Ernest was this. .... He made a separate muster of each part [of the run]
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1878
Source:  Boy Colonists
Author:  ELWELL
Vol / Page:  172
Edition:
Quote:  The mode of mustering adopted by Ernest was this. .... He made a separate muster of each part [of the run]

Author:  KIERNAN
Vol / Page:

Quote:  Finlayson went to Arapawanui to try and get Atta for the muster.
Notes:  1879 Jan 13 T.C. Kiernan Diary in 1921 Guthrie-Smith Tutira 123

Date:  4/12/1879
Source:  Chudleigh Diary
Author:
Vol / Page:  282
Edition:  1950
Quote:  2404 sheep to be accounted for, which is either a most fearful number of deaths or the worst muster ever yet made.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1899
Source:  In the Shadow of the Bush
Author:  BELL
Vol / Page:  79
Edition:
Quote:  It was expected that a few of Morton's sheep might have got through the dividing fence since the last muster, ...
Notes:

Date:  27/1/1934
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Muster</i>.-A city correspondent asks for the names of the various musters on high country stations. So far as I know the usual ones are (beginning in spring): the cutting and tailing <i>m.</i>; shearing <i>m.</i>; straggle <i>m.</i>(in old days the shorn sheep were always turned out before the country was straggled, so that they would lead the woolies in); dipping or weaning <i>m.</i> (to wean the lambs and dip the ewes); fall (or autumn) m.; straggle again; then scratch <i>m.</i> or `look over' to get the last of the sheep off the summer country before winter. This last is an undress sort of <i>m.</i>, the men catching what stragglers they can in the basins. There are always other partial <i>ms</i>. of the flock; <i>e.g.</i>, ewes to ram or eye clipping of hoggets.
Notes:  Acland Gloss. additions

Date:  0/0/1841
Source:  Letter
Author:  REVANS
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  I am not yet confident of the mode in which flock and stock musters will be dealt with by the natives

As they complete each flock, it is turned over to a shepherd, who would drive it off with the aid of his dogs to a beat, possibly ten or twenty miles distant ...

Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Muster</i>.- To collect the sheep together on a block of country, for shearing,

drafting, or moving them. Hence <i>musterer</i>, a temporary shepherd engaged for <i>mustering</i>. The <i>musterers</i>, however, usually include the permanent shepherd and cadets as well. (C.)

mustering beat
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a particular area allotted to a musterer as his responsibility in a muster [usually specified as the top beat, middle beat and bottom beat.]

mustering dog
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a sheepdog trained to muster, hunt and head sheep.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  11/4/1968
Source:  NZ Farmer
Author:
Vol / Page:  45
Edition:
Quote:  .. Rose, also a black brindle, was a very useful, handy bitch destined to become one of the famed mustering dogs for that part of Canterbury.
Notes:

Date:  25/11/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Sheep dog</i>.- Dog to work sheep; <i>collie</i> (q.v.). <i>S.ds.</i> run naturally either to bring sheep towards you or to drive them away; and when a puppy shows his preference he is broken in for that work. The dogs that bring sheep are called <i>heading ds</i>. (q.v.) and most of these can be taught to <i>lead</i> (q.v.) if desired. Dogs which take to driving sheep away are broken in to <i>huntaway</i> and are called <i>htwys</i> (q.v.). Some dogs will both<i> hd</i>. and <i>htwy</i> and are called <i>handy ds</i>. They are not generally high-class heading dogs but very useful about hand and sometimes very useful mustering dogs. Some men have a special <i>slewing d</i>., but a well-trained, <i>hdg</i>. dog or <i>htwy</i>. will usually <i>slew</i> (q.v.). (C.)
Notes:  Acland Glossary

Date:  0/3/1907
Source:  NZ Farmer
Author:
Vol / Page:  209
Edition:

mustering stick
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:  a long stick, usually made of manuka [used by a musterer on steep shingle or sidlings and for crossing swift mountain rivers and jumping creeks.]

Edition:
Quote:  ... with his long mustering stick in his hand, he has a walking beat. ... Mustering sticks are usually nearly shoulder high and must be strong and tough and not too heavy. They are hard to get in some districts and a good one is carefully kept. Manuka is the commonest wood, but Miki-miki and Hazel are sometimes used.

Vol / Page:  188
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Mustering Stick</i>: When on the hill, high-country musterers carry a long walking-stick. Usually of manuka, it is about five feet long and is used for vaulting creeks etc. and as an aid to keeping balance when sidling sheep country. Also referred to as a nibby or pole.

Notes:

muttonbird
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: any of various seabirds whose young are taken for food (considered a delicacy because of their distinctive fishy flavour), especially the sooty shearwater or titi, Puffinus griseus, and in the North Island the grey-faced petrel or oi, Pterodroma macroptera gouldi.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Date:  20/7/1844
Source:  Nelson Examiner
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  The cottages in Stewart's Island are all well garnished with a luxury of the southward - the mutton bird. This I take to be the bird which is sometimes called the sheerwater, or the sooty petrel - a black bird about the size of a duck, with long wings, which all of us have seen on our voyage out skimming over the waves. In the month of December these birds resort to the cky islands about Foveaux's Straits in great numbers, for the purpose of breeding.
Notes:  1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson <i>Examiner</i> July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 254

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Birds of New Zealand
Author:  FALLA et al.
Vol / Page:  42
Edition:
Quote:  SOOTY SHEARWATER <i>Puffinus griseus Other names:</i> Muttonbird, Titi.




Notes:

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
Author:  McLINTOCK
Vol / Page:  2/616
Edition:
Quote:  MUTTONBIRD. Also known as the sooty shearwater or titi, the New Zealand muttonbird is <i>Puffinus griseus</i> and belongs to the order of sea birds known as petrels. As a name, `muttonbird' appears to have originated among early European settlers in Australasia and is said to refer to the taste of the flesh. At least as probable is the theory that the name refers to the rather woolly appearance of the downy young. In New Zealand other petrels are also given the name `muttonbird'. In fact, the sooty shearwater, which is most abundant on the islands about Foveaux Strait, might well be called the <i>southern</i> muttonbird, and the grey-faced petrel, predominant on the islands off the coast of Auckland Province,the <i>northern</i> muttonbird. In Victoria, Tasmania, Bass Strait, and South Australia, the species is the short-tailed shearwater - an occasional visitor to New Zealand seas.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1980
Source:  Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A
Author:  LELAND
Vol / Page:  68
Edition:
Quote:  <i>muttonbird</i>: The SOOTY SHEARWATER or puffinus grisens [sic ?=<i>Puffinus griseus</i>] is a petrel (type of seagull).
Notes:

Quote:  The great feature of the southern seas is the multitude of birds ... Huge albatrosses, molimorks (a smaller albatross), Cape hens, Cape pigeons, parsons, boobies, whale birds, mutton birds and many more, wheel continually about the ship's stern, ...

I have not yet been able to make much progress in negotiating, on behalf of the Government, with the Natives for the purchase of Stewart's Island, on account of the absence of many of the Natives interested, who are engaged catching titi (mutton birds), nor shall I be able to do much till they return.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  309
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Mutton-bird, n.</i> The word is ordinarily applied to the Antarctic Petrel, <i>Aestrelata lessoni.</i> In Australasia it is applied to the Puffin or Short-tailed Petrel, <i>Puffinus brevicaudus,</i> Brandt. The collection of the eggs of this petrel, the preparation of oil from it, the salting of its flesh for food, form the principal means of subsistence of the inhabitants, halfcaste and other, of the islands in Bass Straits. [1839 Aust]
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1855
Source:  Te Ika a Maui
Author:  TAYLOR
Vol / Page:  382
Edition:
Quote:  `The titi, or mutton-bird, is a seabird which goes inland at night just as the light wanes. The natives light a bright fire, behind which they sit, each armed with a long stick. The titis, attracted by the light, fly by in great number, and are knocked down as quickly as possible; thus in one night several hundreds are often killed, which they preserve in their own fat for future use.'
Notes:

Quote:  <i>mutton n</i>. ... -mutt'on-bird n. a migratory sea-bird of the Bass Strait.-mutt'on tree' n. a particular tree in which mutt'on-birds collect.- mutt'on-wood n. a shrub found in coastal areas visited by mutt'on-birds.

Vol / Page:  20
Edition:
Quote:  <i>MUTTON BIRDS</i> Mutton birds are rich in oil, containing vitamins, iodine and bone making material ... high medicinal value. The flesh is tender, and, when cooked, resembles the flesh of wild duck, the flavour being more akin to ... fish.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1952
Source:  Chatham Islands
Author:  RICHARDS
Vol / Page:  84
Edition:
Quote:  Muttonbirds were so called from their fancied flavour of mutton. The first known mention of the name is in a letter from an officer stationed on the newly-founded convict station on Norfolk Island. He writes in 1793 that the island swarms with muttonbirds so called by the convicts or sometimes bird sheep.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1958
Source:  Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn)
Author:
Vol / Page:  269
Edition:
Quote:  Mutton-bird An edible sea bird of Bass Strait and New Zealand. The Maori name is `titi'.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1961
Source:  Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page:  1493
Edition:
Quote:  <i>muttonbird n</i> : any of several Australasian sea birds often used (as by the Maori) for their meat, oil, and feathers: as<i> a</i> (1): a short-tailed shearwater<i> (Puffinus tenuirostris)</i> of Australia and New Zealand (2) : a sooty shear-water <i>(Puffinus griseus) </i>of New Zealand<i> b</i> : any of several petrels (as <i>Pterodroma macroptera, P. lessoni,</i> and <i>P. neglecta </i>

Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a mixed coastal scrub mainly of Stewart Island. (Stewart Island) <i>Olearea Colensoi<i/> and <i>Senecio rotundifolius</i> (both together or separately); also <i>mutton-bird shrub </i>

Notes:

Date:  0/3/2002
Source:  NZ Geographic
Author:
Vol / Page:  No. 56/79
Edition:
Quote:  On windswept Ackers Point, at the tip of the peninsula, the main vegetation is muttonbird scrub; muttonbirds (sooty shearwaters) nest in burrows beneath it in spring. The name "muttonbird scrub" has a derogatory ring to it, but the various tree daisies, with their white flowers and tough leathery leaves, furry white beneath, that fall under the muttonbird rubric are all beautiful shrubs.

Date:  0/0/1840
Source:  Manners & Customs of the NZers
Author:  POLACK
Vol / Page:  1/202 fn
Edition:
Quote:  Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales, called <i>para</i> [as-acute] <i>paraua</i> [a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus).. ; and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes. <i>Ibid.</i> 2/286 Pearl shell may be obtained from the Pawa or Mutton-fish
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1842
Source:  New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author:  HEAPHY
Vol / Page:  48
Edition:
Quote:  The native method of catching this [kahawai] is singular, and worthy of notice. A hook made of bone, with a piece of the glistening shell of the `mutton fish' attached to it, but without any farther bait, is trailed at a short distance behind a canoe, which is being paddled with the greatest possible speed.

Date:  0/0/1882
Source:  Brighter Britain
Author:  HAY
Vol / Page:  2/151
Edition:
Quote:  In the bays and tidal rivers are the mango or sharks - the most highly-prized food-fish - the tamure or schnapper, the whapuka or rock-cod, the kahawai or mackerel, the porahi or herring, the kanae or mullet, the patiki or sole, and many others. On the shores are oysters, mussels, cockles, mutton-fish, crabs, and other shell-fish in profuse abundance. In the fresh-water creeks are eels (tuna), lampreys (pipiharau), and whitebait (inanga).

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  310
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Mutton-fish a marine univalve molusc</i>, Haliotis naevosa, <i>Martyn: d from its flavour when cooked. The empty earshell of Haliotis</i>, especially in New Zealand, <i>Haliotis iris</i>, Martyn, is known as <i>Venus' Ear</i>; Maori name, <i>Paua<i> (q.v.). A species of the same genus is known and eaten at the Cape and in the Channel

Islands. (French name <i>Ormer,</i> sc. <i>Oreille de mer.</i>)

Quote:  <i>my colonial oath! </i>a mild expletive used usually as reinforcement, with variations such as <i>my oath!, my bloody oath!, my bloody colonial oath! </i>NZA.

Date:  26/8/1871
Source:  Timaru Herald
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  I called nearly everything a <i>faquement</i> (which name, by the way, I never yet saw in print, and cannot attempt to define); I protested on the authority of <i>my colonial oath</i>; learned to <i>plant</i> anything I wished to preserve; to <i>blow</i> about the <i>hammerings</i> I had given to men, whom I should not have dared to have touched with the end of a barge pole; to <i>finance</i> at cards whenever it was feasible; to give <i>fits</i> to whoever opposed me in discussions; and swear a <i>hurricane</i> if anything crossed my temper.

<i>Blue mackerel Scomber autralasicus</i> ... An Indo-Pacific species ... Often simply called mackerel, from its close similarity to the common mackerel (<i>Scomber scomber</i>) of the Northern Hemisphere ... In New Zealand it has often been called English mackerel and Pacific mackerel, but it is becoming more widely and appropriately known now as blue mackerel.

myrtle
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: various New Zealand myrtle-like plants, such as ramarama, rohutu; manuka, ?kanuka
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: also bush myrtle
Pronunciation:
Notes: also bush myrtle 		[1919 Jul 29] Ver. (WB).= Vernacular names used by settlers supplied by W. Best, Otaki (And) Myrtus bullata bush myrtle 1919 W Best (Otaki) Vernac. Andersen) (bush probably `growing in the bush'; possibly `growing as a bush-, or timber-, tree' (not as a shrub) cf. BUSH MANUKA) Myrtus bullata bush myrtle
Citations
Date:  0/1/1796
Source:  Journal
Author:  MURRY
Vol / Page:  2/534
Edition:
Quote:  [?KANUKA: not RATA or ?RAMARAMA] Capt. Cook has given so good a description of the Spruce Fir, that it is impossible to mistake it. But he has not taken any notice of the Pitch Pine - Birch - And large Myrtle. ... The Myrtle is not so large, it grows near the water, has a red bark, and is known by the smell of its leaf which very much resembles the smell of the leaf from which its [sic] takes its name, it is of use for turners or Cabinet makers, makes excellent block Pins, and from its hardness may be converted to many uses with which I am unacquainted.
Notes:  1796 Jan Murry's Journal of the `Britannia' in 1908 McNab Hist Recs. 2/534

Date:  30/3/1773
Source:  Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The
Author:  FORSTER
Vol / Page:  2/244
Edition:
Quote:  We ... found a fine Myrtle tree, the Leaves of which made good Tea. ... <i>March Ye 31st</i> In the afternoon we got flowers of the New Zeeland Teatree, & also a new Spidewell ... The next morning we tried all the three different Teas; viz: the Myrtle [[ed. fn]

<i>Leptospermum scoparium</i>], the Spruce & the New Zeeland one [[ed. fn] <i>L. ericoides ?</i>]; of which the first seems the most palatable.

Tay, it is useless, it only grows eight to twelve feet and the bark rough, and does not change. It seems very often Solitary. Away from every other Tree. Quote:  ... long list of timber trees whose fine stems are almost all disfigured with rank parasites. One of these parasites, the red myrtle, winding in and [ampersand] out of its patron becomes itself an enormous tree stifling the original growth ...[sic] as the first tree rots from its grasp. It is covered in season with lovely scarlet and [ampersand] gold flowers in shape like those of the English myrtle.
